div.p: THE HISTORY OF THE AMOURS OF THE Marhal de Boufflers: Or, a true Account of the LOVE-INTRIEGUES AND Gallant Adventures, WHICH Have been privately carry'd on by Him, ever ince He firt obtain'd a Command in the French King's Armies, till His Marriage with Mademoielle de Grammont.
The whole Relation being faithfully Tranlated into Englih, out of the French Original lately Publih'd at Paris.
LONDON: Printed for Edward Mory, at the Three Bibles in St. Paul's Church-yard. 1697.

div.head: TO THE MARCHIONESS OF Maintenon.
div.p:
'TIS to be hop'd that your Honour will not take it ill, that a Soldier of Fortune here preumes to appear before you; one who, with the Hero of the enuing Hitory, has been Partaker of the Toils and Fatigues, which are ineparable from the Art of War;
and who conequently, has had an opportunity to be an Eye-witnes as well of the Amorous Exploits, as Military Atchievments, perform'd by him in everal Countries; where either the King's Service, or the Glory of Arms, have call'd for his Preence. I have conider'd with my elf, MADAM, for a long time, about the choice of an Eminent Peron, to whom I might properly Dedicate this Hitorical Commentary, without being able to come to a final Reolution, as to that Particular: And indeed, there are different Motives, which induce Authors to act on the like Occaions: For ome do it, with a deign to procure for themelves ome powerful Patrons at Court; others, by way of acknowledgment for Favours already receiv'd; others, only to get the Name of an illutrious Peronage prefixt before their Works; and latly, others, purely out of a Principle of Candor and Generoity, without any manner of Affectation.

MADAM, I have reaon to boas¬Øt, even without Vanity or Otentation, that I am of the number of thee last; ince it is
not to ininuate my elf into your Favour, nor to ollicit you to make ue of your Interet with the King in my behalf, that I have at lat determin'd to make you a Preent of thee Gallantries of the Marhal de Boufflers. I do not (Thanks be to Heaven) tand in need of any of thee, or the like Advantages; but rather, on the contrary, am in a condition to light the Court-Favours, and to look upon the capricious Events of Fortune with Contempt. The true Motive, that has excited me to Dedicate this Hitory to your Honour, is the di-intereed Deire I have, to give you ome ort of Satisfaction, and to afford you in ome meaure, an agreeable Diverion for a few moments, in your Retirement at St. Cyr; by the Reading of a coniderable number of very remarkable Adventures relating to a Hero, for whom you have a mot cordial Affection, and whoe Fortune you have taken care to advance, by cauing him to be promoted to the principal Preferments in the Army, and very near, to the highet pitch of military Glory. Here your Honour may oberve your Darling-Favourite, ever ince he was able to trail a Pike in the King's Service, till his advancement
to the Dignity of Marhal of France, and even till his Marriage with Mademoielle de Grammont; ometimes expos'd to the greatet Misfortunes that can be imagin'd; and ometimes appearing Triumphant, as it were the mot fortunate of all Mortals; according to the variety of Accidents caus'd by the capricious Humours of the God of Love. Indeed the trangenes of the urpriing Events, of which we are inform'd by this not able Hitory, might at firt ight, give occaion to upect it to be a kind of Romance made at pleaure, much rather than a Narrative of Matters of Fact; were it not that your Honour has divers faithful Witnees to aert the Truth of the various Occurrences related in it. For you have receiv'd an Account of a coniderable part of thee Adventures, from Monieur Bouffler's own Mouth, altho' they are uch as have been hither to unknown to the World, and the Dicovery of which, as I preume, cannot but be very acceptable: Neither will it be any difficult Task to jutifie ome other particular Circumtances, of which you may poibly doubt; ince the Hero himelf of our preent Hitory, will make no cruple to
be my Voucher as to the reality of thoe Events.

However it may be taken, 'tis evident, that Truth may be dicover'd by certain Lineaments, which cannot be hid from the ight of the more judicious part of Mankind; not with tanding the Endeavours that ome Authors have us'd of late, to conceal from the publick View, uch precious Fragments, which give us an Idea of the good and ill Fate that attends mortal Men in this ublunary World. 'Tis well known, MADAM, that you are the mot agacious, and mot accomplih'd Lady in the Court of France, and therefore you may eaily dicern that this Hitory does not contain any thing that is fabulous or fictitious: Nevertheles, your Honour's Approbation will be of very great moment to recommend it to the World, and will not a little contribute to caue it to be ought for, by all ingenious Peronages; epecially by thoe Honourable Ladies, who have a great Eteem for Monieur de Boufflers, and will not be dipleas'd at the care I have taken to communicate to 'em a coniderable number of private Love-Intriegues, manag'd
by a Hero, who is at preent the Adonis of France, and the greatet Warriour that that Nation can boat of, ince the Death of the famous Duke of Luxemburg. I hall no longer trepas upon your Honour's Patience; only while I beg leave to tile my elf, with all poible Repect and Submiion,

closer.signed: Your mot humble and mot obedient Servant, D. P. E.

div.head: THE HISTORY Of the AMOURS Of the Marhal de Boufflers.
div.p:
SOME Perons who eteem LOVE as the Sweetet and mot tender of all other Paions, have imagin'd it to be more epecially appropriated to the Female Sex: But whoever will take the pains to look back into the ancient Records, may be oon convinc'd that it has extended its Conquets, not only over the Fair Sex, but alo over the greatet Men in all Ages; and that even the mot Famous Warriours amidt their dangerous Enterpries, have too often felt its effects, and
been forc'd to ubmit to its Irreitible Power. Let us but look backwards upon thoe great Heroes, Alexander, Caear and Pompey; cou'd the greatnes of their Deigns ever make 'em abandon their amourous Intrigues? They carce ever drew their Swords, but with an intent to pleae their Mitreses, and to make them to be harers in their mot glorious Victories. Has not Love been too often the occaion of Bloody Wars, and of the Detruction of whole Countries? Has it not undermin'd and over-thrown the Stronget Towers? Why then hou'd it be denied that it Sympathies in a mot extraordinary manner with Mars the God of War. I am apt to believe it to be an unquetionable Truth, that all Mankind feel the effects of Cupid's Arrows; who does not pare a Throne, making even Scepters and Crowns ubmit to his Empire. When the Glory of Martial Exploits and a well proportion'd Body meet in one Peron, they are uch Powerful, or rather irreitible Charms to a tender Heart, that nothing is able to hold out againt 'em. The Hitories of all Ages are full of uch intances to convince us, that even the mot Illutrious Heroes in former Ages, as well as ours, have been carried beyond their Bounds by this Paion, even to that degree, that by the Inchantment of their Mitrees charms, they often become forgetful of their
Duty, having Sacrifis'd to their o much ador'd Deities all their Glory and Renown, which with a Thouand hazards and the los of their Blood, they had before accquir'd, under Mars's Standard. There are never theles not wanting Examples of others, who having made it their chief aim to fight, and to Sacrifice their Lives for their Prince, have been able at leat for ome time to depie and withtand the Force of Love.

The Marhal de Boufflers, whoe amourous Adventures I am about to relate, is of this number: For tho' he had always a trong Inclination to Pleaure, and epecially to uch Love-intrigues as are uual among Gentlemen, he has notwithtanding all this, always kept uch a ballance between Love and Glory, that the firt of thee two Paions, tho' otherwie the mot powerful, has never been able to fully his Martial Glory; our General having ever hew'd himelf as much a Soldier as a Gallant, as will more plainly appear from the following Relation.

Love leads Mankind, even from their Youth thro' o many capricious Adventures, that it is always impoible to avoid its inchanting nares: Let us but conider that we are all made of the ame Clay, of which our fore-Father, Adam was created, who was not trong enough to reit the enticements of a Woman made either for his Detruction,
or pathaps for his comfort, why then hou'd we expect to excel him in this particular? But to return to our Hitory, Monieur de Boufflers had in his younger Years altogether addicted himelf to Hunting, and Amourous divertiements, the latter being never theles for the mot part predominant; when after ome time thus pent in amourous Delights, one of his Friends advis'd him to enter into the King's Service. He having for ome time entertain'd this noble Deign, his Mind was wholly empoly'd in finding out means how to make a Figure in the Court of France, which cou'd not be done without very great expence: The Marhal, who was born a Gentleman in the Province of Picardie, (where Gold is a pretty carce Commodity) was put to a great non plus as to this Affair; when one Day walking all alone in his Garden, and muing upon his preent Circumtances, the ame Friend very eaonably urpris'd him; and by offering him his Pure and all his Credit, freed him from his preent trouble; adding withal, that by this means he might purchae the Royal Regiment of Dragoons, which was then to be old by the King's Order. The Marhal receiv'd the Courtey of his Kinman with a great deal of Joy and thankfulnes, and having by his aitance compleated his Deign, he aw himelf in a little while after at the Head of a Regiment,
which carries along with it Terrour and Admiration, whereever it comes. The poor Protetants of France have been ufficiently enible of it to their cot: But let us leave this doleful Subject, and return to Monieur Boufflers, whom for the Reader's Diverion I will draw to the Life, before I proceed: To peak without vanity there is carce any one that is better able to performe it than my elf, having had the Honour to know him, and to have been his Companion even from his Infancy, and having follow'd him in all his Martial Exploits, as well as Love-Intrigues. If any fault is to be found in the Picture, which I am about to draw, thoe that epie it, I hope, will rather attribute it to the defect of my Pencil and Colours, than to any other imperfection. But let us ee him as naturally drawn as can be, without any Diguie. Our General, who was formerly a Marques of the Marquiate of Boufflers, is a Peron of a mean Stature, but very well et, trong and vigourous in all his Actions, even to exces at certain times. His Eyes are black, prightly and full of Fire, his looks fierce and omewhat tern among Men; but very weet and charming, when he ly's protrate at the Feet of a beautiful Woman; where I have een him making his Courthip a thouand times, with all the Sweetnes imaginable. He has omething, I know
not what extraordinary in his Countenance and Behaviour, which begets him Repect and Veneration. His Face is mooth, of an oval Figure, his Fore-head high, and his whole Phyiognomy the bet compos'd that ever I aw; thee are the advantages which bounteous Nature has betow'd upon him, let us oberve thoe for which he is beholding to his Sword, and whereby he has rais'd himelf to the greatet Preferments in France. During his abode in Paris, he knew o well by what means to ininuate himelf into the favour of the chief Generals, who at that time commanded the Kings Armies, that they receiv'd him among the number of their mot intimate Friends; On the other hand, he made his Court with o much Addres to thoe Ladies who were then mot belov'd by that Monarch, that by their favour he eaily obtain'd whatever he wih'd for at Court; among the ret he paid the mot repect and mot aiduous Viits, to the two Marchionees of Montepan and Maintenon, but the later, who at that time began to have the mot Soveraign Acendant over the King, did recommend him o effectually, and in terms o obliging to that Prince, that thereby he made his Fortune with the King. The Prince of Conde, firt Prince of the Blood, and the Marhal Schomberg, were not behind hand in advancing his Fortune,
thoe two great Warriours having procur'd him the Advantage of being employ'd in the next Campaigne, which was in the Year 1678, where he ignalis'd himelf by his Valour at the Siege of Puicerda, which is one of the bet Cities in Catalonia, ituated in a fair Plain, on the River Segre. The Marhal and Duke de Navaille who commanded in chief before the Place, was o taken with his Bravery, that he lov'd him no otherwie than a Brother, and commended his great Actions to all his Friends; for he never fear'd any Fatigue, being frequently accutom'd during the Campaign to leep in his Boots and Accoutrements, hewing by his example to the Dragoons, whoe General he was, that by hardhip and Toils, as by o many teps they mut acend to the Pinnacle of Glory: He was always the lat that dimounted, and the firt that mounted his Hore. If his Troops reted in any place, he himelf was wont to go the rounds, and viit the advanced Guards; if any Attack were to be made, you'd certainly find him at the Head of his Troops, with an undaunted Courage, animating them by his Example. Thee are thoe extraordinary Endowments befitting o great a Captain, that have rais'd him to that Advantagious Pot, in which we now ee him; The King his Mater having ince
the Siege of Namur, where he defended that City, like a great Warriour, made him a Duke and Peer of France, not without hopes that his Majety will in time be pleas'd to make him Contable. Now let us take a view of his Amorous Exploits, thee being the chief Subject of our preent Relation. 'Tis not to be thought trange that o famous a Soldier as the Marhal de Boufflers, has often languih'd in the Arms of ome Beauty or another, For he has been as Victorious in his Conquets of Love as in his Martial feats, and one may affirm, that he has been crown'd with Roes and Lawrels as frequently in the Field of Venus, as in that of Mars. Part of the French Frontiers have been the Theater, where both his Amourous and Military Expeditions have been repreented: The City of Puicerda, of which I have poken before, will furnih us with a Subject of this Nature.

The Prince de Conti and the Duke de Navaille having made themelves Maters of this Placeby Capitulation, the Troops were for ome time ent into Quarters of refrehment. At this time it was, that Love which eldom lets lip any Opportunity, did peirce the Heart of the Marhal de Boufflers: The God of Love, who diplays his Standard in the Field of Peace and Tranquility, having found it not impenetrable. In hort, the Marhal was deperately Wounded by the
bright Eyes of a Spanih Widow, whom he accidentally met in a Boat paing the River Segre. The name of this fair Lady was Donna Olympia, who beides that he was very amiable in her Peron, by her courteous Deportment to our General, and her charming and engaging Air conquer'd his Heart: As he poke very good French, o he offer'd her his Service in leading her out of the Boat with an intention to have accompanied her to her own Houe; but he notwithtanding her Heart began to feel ome emotions for him, did refue his offer, telling him that the Cutom of her Country did not allow of uch a Civility; that it wou'd be thought very trange if uch a Gentleman as he hou'd Conduct a Lady home to her own Appartment; that uch a thing wou'd be ufficient to ruin her Reputation for ever. A certain grave old Matron, whoe name was Trea Alleva, (uch a one as they call in Spain the Guardians of Young Women,) taking notice of what pas'd between 'em, began to urge her to go home, telling her with a very our Countenance, with her great Spectacles upon her Noe, that her Dicoure was too long with a Stranger, Alas! my dearet cry'd Olympia, (who already began to feel ome effects of Love towards the Marhal) my Heart does even now too much foretell me my Detiny of Loving one day this Stranger. Madam,
reply'd the old Woman Smiling, you are oon intangl'd in the Snares of Love, without making a due Reflection upon what you are going about to do: Your Love towards a Frenchman is too foreward; if your Relations hou'd be inform'd of this matter you'‚ÄîThe Marhal, who undertood the threats of Trea Alleva, thought it time to quit his Mitres, and having queez'd her fair hand, he whiper'd her in the Ear, where he might ee her again, if it were poible for him to live without her till after to morrow? Jut by that Seat, which you ee built at the Foot of that Rock, aid he, with a very paionate Air, I hope to have the good Fortune to talk with you to morrow about ten a Clock at night, if my Paion do not deprive me of this Life before that time. This was enough for the Marhal, who did now fanie himelf the happiet Man in the whole World; o that the ret of that day and the next following, eem'd to him a Year, or (according to the Hyperbolical expreions of Lovers) an Age, which he pent in making reflections upon his approaching Felicity and Pleaures.

Which way, wou'd he ay to himelf, hall I begin to Court my Mitres? What Favours hall I ask firt? It mut not aid he, Smiling, be toee her Feet, for the Spanih Lady's wou'd dye as oon as let any one ee
or touch them, they being commonly o very mall, that they appear like a Puppet's, in comparion of thoe of Men. Their own Hubands mut not pretend to uch a favour. Our General, who does not admire delays in Love, was extremely diturb'd at firt with his growing Paion; but whilt he was ruminating upon the trangenes of this Adventure, and by his amourous conceits, had et himelf all over in a Flame. The appointed hour of the Rendez-vous drew near; he went to the place nominated by his Mitres, and having pa'd everal times by the Houe, he perceiv'd no Body, which almot drove him to depair, having lot all hopes of ever eeing again the Object which Tormented him with o much Violence. The Marhal waited almot an Hour, expecting what wou'd be the iue of this Adventure; when he by the help of the Moonlight perceiv'd a Woman at a Window, playing with her Fingers after a trange manner: This is a certain way us'd in Spain, for Lover thus to peak to one another; in a mute Language, the Marhal who was unacquainted with this odd way of Courthip, did not undertand the meaning of it; but being come nearer to the Window, which was pretty low, and having perceiv'd that it was his new Mitres who call'd to him, he at that Moment made ue of all the mot
tender Expreions, which are uual with Men at the beginning of a mot violent Paion. Donna Olympia was thereby touch'd to the very Heart; and told him in a languihing Tone: Sir, pray don't peak o loud, we dare not make ue in this Country of our Liberty as we cou'd wih; and turning all what the General had aid into Raillery; is it poible, aid he, that o lovely a Gentleman as you hou'd have left France, the very dwelling place of Love, without ome very trong praeengagement? Alas! without Flattering my elf, I can carce be perwaded that you are come hither, without having lot ome part of your Liberty. My cae wou'd be deperate, Madam, reply'd the Marhal gallantly, to have lot it before I had the opportunity to lay it at your Feet: The mot mierable Etate unto which you have reduc'd me, is a convincing Proof of it; you having depriv'd me of my own elf. I was not able to reit uch dangerous blows as Yours; you have Wounded me in the mot enible Part; I did Love or rather adore you from the very firt Moment I aw you. There is none but you, that can make me Fortunate or unfortunate; Pronounce therefore with your own charming Lips my Sentence of Life or Death.

Donna Olympia look'd upon her Lover with Eyes which ufficiently declar'd her Paion,
and finding that Love began to overcome her Reaon, he reply'd not without ome confuion: O Heavens! How weak do I find my elf at this Intant? What crime am I going to commit againt my Duty? Sir, Sir pray have pitty upon me. The Marhal was vext to the very Soul, that he cou'd not make ue of o Favourable an Opportunity as preented it elf; he cou'd have wih'd that the Wall which parted his Beloved and him, had been of Paper or Cloth, that he might have made his way thro' it: He truck with his Sword everal times againt the Window, the Enemy of his happines, but alas! in vain, for he found her o barricado'd up with Iron Grates, that he cou'd carce put a Finger thro' it. His belov'd Angel, who was not inenible of his diquiet, and wou'd very willingly have had a more ecret interview with him, cry'd out to him, take Courage, Sir, Fortune has always a kind chance for Lovers. The Marhal was o Tranported with this charming Expreion, that he cou'd not forebear telling her: Divine Creature, I dye a thouand times a day by a mot violent Death, being uncertain of my detiny; if you be o Inhumane and Cruel as to deny me your pity, and prohibit me to enjoy the Pleaure of eeing you in Private. Rather uffer, that after having declar'd my Paion and what Pains you have made me undergo,
I may dye for grief at your Feet: But continu'd he, I am reolv'd to do it without delay, and drawing his Sword, and putting the Point towards his Breat, I will ayd he, dye in your Sight: He wore thee Words in o Melancholy a Tone, that Donna Olympia fearing he was in earnet, cry'd out all in Tears, hold, hold, for Heaven's ake, don't let your Paion drive you into depair, don't make your elf the mot Criminal of all Mankind; why will you make an attempt againt your own elf, for want of a little Patience? Preerve your elf for my ake, and I promie that I will find out a more favourable Opportunity. The Marhal eem'd extremely pleas'd with the aurances he had receiv'd from his Mitres, and glad that his feign'd attempt had made her believe that his intent of killing himelf in her preence was real; tho' God knows, it was the leat of his Thoughts, being not o much a Fool as to dye for her ake. Nevertheles looking upon her with a very Paionate Eye, Madam, aid he, I am infinitely oblig'd to your Goodnes, for aving my Life, which was ready to be Sacrific'd before you, if you had not topt my Hand, and thereby prevented the fatal Stroak, I hou'd have certainly executed it without delay; but now ince you flatter me with hopes of eeing you again in private; I will leave my mot adorable
Olympia, to convince you of the greatnes of that Paion, which I have for you, and to hew you that an Age will not be long enough to atisfy my Deires. The fair Spaniard perceiving ome of her Women to come that way, retir'd into another Chamber; and the Mar. who urmis'd that ome body had urpris'd her whilt he was talking with him, retir'd omewhat backward from the Window, with a reolution nevertheles to tay all Night to watch an opportunity of entertaining his Mitres a econd time. Having thus walk'd up and down near the Ditch of an adjacent Catle, he aw at the very break of day, a Black-Moor coming from under the Ground out of a Vault, and making up towards him, who preented to him the following Letter:
SIR,
I hou'd think my elf over happy if I cou'd find Words uitable to that Paion which I have for you. But alas! I find my elf quite at a los in this point of extremity, and if I may judge of your Love by my own; both are beyond Expreion. If Abence were able to cure it, I wou'd make ue of that Remedy, but I am too well convinc'd to the contrary. Wherefore let nothing diturb your quiet, but ret atisfy'd, that you hall ee me very hortly, that is to ay to Morrow at the ame Hour. The ame Page who has deliver'd this
Letter to you, is to conduct you into my Chamber, by the ame way that he came out to you: In the mean time be not Impatient; and remember that you are anwerable to me for a Heart, which you have Robb'd me of in pite of all my reitance; This hall be the reward of your Sufferings, if you continue to Love me.

The Marhal who had not without ome fear taken the Letter from the Black-moor, did imagine that perhaps it might be the Devil who was come from the infernal Regions, on purpoe do him ome michief, and being at ome uncertainty what to reolve upon; he went back to his Lodgings, and enquir'd of his Land-Lady, as well as he cou'd in the Spanih Tongue (which he undertood very well) whether he knew that Lady who liv'd at the Foot of that Rocky Catle, which he nam'd to her. Yes, very well, aid he, he is the Relict of a certain honet Gentleman, who is lately dead, his Name was that of the Marques of Toledo; but good God! continu'd he, how unhappy is that pretty Creature ince the Death of her Huband, who lov'd her even to a degree of Folly? She is at preent under the Government of a Brother, who Tyrannies over her like his Slave, not allowing her the Liberty of peaking one word to any Man. His name is Don Bilboano; he is Jealous even
to a degree of Madnes, and 'tis the common dicoure of the Town, that he is in Love with his Siter. At that rate, reply'd the Marhal carelely, as if he had not known her; a Man mut expoe himelf to no mall danger, if he hou'd go about to Court her for a Wife. O Lord! cry'd the good Woman, being much urpris'd, this cruel Man threatens to Sheath his Sword in the Breat of any Gentleman that hall have the boldnes, o much as to think of his Siter; he intending to be her only abolute Mater. Here the Marhal interrupting her aid, but for God's ake do you believe that Donna Olympia entertains her Brother's Paion? I don't believe he does, reply'd the Woman; for how can o charming a Creature as he Love the mot ill hap'd of all Men? for beides that, he is as ugly as the Devil; he has a hunch Back, enough to frighten Children withal, and his Legs are as crooked as a Hoop; tho' as to his internal Qualities, he is not inferiour to any Man, having accomplih'd himelf in all manner of Arts and Sciences. Monieur Boufflers being extremely well pleas'd with the Womans Anwer, which he found very agreeable; and puruing the former Dicoure, ask'd her what was the reaon that this Marchiones had chang'd her Name from Donna Toleda to Donna Olympia. Oh! reply'd he, that is the contrivance of that
ill favour'd piece her Brother, who will have it o. This evil Spirit cannot endure the name of his Brother in Law, his Head being fill'd with a fancy, that his Siter is a Maid till, and that he may enjoy her as uch. This is an extravagant piece of Folly, reply'd the Marhal, uch a Fellow as this, if he liv'd in France, wou'd be ent to the Houe of Correction. It is not the Spanih fahion, anwer'd the Woman, to imprion Gentlemen for being in Love with their Siters; there are o many examples of this nature, that nothing is more common: Every one loves here what he likes bet, without making any further Reflection upon the matter.

The Marhal de Boufflers having ended this Dicoure with his Land-Lady, retir'd to his Chamber, ruminating with himelf concerning what he had undertood from her. His Thoughts were much ditracted the whole Night, and the Day following: He began to conider with himelf to what danger he was about to expoe himelf, if Donna Olympia's Brother hou'd find him with her; if this ugly Devil, this Aeop hou'd, aid he dicover our Intrigue, we are both undone without Remedy; Plague on him! that this Monter hou'd have o good a Head-piece; but let it be as it will, the hopes of poeing o charming a Creature is a ufficient Recompence for a little danger. Having taken
this Reolution, he went towards the Rendez-vous, dres'd like an Adonis, and was no ooner come near the Gate of the Vault, when he aw the ame Black-Moor with a Pike in his Hand, ready to attend him.

The firt thing he did, was to demand the Marhal's Sword, and what other Arms he had about him, which o urpris'd the Marhal, that he made ome difficulty of granting it. But the Black-Moor, who poke good French, inform'd him that it was the Cutom of the Country, for any Gentleman to leave his Sword at the Door, before he enter'd a Lady's Appartment. I know very well, reply'd the General, that this is practis'd in your common Houes, but the Cae is otherwie here, where I believe my elf to be in a Peron of Qualities Lodgings. No matter for that anwer'd the Moor with a Smile, give us your Sword, Sir, give us your Sword; Love having by this time overcome his Reaon; he deliver'd up his Sword to the Moor, with ome Lovis's d'or, at which the Black-Moor being overjoy'd, aur'd our General of his Fidelity, telling him that he needed fear nothing, ince he was left to his care; for aid he, Don Bilboaono the Brother of this Lady, is uch a Devil of a Man, that there is not one in the whole Houe, that has not wih'd him to the Devil thee ten Years: Well it's enough
my Friend, reply'd Monieur de Boufflers, come lead me to your Mitreses Chamber. Donna Olympia having over-heard thee lat words, open'd the Door of her Cloet, and the Marhal being enter'd, found her almot half undres'd, leaning upon a Couch embroider'd with very fine Flowers. Her Complexion being very fair, and the Room where he was, beautify'd with Black Marble, and illuminated with a great many Wax-tapers; he appear'd to him more beautiful than an Angel.

He did not approach without bearing the marks of a profound repect in his Countenance, and having et one of his Knees before her on the Ground. 'Tis none but you ay'd he, Divine Creature, that has the Power of Captivating my Reaon. Your beauty has o far atonih'd me, that I am Tranported even beyond my elf. Then a charming bluh cover'd her Face and Breats, which made our Spanih Lady appear without comparion, the fairet in the World. After he rie from her Couch, he went to the Looking Glas, where he pretended to et in order ome of the puffs of her Hair; which were interwoven with the finet Diamonds that ever were een: The Marhal then epying one of her little Hands whiter than the very Snow, he kis'd it for the pace of half an Hour without intermiion.
This his paionate Behaviour made Donna Olympia bluh; and cating a very amourous look at him; Pray Sir aid he, either moderate your Paion, or I am undone; Good God ait me! Where hall I find trength enough to reit you? Ah! Madam, reply'd he, how is it poible for me, not to be enible of your powerful Charms? It is you that inpire me alone at this Moment, and I can wear and protet to you, that in all my Life-time I never was o much enamour'd as now, having never met with any Object, which appear'd to me o adorable as your elf, not only in point of Beauty, but alo with repect to all other Perfections, which are able to charm a Mortal Man. Sir, anwer'd the Lady with a languihing Air, is it poible that a Frenchman can be incere? It is the general Opinion among us here, that their Amours are never real, but meer Compliments and atteries. By Heaven Sir, uch a ort of Love wou'd not very well agree with my Contitution: And hall never receive any Encouragement from me.

Here the Marhal interrupted her with a Kis, I know very well ay'd he, Madam, that I ought to offer you omething more Subtantial than bare Words; but it is not always adviable to be too forward; don't you know that when a Fort is to be Attackt, we firt take a view of its Avenues and Out-works. Donna Olympia, who wou'd fain have perwaded the Marhal that he
did not undertand his meaning, began to play with her little ucking Pig, which was adorn'd with red Ribands. This Creature had alo Silver-Bells in his Ears and about his Neck; nay, even at the Tail, which made a trange kind of Harmony: This is the Fahion among the Spanih Lady's, who chue rather to carry a little ucking Pig under their Arm, than the finet Lap-dog; 'Tis their Cutom to make it queek, when their Gallants ask 'em a Favour. Our Marhal, who perceiv'd her intent, took it from her, and put it into a little Hutch, made for that purpoe. Then renewing his Courthip with a Thouand amourous Sighs: He at lat forc'd thee words from her fair Lips, Oh! I Love you with a mot violent Paion. And what Proof, reply'd the Marhal (embracing her) will you give me of your Paion? You will not grant me the leat Favour; Ay, don't you know that Love is a Child, which pines after the utmot Favour? And what Sir, reply'd he, mut a Woman keep nothing to her elf, when he is to prove that he Loves? Are not Oaths trong and convincing enough to Lovers? Then laying her Thumb a cros one of her other Fingers, and kiing it a thouand times, according to the Spanih Fahion, he told him, I Love you above my Life; 'Tis impoible for me to believe you, Madam, reply'd
the Marhal in tealing ome Kies from her fair Lips, its meerly impoible to believe it, except you grant me that which is the only Pledge requir'd by Lovers, Surely reply'd he, with a very erious Countenance, I can carce perwade my elf that your Words are anwerable to your Intentions, for hou'd I grant your deire, you wou'd ceae to Love me as oon as you had enjoy'd me; don't you know that that Favour which you eek for with o much Heat, is the Grave of Love. How many gallant Heroes have we known who have been Bury'd under its ruins; and who have been lot when they thought themelves at the very Port of Felicity? The expectation of the Pleaure, will far exceed the enjoyment it elf.

Thee Obtacles made by Olympia againt the Marhal's Paion, did only erve to inflame it and to quicken his deire of making himelf Mater of that piece of Ground, which he o Valiantly defended; and his Paion growing more violent every moment, he cou'd not forbear telling her, that if he let him languih thus any longer, he hou'd dye intantly at her Feet, Donna Olympia then finding her trength to fail her, and fearing that he hou'd not be able to hold out much longer againt her charming Conqueror (as he was wont to call him,) very courteouly deir'd him to withdraw for that time, becaue the day began to appear, and
that her Brother was accutom'd to walk the Rounds in the Houe every Morning early, who if he hou'd find a Man in her Chamber, they both wou'd be in great danger of their Lives. The Marhal having undertood her meaning, with a profound reverence quitted the Room, promiing to renew his Viit in a hort time, Yes, Sir aid he, giving him her Hand (which he kis'd very Paionately) I promie it hall be o, my Heart is only too forward to give its conent to o agreeable an Entertainment; don't fail to ee me to morrow at the ame Hour in my Chamber. You may believe Madam, reply'd the Marhal, that I hall be overjoy'd to Execute your Commands, in which my Love is o nearly concern'd, and that every Hour; nay, every Moment, will eem an Age to me, till uch time that‚ÄîMedina a Relation of this Lady coming towards her Chamber, and having made ome noie in opening a door, he oblig'd our General to Decamp, with his whole Army of Sighs and Languihing Expreions: He return'd to his ordinary Pot: I mean to his own Lodgings where intead of Sleep, he was overwhelm'd with a Thouand amourous Fancies: Donna Olympia flatter'd her elf with having gain'd a great Point, ince by breaking off the Conference, he had preerv'd that which indeed he was ready to part with. Her Heart was torn
in pieces by two different Paions, for if her Vertue induc'd her trongly to its preervation, on the other hand he was apt to reproach her elf for not having been more favourable to her Lover. Medina having perceiv'd the Confuion he was in, and drawing nearer to her, ask'd her in very affectionate terms the caue of her diquiet. Alas! cry'd he, my Dearet, I am the mot unfortunate of all living Creatures. Nothing but Death can expiate a crime which I have committed againt my own elf; Vertue trongly oppoes my Inclinations; but Alas! I am in Love, to my eternal Confuion, with the mot dangerous of all Men, who from the firt Moment, I aw him, has over-rul'd my Reaon. I have reited this Paion with all my Strength, endeavouring to tifle it in its Birth, but this too tender, too Paionate Heart, has at lat been forc'd to yield to its Conquerour. I am now no longer Mitres of it; he triumphs over it in pite of all my reitance. Madam, reply'd Medina, (he being a Lady of a very ubtil Wit) Who is that happy Mortal, that has uch powerful Charms? What is become of that graceful haughtines which never left you till this time? Oh! reply'd the Marchiones Sighing, I do not know my elf my Dearet, there is omething fatal in the matter, I am contrain'd to ubmit to the preent influences of my Stars. Madam, reply'd the young Lady, take courage, I don't believe that Love is o dangerous
and terrible as you decribe it. If Love be a crime, it is one of the mot Innocent, and very few Mortals are exempted from it. Who can without injutice condemn a Paion taught us by Nature it elf? Epecially ince we our elves are not the caue of thoe Effects which he produces; it is he her elf who is the Caue of that Sin, which appears o hanious in your Sight.

He whom I love reply'd Donna Olympiae briskly, is rather the caue of it. My Paion has quite overcome my Reaon. Oh! Madam reply'd Medina with a Smile, this is the way to poil all the pleaures of Love; but pray tell me who is this happy Man? He is a Frenchman my Dearet, anwerd the fair Spaniard with a bluh; he is a French Gentleman the mot charming of all Men, who has robb'd me of my Heart, without the leat hopes of recovering it, this only way being left me to revenge my elf upon him to robb him of his again.

'Tis very odd, reply'd the young Lady, and pray Madam, what is his Name, it may be I may know him? Well my dear Medina, anwer'd Donna Olympia, covering her Face with a veil, ince you are reolv'd to make me confes the truth to my own Confuion; know that it is the Marques de Boufflers, Colonel of a Regiment of Dragoons, which are quarter'd hereabouts, and have lately erv'd in the Siege of Puicerda;
his Courage and Bravery is very well known in thee Parts. The Marques de Boufflers Madam, reply'd Medina, as being urpris'd, Oh! I know him very well, I have een him often at Paris, when I belonged to the Queen's Retinue. And what Queen do you mean, ay'd Donna Olympia? (her Head running upon other matters.) How Madam, reply'd Medina (who cou'd not forbear laughing) ure you have not forgot that the French King has Marry'd the Siter of the King of Spain our Monarch, the Infanta Maria Thereia. Oh! you are in the right, reply'd the Marchiones, embracing her at the ame time; I had quite forgot it; then you know that fair Thyris who has charm'd me, and what do you think of him? I Madam, anwer'd the young Lady very modetly, I think him to be a very accomplih'd Gentleman; but otherwie, I take him to be as fickle in his Amours as the ret of the French are, who make it their buines to Court one Beauty after another, to tell 'em of their Sufferings, of their Sighs and Pains, which eldom are any where to be found but in their Compliments and Bilets Douces, which they are continually ending to their Mitrees, and thoe are foolih enough to believe that they are in Love with 'em. I had not long ago a Letter by me, the mot
paionate in the World, which this General wrote to the Marchiones de Segnelay, Lady to one of the Secretaries of State, in which he had o lively painted the exces of his Paion, that one wou'd have believ'd a Man cou'd not live long under uch an Agony. He told her, that her Eyes did every day commit a great many Murders, for which he mut be accountable to God, and that it was Inhuman in her to dipeople in uch a manner the whole Kingdom of France. Cou'd any thing be more Hyperbolical, cou'd any thing be more Nicely contriv'd, to cajole a Poor Lady, who lov'd him in good earnet? Alas! my Dearet, aid Donna Olympia, don't draw the Picture of him, who has robb'd me of my Liberty, o much to his diadvantage; if thou wert convinc'd as well as I that 'tis to late for me to reit his power, thou wou'dt pity me. To be hort, I Love him, and 'tis? not in my power to avoid it. She had no ooner poke thee Words, but he flew out of the Chamber and lockt her elf up in her Cloet, where amidt a Flood of Tears: Alafs, cry'd he; Cruel Love, thou hat aail'd my Heart at a time when it was leat a ware of thy mot dangerous Snares. Heaven that knows the ecrets of my Heart, is my Witnes that my Paion is uch that its impoible for Female power to reit it. Am not I the mot unhappy
of all Women, to wih at this very intant for the ight of him, who is the greatet Enemy of my repoe: I wou'd fain banih thee Thoughts, which only erve to feed my Paion, intead of checking it, which I am enible wou'd be much more to my Advantage. But good God! How hard it is for a Woman of my Age to take a firm Reolution upon uch a Critical Conjuncture; and how much more difficult it is to put it in Execution! I can only ay thus much, that I wih I cou'd do that which I am confident is not in my Power.

Thus the Lady having pent the greater part of the Day, and the next following Night, the Marhal found her taken up with thee Tormenting Fancies. As oon as he enter'd the Room, he renew'd his former Courthips; auring her, (as he was always accutom'd to do) of the violence of his Paion. Donna Olympia receiv'd him omewhat coldly, and Monieur Boufflers being urpris'd at this udden change, broke out into thee Words, Divine Creature; unto what mut I attribute this indifferency, which I meet with in you at this time? What crime have I committed that cou'd deerve this Cruel Treatment from your Hands? He had no ooner poke thee Words, but he fell intantly into a Swoon at the Feet of the Marchiones, who being
extremely concern'd at this ight, threw her elf upon him, embracing him very Paionately; for he was afraid that as oon as he hou'd recover himelf, he wou'd have recoure to his Sword, againt his own Life, (as he had everal times threatn'd he wou'd) but not finding his Sword at his ide, he was exceively Tranported with joy, not doubting but that her Black-moor had taken it from him before he came into her Chamber. In the mean time, he was not pareing of her Carees nor Kies, in hopes by that means to recover him out of his Swoon, which indeed was only feigned; nevertheles he held it out thus, as long as ever he was able, having ince proteted to me, that in all his Life-time, he never receiv'd o much Satisfaction and Pleaure, as at that time, when he was thus entangl'd in the embraces of this fair Lady, whoe Paion being then without diguie, did ufficiently tetify that he Lov'd him in good earnet. He continu'd for ome Moments in this charming Extaie, ere the fair Spaniard cou'd make him come out of his voluntary Trance, and that not without a Thouand Amourous Kies, when he begg'd of him to it down by her, upon a Turky-work Carpet; where he perceiv'd a flood of Tears trickling down the Cheeks of his fair Mitres: Being now very well recover'd; he began to renew his
former Addrees, and to give the mot lively repreentation of his Sufferings and Pains. You ay you Love me, Madam, added he, looking upon her with a very Paionate Eye, and why will you then deny me that Favour which I have o often Su'd for? If you will not any longer delay to grant me the utmot Favour, I here Swear and protet to you, that nothing hall be able to eparate me from you, and that I will not Love any thing beides you in the World.

Thoe that know the Marhal de Boufflers, to be one of the mot incontant Lovers in the World, who eteems it the greatet misfortune that can befal a Gentleman, to Love one Object longer than a Month or two at the mot; will eaily imagine, that he did train the Point to the utmot, when he made this Oath. Donna Olympia on the other ide, who had not forgot what her Kinwoman had told her concerning his incontancy, propos'd a Match between 'em, which exceedingly urpris'd him, his Thoughts being very far from Marriage at that time, epecially in a Foreign Country. As oon as he had recover'd himelf from this Surprie he endeavour'd to conceal his entiments, and to appear as gay in his Humour as before. He was not Ignorant, that if a Gentleman does expect the lat Favour from a fair Lady in Spain, he mut not deny her any thing;
wherefore turning the Dicoure another way, he promis'd to end her ome of the bet Pearls and Diamonds, and uch other valuable things, as he cou'd procure in the City. This Generous offer inenibly overcame the rigour of the Fair Spaniard, and tho' her lover had not at this time mention'd what he mot wih'd for, he imputed it to the profound repect he believ'd he had for her.

The Marhal, who is as great a Mater in the Art of Love as in that of War, did not ceae to advance his approaches with vigour, and to lay a formal Siege to that place, which he was reolv'd to Conquer; it mut be confes'd, the acces to it was very difficult; but he beieg'd it o cloely, and Attck'd it o vigourouly, that at lat the White Flagg was put up, tho' Donna Olympia for this time deferr'd to ign the Capitulation. She told him that he was not as yet ufficiently prepar'd for a total urrender; that he expected to receive the Marks of his Generoity, as to thoe Preents, which he had poke of before; and that in the mean time he wou'd preent to him a very fine Scarff, which formerly belong'd to her deceas'd Husband, and which was curiouly Embroyder'd, by her own Hands. The Marhal having receiv'd the Preent, departed very well atisfy'd for that time. After he had Din'd, he went into the City, where he bought ome of the finet Amethyts and
alds that he cou'd meet with, and having intermix'd 'em with ome Diamonds of good value, ent 'em a little after, by one of his Dragoons, who preented 'em together with a Billet Doux from his Mater to Donna Olympia; which he having Kis'd a Thouand times, the Dragoon had much a do to forbear Laughing out, at the Fantatick Actions of this amourous Lady. But he having open'd the Letter, found thee following Lines:
Madam:
OR rather my bright hining Sun: It cannot be expres'd with how much impatience I wait for that Hour, when I may give you new Proofs of my Love. I was not able to tay till Night to aure you of it, by my own Mouth: You your elf hall judge whether I don't lead the mot diconolate Life in the World; being depriv'd of your Preence. The Scarff which you have betow'd upon me, is of o great value to me, that I cannot be a Moment without looking upon it: This precious Pledge of your Love replenihes my Heart with joy, as the fore-runner of thoe Pleaures, which I am to tate at that time when you hall vouchafe to grant me that Favour, which I deire o earnetly. But alas! I dare not reflect too much upon 'em, for fear of a Relape into that Swooning Ditemper, which I have been
Subject to ever ince I firt aw you; If this hou'd happen to befal me in your Abence, I hou'd be in great danger of Death, for want of your preence, you being the only Peron in the World, that is able to recover my fainting Spirits. Adieu my incomparable Creature; let me beg of you not to be foregetful of him, who is the mot Paionate Lover in the World. I have ent you by one of my Dragoons ome Jewels, the bet I cou'd meet with; Expecting in the mean time your Commands. Let not that Demi-Devel, who haunts you at home, put you out of Order. If the violence of my Paion will let me Live till ten a Clock at Night, I will not fail to run to your Embraces, and to renew my former Protetations, that I am without reerve,
Madam, Entirely Yours, &c.

The Lady was at firt reolv'd to have ent an Anwer to the Marhal's Letter, but conidering with her elf, that Secrets of this nature ought not to be committed to the dicretion of a private Centinel; he forbore for that time. Not long after, Night beginning to approach, the Marhal did not fail to meet his Beloved at the appointed Hour. He had dres'd himelf that Day as
fine as cou'd be, and the better to pleae his Spanih Mitres, he wore that ame Scarff, which he had receiv'd as a preent from her. The Lady, on the other Hand, had trove to out do him in the Richnes of her Apparel. Her Suit was all made of Cloath of Silver, trimm'd with a vat quantity of Green Ribands, and a very rich Gold-Galloon all after the French Mode. Upon her Head he wore green Feathers, which made a great Addition to her Face, which was extremely Beautiful. The Treses of her fair Hair, which hung down to her bare Neck, whiter than Snow; appear'd the mot charming in the World.

The Marhal at the ight of her, was o overcome by his Paion, that he was not able to utter one Word; and he eeing him o ilent at a time when he leat expected it, cou'd not forbear asking him the Reaon of it; Monieur Boufflers, anwer'd with a heavy Sigh, Madam, Your Charms are the caue of my ilence, they having taken from me the ue both of my Tongue and my Reaon. I am not the ame Man I was, when I firt aw you. Here the Marchiones interrupting, and embracing him; For God's ake, aid he, My Lord, awake out of this lumber; I love you more than my own Life, and if you don't anwer my Paion, I aure you that I hall not live any longer than your elf: o that if your Words be true, we hall be the Occaion of one anothers
Death. Oh! my mot adorable Deity, reply'd the Marhal, fixing his lips upon her's, let us dye for one Moment both together. For God's ake, Sir, anwer'd he very charmingly, don't put things o far, I am but too much afraid of that Death you peak of, which often proves the pring of whole Rivulets of Tears. What fear is it replyed the Marhal, all upon a udden, that has eis'd you, don't you look upon me as a Man of Honour? I aure you that I wou'd rather dye a thouand times if it were poible, than be in the leat guilty of any Crime towards my ador'd Mitres. Oh Heavens! cry'd he, can you ask, Sir What I fear? I fear your fickle Humour, your incontancy, which I believe to be an Hereditary Evil, incident to Gentlemen of your Nation, who think it a Crime to love any Woman long; Unfaithfulnes and Incontancy being their chief Delight. And Madam, reply'd the Marhal briskly certainly you peak by your own experience, that you can talk with o much aurance concerning their Incontancy; No Sir, anwer'd Donna Olympia, as briskly as he; I never was o unfortunate as to fall under their clutches till now you being the firt, who has made me enible of Love. The Marhal perceiving with what Reolution this Lady held out againt all his Attacks, and being reolv'd to
bring the matter to a concluion, told her with a great deal of eeming indifferency Madam I wou'd advie you to break off with me, whilt occaion erves; to tell the Truth, the French are great Deemblers, and epecially the Officers, who eldom make a farther account than for one Day, leaving all the ret to Chance and Fortune: Nevertheles I hope you'll not deny but that the Spaniards are not behind hand with the French, as to the Point of Incontancy in Love. And to peak incerely, that Variety which is o delightful in Love, is agreeable to all Men without exception. As to my part, I will not be o Preumptuous as to be anwerable for my own Heart, 'tis your part to preerve it by the Force of your Charms. If by Chance, Time (which unties the hardet Knots, and breaks the tronget Chains) hou'd make me hake off your Fetters; impute it to your own want of Strength and Deerts, which were not ufficient to keep me long under your Obedience; This indeed is a Suppoition, which perhaps will never come to pas, and you may well tell me, that I am not very Complaiant at this time; but to confes the Truth, I will rather chue to hewles Complaiance, and more Sincerity, than to be accounted a Diembler and a Perfidious Wretch: Thee being the Titles
which your Sex uually betow upon us, when for want of their own merit, they are no longer able to keep their Lovers under Subjection.

'Tis impoible to find words uitable to the Surprie, which this Harangue of the Marhal caus'd in Donna Olympia; he took it o hainouly, that immediately without peaking one Word, he flew out of the Chamber into another. The Marhal eeing himelf thus left alone, was jut ready to leave the Chamber, when epying the Picture of his lovely Spaniard lying upon the Table, he cou'd not forbear to take it up, and to put it in his Pocket. He was no ooner return|'d to his own Lodgings, and having order'd Candles to be brought up, but he began to look very earnetly upon the Picture; which was the finet drawn that ever was een, the Marchiones being painted in the Habit and Poture of Diana, with a Quiver hanging over her Shoulders, and a Bow in her Hand. The Marhal finding this Picture o lovely, What new Charm, do I dicover, aid he to himelf, now I begin to repent of thoe Words, which the refual of her lat Favour made me utter. He reproach'd himelf thus for a long time; and o tormented himelf both that Night and the next Day, that his grief eem'd to be pas't Remedy. At lat after a Thouand Reflections, which ditracted his
Mind, he reolv'd to go and renew his Viits to the Marchiones, at the accutom'd time. Donna Olympia in the the mean while, who had not left the Marhal, without a great contraint, was altogether overwhelm'd with Grief and Tears. Medina her dear Confident, found her in this Poture; and he happen'd to come in, very Opportunely, for Donna Olympia was jut ready to Kill her elf with the Marhal's Sword, which he had left with the Moor, who had given it to his Lady as omewhat very precious, belonging to the Marhal de Boufflers; whereas it wou'd have prov'd fatal to this Poor Lady, if her Kinwoman had not topt her Hands, crying out to her, For God's ake what are you going about to do? Conider that you are a Chritian, and that you mut be anwerable for a Soul which you have receiv'd, from Almighty God. What is it that cou'd put you upon uch a deperate Reolution? Can the ill uage of a Lover be a Motive trong enough to incite you to Murder your elf? Oh! conider and dread God's Jutice, which never lets Crimes of this nature go unpunih'd. Donna Olympia was not able to peak one Word in anwer to Medina, but all her trength ailing her, he fell into a Swoon at the Feet of her Kinwoman. This young Lady having lifted her up, and lay'd her upon a Couch; by the help of ome trong Waters, which he held to her
Noe, brought her to her elf again. My Dearet Coin, aid he, tenderly embracing her, what was it that cou'd induce you to take this rah Reolution of Detroying your elf? Alas! my Dearet, reply'd the Marchiones, in a languihing Tone, What wou'd you have me tell you? That ungrateful Man, of whom I have poke to you, has already made me feel the effects of his Incontancy; This Perfidious Creature has abandon'd me before he has enjoy'd the weet Fruits of our Love. Oh! you only poke too true Medina, when you told me, that the French were Fickle and Capricious in Love. I am only too enible that I ought to fly from him, but I cannot; my Paion forces me to et aide all other coniderations, which wou'd banih me from his Sight. Medina was about to make Anwer, when Don Bilboano the Marchiones's Brother, having heard the out-cryes of the Women in her Chamber, when he Swoon'd away entr'd the Room with his Sword ready drawn. Donna Olympia having a quick Wit, immediately hid the Marhal's Sword under her Bed, to take away all manner of Supicion from her Brother, whom he knew to be almot mad with Jealouie. She gave him to undertand how all upon a udden he felt her elf o ill, that he Swoon'd away, but that thanks to Heaven, he was now very well recover'd. Don Bilboano told his Siter that he was overjoy'd to ee her o well, and
having Cares'd her in a more Paionate manner, than became a Brother, he left the Room. Night now began to approach, and our Lady, who was very impatient to ee her Lover again, made her Black-Moor tand Centry at the ame door, thro' which the Marhal was wont to be conducted into her Appartment; having deir'd Medina to tay with her, till uch time that he hou'd come in, whom he expected with o much Impatience. Our General did not fail to be there at the accutom'd Hour; but under the diguie of a Dragoon, for fear of being taken too much notice of, if he always appear'd as an Officer. He preented his Sword to the Moor, who refus'd to take it, not knowing him in this Diguie. The Marhal having convinc'd the Moor by putting ome Lovis's d'or into his Hand, that it was himelf; he by that means av'd his Life, which he had ele put in jeopardy for his Mitres's ake. Having enter'd his Mitres's Chamber, he threw himelf immediately at her Feet, begging of her to pardon all what he had told her, proteting that he was very enible of his Fault, and that if he thought fit, he wou'd expiate it, by making himelf a Sacrifice at her Feet: He expres'd thee words to naturally, and with an Air o engaging, that the Marchiones's anger was wholly appeas'd; he reproachi'd him with his Incontancy and want of Love; She
call'd him Capricious fickle and Incontant Frenchman; and added many other Taunts, which he imagin'd might affect him mot enibly. The Marhal bore every thing, not with the patience of a Dragoon (for this is a quality not peculiar to 'em;) but like Job, for he did not o much as utter one word in anwer to her Reproaches; On the contrary, to make ome amends for his Fault, he did nothing but kis, ometimes her Hand, and ometimes the Hemm of her Garment; he being that day Dres'd all in Black; it being the Cutom in Spain, if a Lady looes her Gallant, or believes he has lot him, to dres herelf in Mourning Cloaths: 'Twas for this ame reaon that Donna Olympia had put her elf in Mourning, imagining that he hou'd never ee the Marhal again; who was as yet reolv'd not to quit her o, before he was come a little nearer to the Point. Conformably to this Reolution, he pres'd her very hard, not to let him uffer any longer, adding, that the Pains which he made him endure, were beyond Expreion, nay, that they cou'd not be imagin'd by any Peron but one who lov'd o Paionately as himelf. Donna Olympia eeing what pains the Marhal took to repreent to her, his Love, cou'd not forbear laughing at it, when the Marhal with a Smile told her, Madam, indeed you are very Cruel, thus to divert your
elf at the expence of your unfortunate Lovers, whom you make to languih at your Feet, without hewing the leat Compaion to 'em; when you go to Confeion I hope you'll not forget to tell your Father Confeor among other Sins, how you make it your diverion to caue Mankind to dye a languihing Death, and how many Murders have been committed by thoe fair Eyes. I don't know Sir, reply'd the Marchiones, laughing outright, I never took any account of their number. But continu'd he, looking upon the Marhal, who feign'd himelf Ill, Pray tell me whether you are Sick in good earnet; Pray let me feel your Pule, truly it beats very quick. Alas! my dearet Creature, reply'd the Marhal de Boufflers, embracing her how hou'd it be poible to be o near o lovely and charming an Object as you are, without the greatet emotion of all my Vital Spirits; certainly if you don't oon take pity of me, I cannot live much longer, Oh Heavens! reply'd the Lady, keeping him at a little ditance; how you put me into a fright, in this habit of a Dragoon. How cou'd it enter your Thoughts, thus to diguie your elf, that I am not able to endure the ight of it. Madam anwer'd the Marques, you know the Reaon why I did it, 'twas becaue I hall not be o much
oberv'd, as if I hou'd appear every day in the ame Equipage. Beides this diguie may prove very convenient upon another account; for I wou'd not for all the World that our Generals hou'd get the leat notice of our amourous Intreague. I am the greatet admirer of ecreie that can be, but epecially in Love-concerns, where evenmatters of the leat moment ought to be kept ecret. Here the fair Spaniard interrupting him, then pray Sir, aid he, give me leave to dres you in Womens Apparel; thus we hall have the conveniency of enjoying one another with more freedom. O Lord! Madam, reply'd he, don't contrive a thing which cannot but be very much to my diadvantage; I am o hard favour'd that in a Womans Head-dres I hall be only fit to frighten Children. Let me for this time pas as I am, and I promie you that I will return to morrow in another Equipage, which hall have nothing terrible in it. In the mean while let us not looe the enjoyment of a happy Minute. To Morrow, to Morrow cry'd he, Mr. Dragoon. Oh! Madam, reply'd the Marhal, it is not without great violence, that I can deferr it till then. The Heat and vigour of Love lackens by delays; the Cannon is ready mounted, let us make a breach in the Walls, and enter
with our Swords drawn. Sir, reply'd the Lady, the Duke de Navaille at the head of the French King's Army, cou'd have aid no more. If terms of War are the ame with thoe of Love, I don't as yet undertand the Language, therefore I hope you'll give me ome time to learn 'em.

It was not without very weighty Reaons that the Marhal was o eager, to come to the Concluion of the whole Story; for he had but a little time to tay at Puicerda, having receiv'd Orders to March towards the Rhine Where: The Counts of Schomberg and Choieul, and the Marhal de Crequi; threatn'd to Beiege Rheinsfeld, a Place Situated in a Plain. Thee coniderations caus'd no mall commotions in his Mind: Which was divided between the glory of Arms and the delights of Love. But at the preent, being oblig'd by his Mitreses command, to retire, he did it with o much indifferency, that he not o much as afforded her one parting Kis, which he earnetly wih'd for, as I have undertood ince. Being return'd to his Lodgings, he took a Reolution not to viit her in two or three days, in hopes that by this device he hou'd bring her over the ooner, to grant his Requet. During the time of his abence, he employ'd all his Wits in finding out omething or another, which might oblige her to cry for fair Quarter;
and at lat he obtain'd his aim, as will appear from the equel of the Hitory.

Having conider'd with himelf that all the Spanih Lady's are extremely taken with the vanity of rich Cloaths, tho' they themelves are not very extravagant that way. He order'd a Suit to be made, the richet that cou'd be contriv'd; it was trimm'd with Amarant and Gold Colour'd Ribbands (this being the favourite Colour of his Mitres) his Wate-coat was of the ame Colour, finely embroider'd by a certain Moores, who was very famous for that ort of Work in thoe Parts. He wore a green Feather in his Hat; his Legs being extraordinarily well hap'd, he put on that day a pair of black Silk Stockings, and a pair of very mall neat Shoe's, lin'd with Crimon-Velvet, which was at that time the Mode at Puicerda. Whilt he was dreing himelf, he aid to his Valet du Chambre, whoe Name was Champonniere, and who knew the whole Intrigue, See what a Man is fain to do for a Mitres, wou'dt thou doe the ame for thine? O Yes, reply'd he, If I thought he deerv'd it. Thou art in the right on't, aid Monieur de Boufflers, he that will pleae the Women mut take care to appear in a very fine Equipage. When he was dres'd, he thought it an Age ere the appointed Hour was come, which was ten a Clock at Night. He walk'd hatily up and
down his Chamber, being in a continual Study concerning his amourous Adventure. At lat the wih'd for Hour drew near, when with all the peed imaginable he hatn'd to his Mitres.

Medina by order from Donna Olympia conducted him into a certain Appartment, where he had never been before. This Room being adorn'd with very rich Tapetry, great Crytallin Looking Glaes, and good tore of Wax-tapers; o that any Perons might view themelves all over from Head to Foot. The Marhal being for ome time entertain'd by Medina, whom he did not know, tho' he had een her before at Paris; look'd upon the Tapetry-work with a very dicerning Eye, asking her everal times the meaning of divers Figures which he aw, and particularly, concerning that of a certain Princes, repreented there with a naked Sword which he was about to deliver to her Lover, for him to Sheath it in her Breat What extravagancy is this, cry'd the Marhal, Cou'd any thing be o barbarous, as to run a Sword into the Breat, of o lovely a Woman? Oh! Sir, reply'd the young Lady, If you were acquainted with the whole Adventure, it wou'd not eem o trange to you. This unfaithful Lady having at everal times prov'd Treacherous in her Love; and being one day all overcome with hame and Confuion, when he reproach'd her with
her perfidiounes, at lat natch'd his Sword from his ide, which he preented to him, begging of him to heath it in her Breat, to expiate her former incontancy. But the Prince who deteted o Villainous an Act, wou'd by no means comply with her demands. This is omewhat urpriing to me Madam, reply'd the Marhal, I cou'd carce have believ'd that a Woman cou'd be o Treacherous to her Lover. He wou'd have continu'd his Dicoure, if he had not been interrupted by the coming in of Donna Olympia, who appear'd to him as fair as an Angel. She had dres'd her elf, that day o advantageouly, that he quite amaz'd the Marhal by her charms; he for ome time not being able to doe any thing but to gaze upon her. Certain Trees of Hair which hung down to her Neck, were no mall addition to her charming Beauty. Her Gown and Petty-coat were of an Amarant and blew Colour, and her Girdle all cover'd with Diamonds of great value. Monieur de Boufflers being at that intant more inflam'd than ever, told her very tenderly that at this moment he had quite ubdu'd his Heart; and that he appear'd to him o charming, that he cou'd not look upon her otherwie than his adorable Deity. Sir, reply'd he; you are pleas'd to make port with me, 'tis you that appear more bright than a Star, and more charming than ever Adonis was. You have this day taken particular
care to et your elf off to the bet advantage; 'tis poible you have ome great deign in hand. Yes Madam, reply'd the Marhal, kising her Snow white Hand, my deign is to pleae you, and effectually to make you enible of my Paion, all naked as it is. Oh! no Sir, aid the Lady, 'tis poible you may frighten me, you had better cover it with omewhat or another. Medina who was unwilling to diturb thee two Lovers, retir'd out of repect to her Kinwoman. The Marhal being now left in Company only with his Mitres, did o lively repreent the vehemency of his Paion, in Terms o affectionate and obliging, confirm'd by a thouand Oaths and Imprecations, that he wou'd Love her as long as he liv'd; that at lat the fair Spaniard was vanquih'd, and having ask'd him with a very tender and Paionate Air; Will you never ceae to Love me? Will you never forake me? She urrender'd the Place which had held out o long againt the Marhal's mot vigourous Attacks. The Marhal had no ooner taken poeion of this trong Hold, but he repented of the Bargain; having found her nothing near o amiable as he had imagin'd before.

The Spanih Lady's are generally Subject to a great Infirmity; for as oon as they have pas'd the Age of Eighteen or Twenty Years, they are eiz'd with a continual Flux, which is not fit to be touch'd nor o much as nam'd,
and the wort is, that no Remedy can be found againt it: This was more than ufficient to put our General out of conceit with his Mitres; he being the Nicet Man in the World, as to Women. Indeed he was o dimay'd at this Bloody Encounter, that he cou'd carce conceal his dipleaure. The Lady was for having him renew the amourous Engagement, but he excus'd himelf as well as he cou'd, telling her that on a udden he was eis'd with a mot violent Head-Ach: The Lady was therefore oblig'd to expect the econd Rencounter the next time; which is as yet to come, for he never came near her ince that Day. He was nevertheles o generous, as to make her a Preent of ome Jewels, which he had brought along with him for that purpoe, as a reward of that Favour, which he had receiv'd from this fair Spaniard. Donna Olympia with a profound reverence Kis'd her own Hands; which according to the Cutom of that Country, is as much as to ay, I accept the Preent: Nay he appear'd extremely well atisfi'd at firt with it, looking upon it as a Pledge of her Lover's Paion; but he was mot groly mitaken in her aim, for the Marhal's Pasion was grown o cool by this time, that he wih'd himelf at a great ditance from the Place where he was. Donna Olympia in the mean while began to be more and more
enible of the indifferency of her Lover, which made her break out into thee Words: Did not I tell you before, Sir, that as oon as you had obtain'd what you o Paionately wih'd for, you wou'd not continue to Love me with the ame Ardour as before; all Men uually looe a great part of their eager Deires, as oon as they have tated the puret and mot delicious Pleaures of Love. Oh! how much are you chang'd already, what is become of that Paion, which the Univere was not able to contain? What is become of all your mot incere Protetaions; what of all your Paionate Expreions? The Marhal, who began to be afraid that the Lady might play him ome curvy trick or another, or perhaps caue him to be Poiniarded, before he cou'd get out of the Houe, was fain to et on the bet countenance he cou'd; and to Cares her with a thouand fair Promies, of which he did not intend to keep the leat. By this Artifice he at lat got clear of his Mitres, having firt made a olemn Promie to viit her as often as he hou'd think convenient. Promies, made in the Air, without the leat Propect of accomplihment, except he had lik'd the Game better than he did; but what wou'd not a Man ay to a Woman, when he has lot her charms, and is become Burdenome? The Marhal being return'd to his Lodgings, had now all his Thoughts employ'd how to
Decamp with privacy from Puicerda, which he now began to naueate as much as he hadadmir'd it before. Have not I done very finely, ai'd he to himelf, to have pent o much time i'dly in an Amourous Adventure, which was not worth the pains I took in looking after it? Madam Olympia, 'twas not in your power to retain me long in your Service; I was very much mitaken in your Charms. You are not engaging enough for a Man of my Humour, who hates to Swim in‚ÄîBut away with it, let us not think of it any more, for I begin to be Heart-ick. Then calling his Valet du Chambre, Champonniere, aid he, hadt thou ever a Spanih Mitres? Pray tell me your Adventures. The Marhal's Gentleman finding his Mater in a Humour to divert himelf with him, ome part of the Night, burt out into laughter; having oon perceiv'd, how he had been treated by this Spanih Lady. How now, Rascal! aid the General, is this your way, to laugh at me as fat as you can? Oh! Sir, reply'd the Servant laughing as heartily as he did before; You have order'd me to make a recital of my amourous Adventures, and when I reflect upon ome paages of 'em, 'tis impoible for me to forbear laughing. If thy Mitres were a Spaniard, aid Monieur de Boufflers, without quetion he gave thee great atisfaction. Yes Sir, anwer'd his Genteleman, I have had a touch with mot Nations How, aid the Marhal; then
thou hat dipt thy Sword in that Current of the Spanih Women. What dot thou think of thee running Rivulets? Truly Sir, aid he, I don't know what to ay of 'em, but that they are not very Savoury. Thou art in the right on't, reply'd the General, Let us have no more of 'em, or ele I hall Spew my Heart out. Go bring me up ome Wine, to recruit my Spirits, or ele I hall Swoon in good Earnet. The Gentleman thought that his Mater had only been in jet, but he was extremely urpris'd when he aw him intantly fall from his Chair upon the Ground. Being in a great Conternation, he call'd up the Land-lady, who having wah'd his Face very well with fair Water, oon brought him to himelf again, and having caus'd him to be laid in his Bed he reted pretty well for the remainder of the Night.

Some days after, Monieur Boufflers quitted Catalonia, and march'd with the French Army towards the Rhine, where he ignalis'd himelf in everal advantageous Rencounters with the Imperialits. The two Marhals de Crequi and de Navaille puru'd their Victories againt the Imperial Forces, having defeated a coniderable Party of their Dragoons; and the Marhal de Boufflers gave great Proofs of his Valour in this Engagement, which was follow'd by the urrender of the Catle of Dortamburg and that of Fort Kell. Amidt thee Martial Exploits, the Marhal de
Boufflers did not lay aide his tender inclinations for the fair Sex, being as oon as he was a little at leaure, as indefatigable in his amourous Engagements, as he had been before in his Warlike Enterprizes; as it will appear in the equel of our Story: But before we proceed, let us return to the unfortunate Donna Olympia, who being quite ras'd out of his Memory, hew'd all the marks of a depairing Peron, in tearing off her Hair, and committing all orts of Extravagancies, without uffering any one o much as to Speak to her of Conolation. Medina endeavour'd to perwade her, that it was the common chance of Women in Love to be forgot and Slighted by their Gallants. But all in vain; for he continually Exclaim'd againt her ill Fortune, calling him at the ame Moment ungrateful and perjur'd Wretch. Where art thou now, aid he, with all thy Oaths and deceitful Promies? Oh good Heavens! can you uffer that uch a Monter as this, hou'd walk upon the Face of the Earth after having violated all that is Sacred to me? What ill Fate did over rule my Inclinations, when I granted him that, which ought to have been more dear to me than my own Life. This incontant, Perfidious Wretch triumphs over my Honour. Ah! I am reolv'd to Travel all over the World in quet of him, on purpoe to reproach him with his infidelity, and if he refue to hearken to
my jut Complaints, I will, aid he, (taking up a Dagger which lay upon the Table) Stabb him to the Heart. Yes, aid he, I don't doubt but this Arm of mine hall have trength enough to dipatch this faithles Wretch, who ought not to live any longer, ince he has deceiv'd me. She had no ooner poke thee Words, and being altogether animated with Revenge, but he begg'd of Medina to be her Companion in this Enterprie, aying that they wou'd both diguie themelves in Mens Habit, and find out the Marhal in whatever part of the World he might be. But her Kinwoman, who was more prudent in weighing the matter, utterly rejected her Propoal, as being o little agreeable to their Sex, repreenting to her all the dangers, which mut be the neceary Conequences of uch an attempt, to Women of their Quality.

p.U:
aid he, very wittily act the Heroine Muqueteer, will you be ambitious to imitate your Romantick Heroes, what gainer will you be by all this? But to make your elf a Laughing Stock to the World. Let your ungrateful Lover enjoy his own Peace, 'tis poible his Concience does already ufficiently accue him of his Treachery. Your French Gentlemen, as I have often told you, eldom do otherwie than he has done; and I pitty thoe poor Women who are o unfortunate as to believe 'em. Endeavour therefore to compoe your Mind; that is the only
way left you to be even with him, for I don't quetion that but he is vain enough to believe that you are extremely concern'd at his Abence: But if I were in your cae, he hou'd never boat of that atisfaction. Oh! my Dearet, reply'd Donna Olympia all in Tears, he has now very little regard to me; yet he has gain'd what he aim'd at, and 'tis that which almot put's me into Depair. I hall never ee again that Conquerour, who has triumph'd over my weaknes in pite of all the Reitance I was able to make; I was too too oon overcome by his flattering Promies. Good Heavens! you that know my digrace, Revenge me upon this perfidious Man. Madam, reply'd Medina, if I hou'd tell you, that thee things ought to have been conider'd before you entertain'd the Marhal o far, I hall perhaps looe ome part of the advantage of comforting you, wherefore I think the bet Office I can do you at this time, is to deire you to take comfort, to forget what is pas'd, and to be more Circumpect for the future. Donna Olympia o well approv'd the Advice given her by her Kinwoman, that ome time after, as we have been ince inform'd, he threw her elf into a Nunnery of the Female Converts, where he pends the remainder of her Life-time in doing of Penance; eating of nothing but wild Roots, and Drinking nothing but fair Water, in Atonement of her former enual Pleaures: And Medina follow'd her Example, to mortifie herelf, for
ome former Love-Intreagues in France and Spain. Thus we are come to the concluion of the Hitory of our two Spanih Lady's.

div.p:
'Tis now time to return to our Marhal, who has not been Idle in Germany; having already found out a new Mitres, whoe Charms have render'd him her Captive. Here you mut not imagine that 'twas a native of that Country, who was o dexterous in engaging his Heart: no, they are very rarely o ingenious at Love-Intreagues in thoe Parts, being omewhat unacquainted with uch languihing deires, which are the contant attendants of Lovers. The Beauty which Captivated him, was a certain Englih Gentlewoman, whom chance had brought to the ame Inn where he Lodg'd. This Lady whom we will call my Lady Stone, was the Wife of a certain Irih Gentleman, who being accus'd of High-Treaon, was forc'd to quit England, and finding no redres in his Affairs, had ought for a Sanctuary in Germany, as his Wife was inform'd; who had undertaken this Journey, in hopes to find him out there; but not having got any farther Information concerning him, notwithtanding her utmot endeavours, was extremely uneaie in the Inn where he Lodg'd, for fear that he hou'd not be able to learn any news relating to her ungrateful Husband, who had
left her without giving her the leat notice, ince his departure, of the place of his Abode. The Marhal, who was inform'd before hand of her Circumtances, hew'd her all the repect due to a Lady of her Quality and Merits, who labour'd under great afflictions. It will not be a-mis here to give you a Character of this Englih Lady. She was mot delicately hap'd, very courteous and affable in all her Behaviour. Her Hair was Black, her Complexion very fair, and her Skin very mooth; her Eyes very bright and parkling; he had the prettiet Mouth in the World, and he laugh'd mot charmingly: As for her Teeth, they were none of the bet; this being a general defect among the Lady's of this Country, who commonly poil 'em with eating Sweet-meats too plentifully. She had beides thisa, certain Majetick Air, which was urpriing at firt ight, tho' he was extremely Obliging and Courteous in Converation. Her Neck and Hands were very fair and plump, and to comprehend all in a few words, he appear'd o adoreable to our Marhal, that he became trongly enamour'd with her Beauty. The firt Proof he gave her of his Love, was one Morning, when he found her all in depair in her Chamber; he had torn her Hair, and was jut ready to make a way with her elf. If in any other Country
but England a Woman hou'd commit thee extravagancies, he wou'd be thought only fit for a Mad-Houe. But it is to be conider'd that in no other place in the World thee violent attempts are o frequently put in Execution as there. I don't know what hard entiments they have concerning themelves, but this is certain, that for a mall diappointment, 'tis often known that they Hang, Poyon, or Pitol themelves without any ene of thir crime. Our General being touch'd as much with compaion as with Love, threw himelf ather Feet, entreating her to tell him the truecaueof that affliction, which had inpir'd her with o deperate a Reolution, the mark's of which plainly appear'd in her Countenance.
