The Englih Lady being omewhat of a haughty temper, cou'd at firt carce reolve to dicover the Circumtances of her Affairs to Monieur de Bouffflers, looking upon it as a thing very unbecoming herelf, and as omewhat which cou'd not but mot enibly affect her Honour: Nevertheles, conidering with her elf in what a generous and obliging manner he was treated by the Marhal, he at lat determin'd to make an ingenuous Confeion in thee Words: Is it poible, Sir, that my ill Fortune hou'd drive me to this point of Extremity, in which you ee me at preent: My Huband, who carce deerves that name, having
left me without Mony, and without any propect of receiving aitance from any Peron? I have been for ome time in this Inn, with my Valet du Chambre, and my waiting Woman; and beides other Necearies requiite for a Peron of my Quality; I have not wherewithal to atisfy my Hot, whom I cannot expect to entertain me Gratis, I am quite beyond all Patience, to ee my elf reduc'd to this extremity, by the neglect of an ill Husband, who‚ÄîShe cou'd not proceed, the Tears which trickl'd down her Beautiful Cheeks, having quite topt her Speech. The Marhal was o touch'd with compaion, that immediately he offer'd her his Pure, deiring her to make ue of it, as if it were her own; and to hew her that his Words were not bare Compliments, as 'tis the common Cutom of a great many, but that his Offers were real, he went immediately down to the Hot, whom he ask'd how much that Englih Lady who with her Servants Lodg'd in his Houe, was indebted to him. The Inn-holder having brought him her Bill, he immediately pay'd him what he demanded; telling him, that he had receiv'd Orders from her Husband Mr. Stone, to pay him his Mony, and to engage his Word for what ever he hou'd have occaion for in his Houe, for the future. In a few Moments after, Monieur de Boufflers ent to his new Mitres a Pure full of Lovis's d'or, Embroider'd
with fine Pearls on both ides, and trimm'd with Ribonds of all orts of Colours, to upply her elf with uch little Necearies as he might have occaion for at that time. The Marhal dicovering in this fair Lady every day new charms, was extremely glad of this Opportunity, hoping that his Liberality wou'd be repaid him in another Coin, that is to ay, by his Mitrees Favours. Is it posible, aid he to himelf, that any Husband can be o unworthy, thus to abandon a Peron of her merit, and who is o Charming and Amiable in outward appearance? Truly I don't know what may be in the bottom of this matter, which perhaps is pat my finding out; if he hou'd perhaps, continu'd he with a Smile, have ome reemblance to my Spanih Mitres, what a diappointment wou'd that be? but let it be as it will, I don't repent of having given her ome asitance, at a time when he was jut at the point of Depair; I have at leat done a work of Charity, if her Charms hou'd not prove anwerable to my expectation. If Monieur de Boufflers was thus employ'd in reaoning with himelf, my Lady Stone did make no les Reflections upon the Liberality, which he had receiv'd from an Officer, whom he did not know, before he had een him in the ame Place where he Lodg'd. Oh! cry'd he, being all alone in her Chamber. I inenibly engage my elf to I know not whom: Perhaps this Stranger
will carce be contented with a bare Acknowledgement; he appears to me o Paionate, that I have all the reaon to believe he aims at no les than my Heart. Without this propect, which is natural to all Men; what cou'd have induc'd him to hew his Generoity to me? Oh cruel Husband, cry'd this Lady ighing; If I part with omething which only belongs to you alone, remember that you your elf are the caue of it: For when I reflect upon your Behaviour towards me, I find a trong Inclination in me to grant it. I beeech thee good God, to give me Vertue and Strength enough to reit o powerful a Temptation. I foreee by ome ecret Intinct, that I hall not be able to come off a Conquerour in this Engagement. My Lady Stone was thus Tormenting her elf, when the Marhal came into the ame Room, where he was, and after having pay'd his repects and Saluted her, he et himelf down by her; What is it Madam aid he, that occaions all thee troubles: Why do you trive to render your elf unfortunate in Reflecting too much upon your preent Condition? Don't let the Spring-eaon of your Life pas away without Pleaure, o charming a Peron as you ought to be made enible of the atisfaction, which attends the full enjoyment of the happy Minute. If you have the leat inclination to Love, I know a certain Gentleman o violently charm'd with your engaging Air, that he declares he loves you more than his own
Life. And how come you to know this, anwer'd the Lady, in a Melancholy Tone, are you the Guardian of this Gentleman's Heart? Yes Madam, reply'd the Marhal with a very Paionate look, I know him as well as my own elf, and I will be anwerable for his Paion and Contancy, and that he hall protet to you that he will Love you as long as he lives. You urprie me Sir, reply'd the fair Lady, pray tell me who is this Gentleman, that has uch advantageous Thoughts of me, do I not know him? Madam, reply'd the Marhal, cating on her a very amourous look; He is not unknown to you, 'tis the ame whom you ee before you.

This Declaration of the Marhal's, having put our Englih Lady to the bluh, he continu'd to make to her all the mot incere Protetations of a violent Paion, according to the Cutom of mot Men, at the firt rie of their Love. The Marhal was o extremely delighted with his growing Paion, that he proteted with a Thouand Oaths at the Feet of his Mitres, that he Paionately lov'd her; that he ador'd her; that he was Inchanted by her powerfull Charms, and a Thouand uch like extravagant Expreions. Is it poible, reply'd my Lady Stone coldly, that you hou'd Love me o much as you pretend you do? May one rely upon your Words? Commonly Perons of your
Character are in Love with mot Women, more out of a Principle of Civility than Love. But, continu'd he, what is it that I ay, I cannot but be perwaded that you have ome kindnes for me, ince you have dealt o generouly with me; I will take it then for granted, it will erve at leat to pleae my Fancy; What advantage cou'd you purpoe to your elf in deceiving an unfortunate and afflicted Peron, who deires nothing but Compaion. Oh Madam! reply'd the Marhal, queezing her fair Hands between his own. 'Tis I that rather tand in need of Compaion; my Love encreaes every Moment, and if you don't find out a Remedy to appeae my pain, I am infallibly undone. Sir, reply'd the Lady Smiling, I have a certain Chamber-Maid belonging to me, who has a Soveraign Antidote againt Love; I'll engage as oon as you do but look upon her you'll be cur'd of your Ditemper. O Madam! cry'd the Marhal being impatient to ee her, pray let her come, that he may apply omewhat to awage my Pain. The Plaiter which he ues reply'd the Englih Lady, facetiouly, is very large, it will cover your whole Body. This is a Plaiter for the Devil, aid he, but pray let us ee it, he had no ooner poke thee Words, but the Lady call'd Betty, which was the name of her Chamber-Maid, who was o ugly that he was only fit to make a Bugg-bear to frighten Children withal.
Her Mouth was o big that it reach'd from one Ear to the other; her Noe was very mall; her Fore-head very low and flat; her Eyes vatly large; her Hair and the grain of her Skin very coure, if you touch'd her he felt like a Nutmeg grater; beides that he was as Black as a Tawny-moor, and her hape was all awry: But notwithtanding all this, he had a mot admirable Head-piece, having a ready and well refin'd Wit, and was mot excellent at Repartees. When one heard her talk, he made an ample amends for the Deformity of her Body and Face; and 'twas by this means that he ininuated herelf into the favour of her Mitres, who had a particular kindnes for her. The Marhal, at firt ight of her, went two or three teps backwards, on purpoe to hew his urprie. This young Woman, who as we have already intimated, had a very ready Wit, and was well acquainted with this ort of Divertiements, was not at all balk'd at it, but on the contrary, told the Marhal very briskly; that this was a certain Proof of her Merit, becaue he had been powerful enough to caue o udden an Emotion in a Peron o brave and Galiant as the Marhal. 'Tis very true Mitres, reply'd Monieur de Boufflers, pray come nearer to me, and make me enible of your Remedy againt Love, which your Lady has told me, that you always carry about you. Alas!
reply'd Betty with a Smile, Sir my charms are not powerful enough to cure you of your Love, I want that advantage, except in eeing me o ill hap'd and o ugly, you might take a general antipathy againt Women: They are not all of 'em o ugly nor o ill hap'd, reply'd her Mitres, as thou art Betty, wherefore I don't believe that the Marhal is reolv'd as yet to renounce his Paion for the fair Sex. I conjecture I know a certain Peron in the World, whom he does not altogether look upon with an indifferent Eye. And o do I, reply'd Betty laughing: For that I know it may be your own elf, it being very likely that the Marhal is not inenible of your Charms. You jeer me, reply'd Madam Stone pleaantly; what do you ay to the cajoleing Language of my Maid, aid he to the Marhal, I ay Madam, reply'd he, that he is abolutely in the right on't, and that he has poke nothing but what is due to o adorable and o amiable a Peron as your elf. Alas! I am only too well convinc'd of the truth of it, my Heart having been Wounded by your irreitible Charms. O Sir, reply'd Madam Stone carelely, why then don't you wear it in a Scarff? I am afraid this poor Heart of yours is o mangl'd ever ince you firt aw me, that it will not hold long together. How can it be otherwie, Madam, anwer'd Betty, who was very mart upon the Marhal, o that he was extremely taken with her Converation.

They were about to continue their dicoure, when Dame Helenemberg the Mitres of the Houe came in to tell her Guets that in the Evening there wou'd be a Ball at the Houe of the Bailiff of the Town. The Marhal knew o well how to perwade my Lady Stone to go thither with him, that he eaily granted his Requet, according to the Inclinations of the Englih Women, who are naturally addicted to Pleaure. This German Ball was compos'd of the chief Magitrates of the Place, who after they had Eat and Drunk very plentifully, and their Muick, (which was rather confus'd Noie, than any thing relating to Harmony) having begun to Play, they danc'd according to their own Country-Fahion, with their Wives and Daughters. The Marhal being omewhat concern'd, immediately departed, and at his return brought along with him ome Haut-bois and Pipers belonging to the French Regiments thereabouts, who play'd very weetly, and conducted him and his Mitres to the Ball, where they danc'd with o admirable an Air, that the whole Company tood amaz'd at the graceful performance of thee two unknown Perons. Dame Helenemberg, who had queez'd her elf up in ome corner, for fear of being known, did rub her Hands for joy, being not a little Proud, that he had
the good Fortune to entertain uch Guets in her Houe. At lat the Ball being ended the Turn-Spits, as I uppoe, all on a udden made uch a clattering noie amidt the Kettles and Frying-Pans, and with the Fire Shovels, Tongs and other Kitchen-Intruments, that the Marhal and his Lady being frighted at it, got away as fat as they cou'd to their own Lodgings. It was about four a Clock in the Morning, when they return'd from the Ball; and our Lovers beginning now by degrees to be more and more enible of the Pleaures of their growing Love, reolv'd not to go to Bed that Night, but to pas it away in thoe amourous Protetations, which are uually the effects of a mot tender Paion. The Marhal, who wou'd fain in ome meaure have moderated the Vehemency of his Love, found his endeavours o weak, and his Mitres's Charms o engaging and powerful, that he was contrain'd abolutely to give way to his Paion. He thought her at that time more charming than ever, which erv'd for nothing ele but to render him more unfortunate, and to entangle him the more in a Paion, which it wou'd not be eaie for him to hake off o oon. He grew at lat Melancholy to that degree, that he avoided all manner of civil Society and Converation.

One day the Lady having reprehended
him for his ill Humour, telling him that he was trangely alter'd in his Temper, from what he had known him before: Alas! Madam, aid he, what good can you expect from the preence of a Man-hater, who thinks the World too little for him to range in? The Marhals de Crequi and de Navaille did alo everal times check him upon account of his cloudy Temper, without knowing the true caue of it, o that the Marhal de Boufflers at lat beginning to grow weary of leading uch a diconolate coure of Life, and having communicated his Thoughts to the Count de Choieul, he was oon reliev'd by his good Advice. How, aid he, my Friend, is it come to that pas with you, that you cannot make a Woman Love you, for whom you have a Paion? You may now eteem your elf a orry Fellow indeed. For my part, reply'd the Marhal, triking with his Hat upon the Table, I know not what I am my elf, yet I am ure I am not the ame I us'd to be: I durt not o much as ue for a Favour from the Lady I Love. I cannot believe but that he has bewitch'd me to be ilent, and to bear every thing with an awful Repect. Thee are the true marks, reply'd the Count, of a Man in Love: But why hou'd you complain, ince you have ask'd nothing of your Mitres, and that you have no reaon to accue her of being Inenible, Cruel or Indifferent. Go, go, take my advice, lay aide this dull way
of Courthip, and puh on your Point as cloe as you can: The Englih Ladies are not o avere to the French as you imagine. The Marhal cou'd not forbear laughing at the Count's jolly Humour, who advis'd him to make ue of his middle Point to advance his Amourous Deign, Courage, Courage my dear Friend, cry'd the Count, clapping him upon the Shoulder; 'tis a very good ign when a Love Sick Peron begins to laugh; I'll engage, that before you are a Weak older, you'll be cur'd of your Ditemper: It eems, that when we dicloe our Heart to a Friend, we hare with him one half of our troubles. This was very obervable in the Marhal, who after having freely deliver'd his Mind to the Count his Friend, found himelf half cur'd of his Pain; having therefore embrac'd and return'd him a thouand thanks for his good Counel he went to renew his Viit at my Lady Stone's, who had been very uneaie during his abence.

p.hi: What have I done to you my dear Marhal,
p.U:
aid he, that you thus fly from me as you do; it eems as if I were become your Enemy? Truly Madam, anwer'd he, looking upon her with a languihing Eye, in ome meaure you are o, having bereav'd my Heart of all its Repoe and Tranquillity; ever ince I had the firt ight of you, I am not the ame Peron I was wont to be; I have given you
ome hints of my Paion, but I am apt to believe you carce ever thought of it ince. More than you think for, Sir, reply'd he, I love you better than you can imagine. 'Twas not without ome Confuion that he poke thee Words, but imagining that he had not very well apprehended her meaning, he repeated 'em everal times very pleaantly. The Marhal, who undertands a little of mot Languages, epecially as to Love-Terms, fell into an Extay of Joy upon hearing thee charming Words, which ounded very prettily in Englih from his fair Lady's Mouth. She having everal times after repeated thee Words, I Love you, I Love you; the Marhal did no longer quetion his own happines, and having embrac'd his charming Mitres, he gave her freh aurances of the violence of his Paion, which he told her was rais'd to that height that it mut prove mortal to him, except he wou'd vouchae to prevent it. Is it poible, Divine Creature, aid he, that at that moment, when I look upon you, there hou'd be any thing wanting to accomplih my Felicity? Alas! flattering Fancies! deceitful Imaginations! I am very enible what it is that is wanting to compleat my happines, 'tis that you my incomparable Fair, wou'd Love me as well as I do you. I will Sir, I will from
the very bottom of my Heart, anwer'd he. Now I leave it to the Reader's Judgment, to imagine what effects thee Words proceeding from the Mouth of his mot ador'd Mitres, had upon the Marhal: Indeed he was quite tranported beyond himelf, he Kis'd her a thouand times, and that o cloe as if he were in a Trance. The Englih Lady giving him ome weak Repules; they erv'd only to add Fuel to his Fire, and to inflame his Paion, and not being able to contain himelf any longer; he with the conent of his Fair One, who was as hard put to it as himelf to preerve her Honour, took a walk in an adjacent Wood. When he found her elf alone, I expoe my elf to no mall danger, aid he, in entertaining a Peron who appears very dangerous to a tender Heart. Alas Heavens! I am only too enible of his lovely Accomplihments, he has omewhat o charming in him, that my Liberty is in great danger of uffering Ship-wrack. This Conquerour will in time Triumph over my Weaknes, if I don't oppoe him with all my Strength. Having made thee Reflections, which her almot dying Vertue did inpire her withal; he took her Pen, and having undertood by a certain Friend, who¬Ø was going into Swierland, that her Huband had been een in that Country, he wrote him thee following Lines:
Cruel, Ungrateful,
YOU appear o depicable to me at this time, that your neglect hall not cost me o much as one Sigh. What cou'd induce. you to leave your faithful Spoue without Remore? There need no great quetion to be made concerning the difference of our Sentiments, they are o oppoite to one another, that they are pas'd all Reconciliation on my ide. Oh! had it pleas'd Heaven, which has punih'd me for loving you too much, to let me know you as well long ago, as I do at preent: This Knowledge wou'd have av'd me many a torrent of Tears and Sighs, which I have o lavihly betow'd upon an ungrateful Man, who is not in the leat worthy of 'em: When you eriouly conider with your elf unto what danger you have expos'd a Woman of my Age, and if I may ay o my elf, who may alo pretend to ome merit, you ought to bluh for hame. My Vertue has hitherto defended it elf againt thoe Temptations which daily preent themelves before my Eyes; But alas! How difficult it is to be aur'd of an entire Victory over ones own Inclinations. How do you know but that when matters come to the utmot extremity, my trength may fail me? Make hate therefore to help me before I am utterly lot, which I hall certainly be without your Preence.
You have left me detitute of Mony and all other comforts. What wou'd you have me reolve upon in this mierable Condition? If it had not been for a certain Friend of mine, who in time may alo be Yours, I mut have perih'd unavoidably for want of neceary Subitance. I leave it to your own conideration, what acknowledgement is due to his Generoity. I cannot without ome Confuion recite to you the ill Circumtances of our Affairs: Let me hear of you, if you are till among the Living, and to be ure informe me where you are at preent, that I may come to ee you. I hall be impatient to undertand where you are, at the ame Houe, where this Friend the Bearer of this Letter has left me, and whither he will direct you. Adieu, I remain in pite of all your unkindnees
Your Faithful Spoue.

div.p:
No ooner had he dipatch'd this Letter, but he went to take the Air in an adjacent Foret, where he knew that the Marhal was gone before accompany'd only with his Gentleman. Sympathy, which o trangely guides Lovers in their Actions, had oon drawn the Marhal to the ame Place
where he had et herelf down; thus muing upon her amourous Adventure; and epying a Flock of Sheep feeding not far off, he cou'd not forbear aying, (as if he envy'd their happines) O you innocent Creatures, how happy are you! You feed here without care and Anxiety; thoe Paions which continually afflict us Rational Creatures, never diturb your Tranquillity; you follow the intincts of Nature, without either Crime or Punihment: Your deires never exceed the bounds precrib'd by Nature: Love, which never diturbs your contented Mind, follows among you its own Laws, O you Peaceable Creatures! You are more happy than we Mortals. Monieur de Boufflers, who had hid himelf behind ome Trees, over-heard all that he aid, agreeably urpriing her. Oh! Sir, cry'd he bluhing, who thought to have found you here? You are o dextrous at a Surprie when leat expected, and epecially when one is employ'd in uch matters as ought to be kept from your Knowledge. I was jut admiring the Sweetnes and Tranquillity which thee Creatures enjoy, nothing vexes 'em, nothing diturbs 'em. Alas! why was not I made like them? Madam, aid the Marhal, it lies in your own Power to enjoy the ame Tranquillity; you may make your elf happy whenever you pleae, and all uch of your Friends, upon whom you hall vouch
afe to betow your Favours. Do but Love, do but Love, continu'd he, this is the only Happines of Life. He wou'd have proceeded in his dicoure, but our Englih Lady having made igns to him, that her Gentleman, who follow'd her cloe, undertood a little French, the Marhal did not enlarge any further upon this Subject; and tho' their Conference lated omewhat longer, they where wholly employ'd in dicouring about indifferent matters. Thus as the Marhal and the Lady were walking along with a low Pace, they found themelves inenibly got very far into the Wood, when they epy'd aar off a kind of Cottage thatch'd with Straw and very neatly Built; inomuch that their Curioity inpir'd 'em with a deire to know who it hou'd be that dwelt in o olitary a Place, therefore my Lady Stone ent Mr. Game, her Gentleman to informe himelf of it: Upon his Return, he told our Lovers that this little Houe belong'd to a certain honet old Man, aged above a Hundred and Twelve Years, and that he had with him one of the mot Beautiful Creatures in the World, which he aid was his Daughter. This News eeming omewhat urpriing the Englih Lady, he enjoyn'd her Gentleman to return to the ame Place, on purpoe to ask him how old he might be when he begot this Daughter, and to make ome
other particular Enquiries concerning the whole coure of his Life. While the Gentleman was gone to execute his Mitrees Commands, he had et her elf under a Tree, where he expected his return: The Marhal having here Protrated himelf at the Feet of his Goddes, began to renew his former Protetations. Hold your Tongue you pratling Fool, aid he, giving him a gentle blow upon one Cheek; which being done with a very gallant Air, it o enibly touch'd the Marhal, that he was ready to expire for Joy. In the mean time Mr. Game being return'd drew near and told 'em, that the Country-Man refus'd to anwer his Quetions, imagining that he was come to play upon him, and that he had hut himelf up in his Hutch. Let us go Madam, aid the Marhal riing from his Seat, and make him open the Door, that we may have the Satisfaction to ee that handome Damel, whoe Beauty has urpris'd Mr. Game. What reaon is there reply'd my Lady Stone, (being jealous that this Damel might urpas her in Beauty) to diturb thee poor People in their peaceable Enjoyment? come let us go Home to our own Lodgings. The Marhal, who always hews the utmot Complaiance to Lady's, was unwilling to contradict his Mitres, tho' he had a great mind to ee this
Country-Beauty, therefore he thought it mot convenient to deferr his Curioity till a more favourable Opportunity, when he hou'd be alone. Having reconducted the Lady to her Lodgings, the remainder of the Day was pent in playing at Cards, and uch ort of Sports. Neither was Love laid aide, but had a hare in the Patime, and our Marhal wou'd have been very willing to play another Game, but he cou'd not prevail at that time.

It is carce to be imagin'd how this Englih Lady, who aw herelf reduc'd to the utmot extremity, cou'd defend her Honour with o much bravery. She endeavour'd to detain her Lover with fair Words from one Day to another, in hopes that her Husband in the mean time might come to ait her in this Critical Conjuncture: Not but that he had a very favourable Opinion of the Marhal, whom he lov'd extremely, nay, even to that degree, that he herelf depair'd of reiting his Charms much longer. For he that is once Mater of the Heart of a Lady, need not much quetion all the ret Our preent Narrative will furnih us with Examples of this nature. But let us return to our General, who notwithtanding this praeengagement, went in earch of a new Paion. He cou'd not forget what he had heard the other day
in the Wood concerning the Country-Damel, whom he had not as yet een, except it were in the Idea of his own Fancy, which appear'd to him very pleaing; therefore he aroe one Morning early with the Sun, and repair'd to the Wood, without letting any one know his Deign, teering his Coure directly towards the Cottage, where he found the old Man and his Daughter buie in making your Basket-work Umbrello's, by which they got their Lively-hood; who eem'd to be much urpris'd at the ight of him. The Marhal was no les amaz'd at them; for he proteted ome hours after, that tho' he had Travell'd over a great part of the World, he had never in all his Life-time met with any thing comparable to this Country-Beauty. He took particular notice of the exact features of her Face, her delicate hape, very proportionable to the ize of her Limbs, which were not as yet come to their full growth and perfection; he then not having attain'd to above Sixteen or Eighteen years of Age: The whole Ornament of her Body being a mall Jacket of pure white Linnen. The Marhal wou'd have enter'd into dicoure with her, but he found her o Savage and ill Humour'd, that he flew away from him directly into her Cottage. In the mean while her Father took the Liberty to
tell him in the German Tongue, that he had bet go about his buines, or ele he wou'd not long be pleas'd with his Entertainment. The Marhal eeing himelf threatn'd by a plain Country-Fellow (who by reaon of his Skill in Magical Arts, was not o ignorant as he imagin'd) depiing his threats drew his Sword at him, telling him, you old Sorcerer, I'll make you know, at leat to let me ee your fair Daughter: He did not believe that he had call'd him by his right Name, but was oon convinc'd of the Truth of it; for in an intant, he aw three or four great black Fellows, like o many Infernal Fiends fall upon him, ometimes pulling him by the Noe, which they Pinch'd oundly, ometimes by the Ears, which they tretch'd with uch a force, as if they wou'd have pull'd 'em off. This Game being over, which was nothing to what was to come, they drew him up into the Air, and with his own Sword gave him innumerable Blows; from hence they convey'd him quite to the other end of the Foret, upon a precipice urrounded with Water: The Marhal as brave as he is, was heartily afraid that thee Devils wou'd have thrown him down head-long from thence into the Pond, but it eems it was not his fate to be Drown'd. At lat, after he had been well drub'd
again, they threw his Sword at his Head and o left him. The Marhal return'd as fat as he was able to his Lodgings, where he did not peak o much as one Word of his Adventure, but he was forc'd to keep his Bed for everal Days, and Champonniere his Valet du Chambre was fain to bath his Limbs, (which were extremely batter'd) with Spirit of Wine, and Spanih Soap. My Lady Stone not being able to gues at the caue of this udden Ditemper of her Lover, was almot out of her Wits; he came every Day to his Bed-ide, to hew him her Affection, and how much concern'd he was for his Ilnes: The Marhal on the other hand, acknowledg'd her Civilities in the mot Obliging manner in the World. As oon as he was recover'd, he did not fail to give her the ame Demontrations of his Love as before, nevertheles he oon perceiv'd that the vehemency of his Paion was omewhat abated. The Beautiful Country-Damel whom he had een in the Wood, notwithtanding the ill Treatment he had receiv'd, had o enchanted him, that his Thoughts cou'd not be employ'd any where ele, My Lady Stone appear'd much diatisfy'd at his Shynes, not knowing unto what caue to attribute this indifferency. Shou'd it not perhaps be, aid he to her elf, becaue I have deny'd him
thoe Favours which he u'd for o earnetly? But how cou'd I do otherwie? Why hou'd I at once betray my Vertue and my Husband, to atisfy the Brutih inclinations of a Man, who perhaps when he has obtain'd his aim, will make me a Laughing Stock to his Companions? No, No, I'll never conent to it. Not but that my Husband, who has play'd me uch a prank o lately, deerves it very well; but I am reolv'd to ubdue my Paion, for my own atisfaction's ake, and not to looe the pleaure of Triumphing over all thoe flattering Temptations which daily lye in my way. Nevertheles I mut own, that I have vat Obligations to the Marhal, who did o generouly ait me when I was in extremity: a bare acknowledgment will be carce a ufficient Recompence for his Liberality. neither am I ignorant that all Men are guided by Interet, and that they never oblige a Woman without a Propect of Reward. Thus our beautiful Englih Lady was reaoning with her elf, when Monieur de Boufflers (who was by this time pretty well tir'd with the thoughts of his Country-Beauty) urpris'd her upon a udden: What is it Madam, aid he, that diturbs your Mind, what is it that makes you o penive? Truly Sir, reply'd the Lady not without ome diturbance, I am o, and that too upon very good Grounds: For is it not caue enough of trouble to ee my elf look'd upon by you with all the indifferency
imaginable, even at the ame time when I can hear no News from my Husband? Don't you think that all this is ufficient to overwhelm me with Grief. Alas! Sir, to my Misfortune I have plac'd you too near my Heart. She cou'd not proceed without hedding ome Tears, which very enibly affected the Marhal, who very dextrouly attributed the effects of his Dicontent and Indifferency to her Shynes; telling her that it was becaue he had et light by his Paion. Indeed, reply'd he, I might eaily Conjecture this to be the true caue of your indifferency; but can you imagine Sir, that without a great deal of trouble we can reolve to grant your Sex thoe Favours, which you aim at. I am apt to believe you ay right, Madam, anwer'd the Marhal, but if a Woman meets with one whom he knows to be a Peron of Honour and Dicretion, what has he to fear? As for my own part, continu'd he, I wou'd rather a Thouand times fall upon the point of my own Sword, than brag of a Favour receiv'd from a Lady. He mut needs be detitute both of Honour and Integrity that does it. If this be the only Scruple remaining, which troubles you, I can quickly free you from it, by auring you that as to this particular I am invincible: Love me therefore my Dearet, and
don't any longer refue to give me that mot precious Pledge of your Love, which I beg of you. The Marhal expres'd thee words in o Paionate a manner, that even at that very Moment the Lady was overcome. I have undertood ince, that our General, who never attacks any Place without ucces; luckily hit at that time on the very Critical Minute, and he made ue of it with dicretion, like a Man of Honour, this is to ay, without boating of it, as a great many Gentlemen do, when they meet with a good chance. The atifaction which the Marhal receiv'd in the enjoyment of this Englih Lady, far urpaed what he had from his Spanih Mitres at Puicerda. He continu'd his amourous Engagements for ome time with the latter, as a Peron of much Honour and Bravery; till being order'd to ome Warlike Expedition, he was fain to reolve to quit his Mitres. While thee two Lovers were lamenting that cruel eparation which was o near at Hand; the Husband of this fair Englih Lady, having receiv'd her Letter, and fearing not without Reaon, that a Coronet was preparing for his Head, had made all the peed he cou'd to come into Germany. The Marhal was over-joy'd at the News, finding his Mitres to grow omewhat burdenome to his Pure, be.
ides that he was oblig'd to pay her more than ordinary repect, in regard of her Quality.

Mr. Stone was extremely well atisfy'd to meet his Wife, whom he believ'd to have been very faithful to him; but poor Man, he was very much mitaken, he mut have come a little ooner, if he wou'd have prevented her from entring him in the Cuckold's Order. However, matters pas'd between 'em with a great deal of Love and Amity. The Marhal treated the Englih Gentleman no otherwie than his Friend, auring him by everal Oaths that he wou'd be ready to erve him, whenever any Occaion hou'd preent it elf. But the Lady was greatly afflicted at the Approaching departure of her Lover, who was o complaiant to tay with her as long as poibly he cou'd, even ome time beyond his Orders, during which, they let lip no opportunity to trengthen the good Huband's Horns, who was not enible of what pains they took for him, or if he was, did conceal his Reentment. However, one Evening, after the Marhal was jut gone out of her Appartment, he cou'd not forbear telling her, that he thought he had a little too much kindnes for the Marhal. What wou'd't thou have me do my Dear, reply'd he, you know what vat
Obligations I have receiv'd from him; he has dealt o generouly with me, that 'tis impoible for me to forget it as long as I live. Alas! if it had not been for him, I had not been now among the Living. This was ufficient to perwade the poor Englih Gentleman, that all the kindnees which he had hewn him, were the bare effects of Gratitude. At lat Monieur Boufflers was forc'd to leave his Pot, and to depart conformably to the poitive Orders of the Count de Montal. I will not undertake here to give you a Relation of what pas'd in the Field during the ret of the Campaign, this not being my preent deign, but I hall rather follow the natural coure of our Hitory, which will lead us to ome new Love-Intreagues of our General; who being return'd after the Campaign was finih'd, to Paris, oon provided for himelf a new Mitres: This was a young Damel, the Daughter of a certain rich Merchant, whom he aw one Morning going to Mas at Clermont, where he went to hear a Sermon preach'd by a Jeuit, who contrary to the Cutom of his Society, was at that time to treat of pure Morality. Tho' the Marhal eem'd to be very attentive to the Doctrine preach'd by this Jeuit, who dicours'd like a very good Chritian, yet Love did not ceae to ininuate it elf into his Heart, and to make
him enible of its Force. Mademoielle Landy was the name of this Beauty, that had charm'd him at Church: She wore that day upon her Head one of your little black Feather-Caps, that were then in Fahion, which was o becoming to her, that tho' he was otherwie but an indifferent Beauty, yet the Marhal cou'd carce keep his Eyes from her. She oon perceiv'd it, and knowing her elf to be in a Place, where every thing ought to be done with a great deal of Modety, he pull'd her Hood omewhat lower over her Face. Sermon being ended, the Marhal took care to go out with her, and with a very gallant Air to ask her, if he wou'd not allow him the Honour to wait upon her to her Houe. This young Gentlewoman who was very well bred, and did not want Wit, quickly perceiving by his Behaviour that he was not a Man to be depis'd, accepted of his Civility; nay, eem'd well pleas'd to be Conducted home by o gallant a Gentleman.

The next day, the Marhal made her a Viit; he found her in her Chamber, where he was playing very Sweetly and Charmingly upon the Lute. The weetnes of her Voice and the skill with which he expres'd her Words to Admiration, were uch Powerful Charms to him, that
he eem'd to be quite Enchanted. But he was forc'd to carry on this Love-intreague with a great deal of Precaution; for her Father and Mother were Perons of good Repute, whoe chief aim was to preferr their only Daughter to ome good Match or another. They flatter'd themelves for ome time with the hopes that Monieur de Boufflers viited their Daughter upon this account, but they were much mitaken, for his only buines was to divert himelf, and to pend his leiure-time in amourous Adventures. Monieur Landy began at lat to dicover his Deign, and coming one day from the Exchange, met with the Marhal de Boufflers upon his Knees before his Daughter, Kiing her Hands: Upon his departure, he check'd her very everely, and in a Week after ent her to a Nunnery. The Marhal having perceiv'd that he was the caue that the Father had o unkindly treated his Daughter, gave him a Viit on purpoe to upbraid him with his everity. Will you marry her Sir, aid the Merchant briskly to Monieur Boufflers, if you will, I'll give her Thirty or Forty Thouand Crowns, ready Mony for her Portion. No Sir, reply'd Monieur Boufflers, my intent is not as yet to entangle my elf in Wedlock; all that I did, was only to pas away ome Melancholy hours in admiring thoe perfections, which I found in
her. You peak like a Gentleman, aid Monieur Landy miling, You have tht Opera and Play-Houe in this Town, which I hou'd think might be ufficient to divert you, without haunting our Houes, on purpoe to Debauch our Daughters. I have found my Daughter Madelon quite alter'd from what he was wont to be, ince he has convers'd with you. Gentlemen of your Kidney have a trange Influence over uch young Maidens, which is not much admir'd among us Citizens: We are not very ambitious of having 'em turn Wanton or Impudent Houe-wives: We willingly leave thee Qualifications to your Lady's of Pleaure, who don't think it any coniderable Crime to Cuckold their Husband's. You are not in the wrong of it, Sir, reply'd the Marhal with a Smile, to take care of your Pullets, let uch Game-Cock's as we hou'd Sport with 'em; I do believe we hou'd be apt to teach 'em another ort of Game; but at the ame time you treat your Daughter with too much Rigour, thus to thrut her into a Nunnery: As for my own part, I'll wear to you by St. Urbot, that I never poke twice of Love to her. Don't you know Sir, reply'd the Merchant, that St. Urbot is the Patron of all Treacherous and Perjur'd Perons, and what wonder is it, if you Soldiers chue him to be your Protector? You take us Soldiers then to be Devilih trange Creatures, my Friend, anwer'd the Marhal,
but I wou'd have you know, that if it were not for us, our Enemies wou'd have cropt your Ears long ago. No, no, Sir, you are mitaken, reply'd the Merchant, if matters were come to the utmot extremity, I believe we might be able to defend our elves as well as you. And continu'd he, Swearing a great Oath, and pointing at an old Cimetar that hung up in the Hall, with this very Weapon I dare undertake my elf to dipatch Thirty Soldiers at one troke. O brave Merchant, reply'd Monieur de Boufflers, taking him by the Hand; I find now that you are a Man of Courage, if our Enemies hou'd ever come to enter France, we hall be ure not to want brave Soldiers to ait us upon all Occaions. I'll take care that his mot Chritian Majety hall be inform'd of your Bravery. O good Sir, anwer'd Monieur Landy, I hope you will not play me uch a curvy trick; to tell you the truth, I am the greatet Coward in the VVorld; if any one takes me at a word; my Courage and Riches both are only in Conceit. Indeed, reply'd the Marhal, you have done very well to undeceive me, for ele I hou'd have certainly made you pas with the King both for a Croeus and a Caear: See now, aid the Merchant, how dangerous it is to have more Reputation than is convenient. 'Tis very probable that for this Opinion which the VVorld wou'd have conceiv'd both of
my VVealth and Bravery (tho' far from Truth) I might have paid dearly one time or another. VVell Sir, reply'd the Marhal, you are the bet Judge of both; Adieu, I leave you to your elves, but I wou'd have you hew your elf more kind to your Daughter, who does not deerve this ill treatment from your Hands.

Monieur de Boufflers, after having left the Merchant, return'd to his own Houe, to reflect upon his amourous Widdow hood which indeed was o burdenome to him, that he was not able to endure it long: He wanted ome new Love-engagement, let it cot what it wou'd. Opportunity, which always was favourable to him, oon preented a Paramour to his view. This was the Wife of a certain Counellour of Paris, one of the mot beautiful Women in this famous City. Their firt Acquaintance happen'd at the Play-Houe: He being then plac'd in one of the Boxes, this Lady who was in the Pitt, cat uch killing looks at him, that he cou'd not forbear going in, and to et himelf down by her. Being deirous to be further acquainted with her, he ent his Servant for ome dry Sweet-meats, China-Oranges and ome Lemonade, which he preented to her: The fair Lady, who was accutom'd to receive great Preents, did nevertheles not refue the mall ones; She accepted 'em
very chearfully, returning a thouand thanks to the Marhal, who told her at the ame time; Madam, I am over-joy'd at this happy Hour, which has procur'd me the advantage of your Acquaintance, It is a coniderable time ince I have been ambitious of this Honour. How Sir, reply'd the Gentlewoman very Merrily, cou'd you know me before I ever had an Opportunity of eeing you. Yes, Madam, reply'd he very eriouly, it is certain that a great while ago I had the advantage of knowing you, but looking upon you as a Peron of extraordinary Beauty and Merits, I never had the boldnes to approach you. The Lady finding her elf out-done in Compliments, turn'd the Dicoure upon the Players, who Acted their part very well, o that he wou'd fain have made thee the only Subject of the preent Conference, but Monieur Boufflers interrupted her. This is not, aid he, the Point in Quetion, you don't anwer me to what I poke to you of, concerning the Honour I have obtain'd of your Acquaintance. Truly Sir, reply'd he very martly, I know not well what anwer to make, you tell me that you have known me for ome time, and I was born in a Province which I believe you carce ever aw in your Life-time,
that is to ay, Normandy; and having not been above two Months in Paris, I cannot take it any otherwie than that you are pleas'd to Jet with me. Oh! Madam, anwer'd the Marhal, I rather wou'd be my own Executioner, than to conceal my entiments on purpoe to divert my elf at the expence of o lovely a Creature. I hou'd be aham'd of uch initer Proceedings, neither can my Heart conent to o bae an Action: Indeed it is not accutom'd to deal perfidiouly with any Peron, and much les with one who is o beautiful as you; it wou'd be eay for you to reduce its Inclinations to its Duty, if it were not in its own elf capable to Act with incerity, even in matters of the leat Moment. Oh! that pretty loving Heart, cry'd the Lady, as if he had been urpris'd, I believe this to be the only one in the World. How! always true, always incere, and without diguie; this is the firt of this kind, that ever I heard of, and epecially of o brave a Cavalier as you, who eteems it commonly no Sin to ay to a Woman whatever you think fit, tho' you carce ever retain any thought about it afterwards; much les that you hou'd have an inclination to performe it. Then you take me, Madam, aid the
Marhal looking earnetly upon her, for a Diembler and one that pretends to quite different things from what he thinks. Is this the Honour you are pleas'd to betow upon me at firt Sight? At this rate I have but little hopes of ininuating my elf into your Favour; it is not likely that you will et much value upon a Man of uch a Character. Notwithtanding all thee infirmities, reply'd he, 'tis not impoible but that I might Love you, provided that‚ÄîOh! Madam, aid the Marhal, being impatient to hear the ret, don't top here, ele you'll leave me in the greatet Ditraction imaginable.

The Play being jut ended, every one departed out of the Houe, and our Marhal, who had found this Lady's Converation very agreeable, wou'd needs conduct her Home, tho' he had in her Company one of her Brothers, who being a Student in the Jeuits College, was not very well acquainted with uch amourous Repartees. He when he had his Siter alone, began to argue the Cae very handomely with her, telling her, that he was now Marry'd, and therefore did not tand in need of a Gallant, and that if her Husband hou'd get the leat knowledge of it, he wou'd be very angry with her; he told her beides, that your Soldiers of all Men
ought not to be regarded, ince their only aim was to impoe upon the poor Women, and afterwards to laugh at 'em. Go, go, Brother, anwer'd the Lady, with your Advice another way, you have too much Sene for your Age. They that will tate the pleaures of Love, mut not argue o cloely as you do. Monieur Niguee my Husband is not likely to know any thing of our Intrigue; it wou'd be a hard Fate upon us poor Women, if we were to employ all our time and pains only to pleae a Husband: For my part, this does not at all uit with my Humour. The more pity for you Siter, reply'd Monieur Landrirette, (which was the name of the fair Lady's Brother) you'll make but a very indifferent Houe-Wife if you don't intend to make that your chief buines, as becomes an honet Gentlewoman, uch a one as you have been Educated at home; what can, continu'd he, be more Reproachful to a Woman that values her Reputation, than to hornify a poor harmles Man, who has not deerv'd it? And how dot thou know Landrirette, anwer'd his Siter briskly that he does not deerve it, his Brotherin-Law I am ure has great Occaion for a luty Pair to roue up his dull Spirits, and to clear his cloudy Brains.

Truly Siter, reply'd Landrirette, you either intend to make port with me, or ele I believe you are not in your right Wits; if I thought you were in good earnet, I wou'd be the firt that hou'd give notice of it to your Huband, who I don't quetion, wou'd find out a way to prevent his being dignify'd with Horns by you. Indeed, reply'd his Siter coffingly, I don't know whether he cou'd or not; a Woman is a trange ort of Creature to deal with, when he has once et her Reolution upon uch a thing. I am only too apt to believe it, anwer'd Landrirette, as he was going away, but pray Siter be mindful of your Duty, and conider that you have a Husband, unto whom you are accountable for your Actions. Come hither you Block-head, reply'd Madam Niguee, calling back her Brother, cant thou believe me to be uch a Fool, as not to tread in my Mother's Foot-teps. I have heard my Parents ay that when I was born, my Mother perwaded my Father, who is as thou knowt a good honet Man, (I uppoe thou dot apprehend my meaning) that he was big with me Ten or Eleven Months, which is contrary to the coure of Nature: My Father, who was willing to be abolutely atisfy'd in this matter, having
been abent thee Eleven Months, took Counel of a Phyitian, who had had more than half a hare in the begetting me, whether it were poible for any Woman to go o long with Child: You may eaily imagine that the Doctor told him it might very well be, partly out of elf-interet, and partly mov'd by the entreaties of my Mother, who was orely afraid that the Plot might be dicover'd. If any Siniter Accident hou'd happen to me, I warrant you we hall go near to find out means to clear that mitake. Is this your way to rectify your Errors, reply'd her Brother, for hame bluh at thee Reproachful Deigns; Adieu I cannot endure to hear you talk at this rate any longer.

Her Brother having thus left her, he enter'd her Cloet, where he began to Reflect upon her Paion, which he felt for Monieur de Boufflers, who had appear'd in her Eyes the mot charming and mot accomplih'd Man in the World, and as he aid to herelf, who deerv'd to poes the Heart of a Beautiful Woman, Oh! what a Satisfaction is it, aid he, to make uch a Conquet: His whole Air is charming, and I have oberv'd that all his Actions tend to honourable Deigns; but uppoing he hou'd not be o nice
in his Honour, as I cou'd wih for, what hazard can I run in the Cae? I am a Marry'd Woman; if I were a young Maid, he might (after he had deceiv'd me) expose me to his Scorn, but as I am, I need not init upon thee Trifles, I hall enjoy a Thouand happy Minutes, without any farther charge to my elf than a little Complaiance: As to the Horns, which my Husband is likely to get by the Bargain, I matter it not, knowing that he well deerves 'em; beides, that there are a great many others who think themelves fine Fellows, becaue they have the Honour to be admitted into that Order. 'Tis at preent the grand Mode of Paris, a fine buines indeed, to make o many Scruples about; is there not uch a Multitude of Perons who are content to wear 'em, that their number is not to be expres'd? Monieur Niguee her Husband coming into the Cloet, prevented her from making any farther Reflections for that time, being come to lead her to Supper.

The next Day the Marhal de Boufflers, who eldom looes a prize, gave a viit to this Lady, who very joyfully bid him welcome to her Houe, and her Husband, who as I have told you before, was a Counellour, deir'd our General to come into
his Study, which was furnih'd all over with Baggs of Writings. Monieur Boufflers was at that time actually engag'd in a Law uit, and having occaion for the advice of a Lawyer, he deliver'd his Writings to our Counellor, who return'd him a Thouand Compliments for the Honour he did him, in making ue of him in this Law Suit: He promis'd that he wou'd perue 'em all over, and not be wanting in his endeavours to gain him the Caue. I hall think my elf very much oblig'd to you, Sir, anwer'd Monieur de Boufflers, putting two or three Golden Lovies into his Hand: I will deire your Lady to put you in Mind of my buines. She is your Servant Sir, reply'd the Counellor, leading him into his Wifes Chamber, who had left 'em by themelves, not quetioning but that the Marhal wou'd give her a Viit in private before he departed. Pray oberve Sir, aid the good Man, peeping his Wife in the Face, he has more Interet in the Courts of Jutice than my elf. When my Lord chief Preident comes to our Houe, Come hither my Dearet, will he ay, take you my Robe and Cap, and do you give Sentence as you think Convenient. O dear Sir, aid the Marhal Smiling, I hope this may turn to my great Advantage, Come Madam, Come, aid he, making a hew as if he wou'd embrace
her, if you will but take my buines in Hand, I don't quetion but we hall manage the Caue to very good purpoe. But Sir, continu'd he, ere I forget it, are not you a Native of Normandy; if I don't mitake, I have heard 'em ay that you have great skill in the tricking part of the Law, as mot of your bet Gentlemen of that Country have. No, Sir, reply'd Monieur Niguee, I was born near Paris, but Normandy is the Native Country of my Wife. O you then are the Peron who is bet skill'd in that part, reply'd the General in a Familiar manner, it is to you that I mut make my application, and give you Intructions concerning my whole Buines. No quetion Sir, reply'd the Counellor, but that we hall find it out in time, I will leave you with my Wife to open the Caue; whilt I go to a certain Abbot one of my old Friends, to draw up a Petition for him of great Conequence. I cannot but tell you before I go, that this Abbot having got a young Wench with Child, he now Sues him for a Maintenance both for her elf and the Child, for their Lives. My Dearet, do you relate the ret of the Story to Monieur Boufflers. O yes, yes, aid the Lady, being very uneaie that he was not gone before, my dear weet Huband,
I will notfail to do it, do but yno go to the Abbot du Gret, 'tis poible he may ele employ another Lawyer. O Plague! aid he, putting on his Cloak, I hou'd not like that, for he is a pleaant ort of a Fellow; beides, he has always ome Law-buines or another, epecially relating to Women, being a particular admirer of the fair Sex, and is always buie in grafting in their Gardens. For that I undertand aid Monieur Boufflers, this is a dangerous Spark: Adieu reply'd Monieur Niguee, my Wife knows him better than I.

The Counellor's Lady being thus rid of the troubleome Company of her Huband, immediately enter'd upon her Love-concerns, which was what the Marhal wih'd for. The Parly was oon over, and in a little time they began to examine matters, piece by piece, but epecially thoe of the Marhal de Boufflers; which this fair Lady handl'd almot without Intermiion, confeing to him ingenuouly, that he had never touch'd any thing o well proportion'd in her Life-time. But Madam reply'd he, perceiving that he was no novice at the Trade, you have forgot my Lord Preident's, are not his Parts uperiour to mine? Oh! there is a great deal of difference my Dear, reply'd he with a little Confuion, I never met with a more diagreeable Man in the whole
coure of my Life, than he is from Head to Foot; for his Natural Parts both above and below, are o inconiderable, that one wou'd wear he had been clipt on all ides. This was enough for our Marhal to atisfy himelf in what he was deirous to know, concerning this Lady, with whom he had been o lately engag'd, and whom he had found alo very defective as to what he had imagin'd her to be at firt Sight: Wherefore after ome farther Converation altogether relating to Love Affairs, he was for taking his leave, but the Lady, who was not o oon cool'd as he entreated him to tay a little longer, which the Marhal excus'd, under pretence that a violent Fit of the Colick had eis'd him; o that without any farther delay he departed from thence, to give a viit to one of his Relations, who liv'd in the Suburbs of St. Germain, to whom he gave an account of this whole Adventure, without mincing the matter.

O brave! cry'd this Lady, laughing at him, now you have catch'd a Tortois indeed, you have betow'd your Love upon a very deerving Creature, whoe chief Reputation is, that he protitutes herelf to all orts of Men, viz, Priets, Monks, Hotlers, &c. nothing comes amis to her, even to the Curate of Meudon, and he you mut know is a brave
Fellow indeed. And what is this terrible Fellow pray, reply'd the Marhal de Boufflers deiring her to continue her dicoure. What he is, reply'd Madam Garenne, Ill tell you my Dear Kinman, he bepatters the reputation of all the Women and Maids in his Parih, except uch as he knows to be willing to comply with his Brutih Lut. That Impudent Racal, reply'd the Marhal laughing ought to be ous'd, as well as all the ret of the Religious Orders, that cannot keep within their bounds. I know one my elf, whom I make ue of ometimes for a Father Confeour, who oftner talks of Love, than of Penance to thoe Ladies, who come to him to Confeion.

One of the Lady's Gentlewomen coming into the Room, broke off the Dicoure, telling her that the Countes of‚Äîwas come to pay her Honour a Viit. The Marhal very earnetly looking in the Face of of this Gentlewoman, found her as fair as an Angel, beides that he had a mot Charming weetnes in her Speech and whole Deportment; Monieur de Boufflers having been intantly touch'd with her Charms, told his Couin, that for certain Reaons he wou'd not be preent while the Countes paid her Viit, but that in the mean while he wou'd tay in her Chamber. Madam Garenne, who had always a great deal of
Complaiance for him, aid to her waiting Woman, Janneton, do you in the mean time entertain my Couin with the pleaant Adventures of the unfortunate She Lover, which was at that time a new Novel much in Vogue, and which her Gentlewoman had got by Heart. She had no ooner begun to relate the firt Intrigue, when the Marhal Squeezing her Hands between his: told her with a very Paionate look. I wih you wou'd rather tell me omewhat concerning your own Love-concerns, than of others, In which I have not the leat hare. How Sir, reply'd Janneton with a bluh, hou'd I relate to you my own Love-Adventures, who never Lov'd in my Life-time? Is it poible my fairet, anwer'd the Marhal, that o charming a Creature as you hou'd not have been made enible of the force of Love. You wou'd Madam, aid he, give, but will not take. I don't in the leat believe reply'd he, with a very becoming Modety, that it is in my Power to engage any one in Love. Oh! Madam, reply'd the Marhal miling, you are but only too powerful, for at this very Moment you, have made me your Slave. Janneton who was unacquainted with uch Paionate Expreions, epecially coming from the Mouth of uch a Gentleman as the
Marques de Boufflers; return'd no anwer to what he aid, but riing from her eat, was about to leave the Marhal alone notwithtanding her Mitrees orders, to entertain him during her Abence.

But the Marhal topping her Paage, whether will you fly, aid he, my dear Child, pray don't deny to hear my ufferings. What wou'd you have me ay Sir, reply'd the young Gentlewoman with a bluh which had pread it elf all over her Face I don't undertand your Language, and I am much urpris'd that you'll toop o low as to make it your buines to wheedle o inconiderable a Peron as I am, who am altogether ignorant in the Love Cards, as in the Art of Algebra. Thou art in Jet ure my Dearet, reply'd the Marhal, going to Kis her Mouth which was very mall, and as red as Coral; Love, is Natural to both Sexes, and I can read it in thy fair Eyes, that thou art not inenible of it. Oh! thou pretty Rogue, let me embrace thee, ele I dye without delay, Dye if you pleae Sir, reply'd Janneton, puhing him from her, you are full of your Tranports and Familiarities, which are in no wie agreeable to my Humour; how long have you known me, thus to call me, thou at every turn, you may call your Servant-Maids
o if you pleae: As for me, I was born the Daughter of the Marques de la Fleur, who is decended of a noble and ancient Family in Bretaigne, tho' omewhat decay'd and under a Cloud at this time. Madam Garenne has been pleas'd to take me into her Houe and does not treat me like a Servant but as a Friend. The Marhal having conider'd with himelf, that his Couin at her going out of the Room had deir'd her to entertain him; which Office does not belong to Chamber-maids, he told her, throwing himelf at her Feet; Madam I beg your Pardon, I was not o happy as to know you before, beides 'twas the exces of my Paion that made me take too much liberty; but I find you Cruel and Inexorable to the highet degree. As far I can ee, you wou'd let whole Troops of Lovers dye at your Feet, without the leat Compaion on your ide; certainly Madam this is a crime of the highet Nature, to be o Inhuman. I take it to be a greater Crime in you Sir, reply'd Janneton, laughing at his being in this Poture, to endeavour to perwade us, if we were o Foolih as to believe it, that you are mot Paionately in Love with all uch Perons, to whom you addres your Courthips; but as for my part, you mut excue me, if I cannot
give Credit to your Aeverations, I know a little too well the true Character of you Courtiers, not by Experience, but by the Relations of others, who have had the Opportunity to try 'em. And what do thoe pretty incredulous Creatures ay of us, reply'd the Marhal carelely. O Sir, aid Janneton, they'll tell you of a thouand Diembling and Perfidious tricks, uch as are altogether unbecoming a great Soul: I wonder how Gentlemen of Quality can condecend to make ue of uch mean ways to deceive our Sex; I hou'd think that Love, being the mot innocent Commerce among us Mortals, hou'd be founded upon honourable Principles. You have poke very well, my mot adorable Janneton, cry'd the Marhal Tranported with Paion; but you mut conider that thee Lady's of whom you peak, deal omewhat unjutly with us, in repreenting all Men of one and the ame Temper: There are ome that are Lovers of Honour and Integrity, and wou'd corn to deal upon other Terms with your Sex; thanks to my Stars, I am of the number of thee, and I wou'd ooner, added he, drawing his Sword out of the Scabbard, thrut this thro' my Heart than deceive a Lady that Loves me. Then Sir, reply'd the young Lady miling, one
mut Love you, if one wou'd make ure of your Heart. Yes Divine Creature, aid Monieur de Boufflers, that is the only way to Conquer it and to make it your Vaal.

Madam Garenne, who had re-conducted the Countes to her Coach, coming in, interrupted 'em, otherwie our General wou'd not have broke off o oon; But this Lady as oon as he was enter'd well Couin aid She, has Mademoielle de la Fleur entertain'd you with ome atisfaction concerning the unfortunate She-Lover? Yes Madam, reply'd the Marhal, cating a tender look upon Janneton, but I have in my turn, entertain'd her with that of the Unfortunate He Lover, who cou'd not perwade his Mitres of his incerity, upon which ubject I have enlarg'd to the utmot of my Ability. Your Mademoielle there, is the mot unlucky, unbelieving Creature in the World, he will not believe a Word one ays; except you forwear your elf to the Devil, you cannot perwade her of the leat thing that can be. O dear Couin, aid Madam Garenne, don't Swear; you are not ignorant that the fair Sex is always incredulous, and that they take a particular Pride in making their Gallants languih for 'em. Plague! on this way of making Love; reply'd the Marques pleaantly, I wou'd have 'em take my Word at
firt. Oh! my dear Kinman, anwer'd the Lady, this wou'd abate a great deal of the pleaure; you know that every thing that is bought dear pleaes bet: If a Woman hou'd at firt ight urrender her Heart, you wou'd be deprivd of the mot charming part of your Paion: What is eaily obtain'd, oon looes its Vigour, and fades as fat as it grows. But come, let us talk of other more ubtantial matters; one cannot live upon Love, and in my mind, Love is but a lender Diet.

No ooner had the Lady broke off this Dicoure, but he order'd that a good Collation hou'd be got ready; in the mean time, the Marhal who appear'd very penive, retir'd into another Room, where having fix'd his Eyes upon everal Pictures repreenting ome Rural Nymphs, he diverted himelf with ome Patoral Songs; which his Kinwoman having taken notice of; Come, Come, Couin, cry'd he, awake out of your Amourous lumber, come tate whether my Wine be good. By my Faith Madam, anwer'd the Marhal, I am o drunk with Love, that all other Food is inipid, every thing ele is indifferent to me: Not very long ago, continu'd he, being at Supper with the two Marhals, de Crequi and de Navaille, and my Thoughts being taken up with a certain amourous Aignation at a place where I had been entertain'd ome time before, with a
great deal of Delight and Satisfaction; thee Gentlemen finding me thus penive, were o piteful as to lip upon my Plate a great piece of a Candle, which I wallow'd ere I was aware of it, and when this was done, you may imagine they jeer'd me very handomely. What a Fool dot thou make thy elf, Boufflers, aid Madam Garenne, thus to put thy elf into Amourous Raptures; if a compleat Hitory of thy Love-adventures were to be committed to Writing, it wou'd undoubtedly make a very large Volume. When you have drunk this Glas of Wine, (which he preented to him,) be o Complaiant, aid he to him, as to tell me who it is that at preent has Captivated your Heart. And wou'd you have me tell you incerely my dear Kinwoman, reply'd the Marhal, 'tis Mademoielle de la Fleur, who has chain'd me o cloely, that I hall carce be able to bear it long, except this lovely Child will take ome pitty on me: She appears to me the mot amiable Peron in the World; her pretty little Mouth, her roguih Eyes, which end forth their Rays like o many Darts every moment: Lord! I hall run Mad, if I think any longer of 'em: Come, Truce in Love for ome time; Come let us drink once, continu'd he, Drinking a hearty draught of Wine, which was extraordinary good: Here is to your bet Inclinations; here is to your charming Eyes, aid he, to Mademoielle de la Fleur, who was jut
coming into the Room. Come Janneton, aid Madam Garenne laughing, Pledge the Marhal that ame Health. Madam, reply'd the young Gentlewoman very modetly, I have buines of greater moment than to pledge the Marhal's Health to my Inclinations, which as I am apt to believe are not agreeable to his entiments, who admires good natur'd and plyable Lady's. and thoe too mut be as weet and tender as young Mutton. Thus I wou'd wih it to be Mademoielle, reply'd the Marhal, taking her by the Hand. Pray Sir, aid Janneton very gravely, let me go, I am jut now about to paint you one, which I am ure will pleae you. Provided he be like you, reply'd Monieur de Boufflers, I am ure I hall like her.

Mademoielle de la Fleur being gone out of the Room, our General, who was really in Love both with her Wit and engaging Air, poke concerning her with a great deal of earnetnes to his Couin, who gave him to undertand that he was a Gentlewoman of good Quality, and that out of Repect, he had made her her Companion. Indeed he told me o, anwer'd the Marhal, and he did not forget to mention the great Obligations he had to you: I have a great deal of Compaion for her upon that core, reply'd the Lady; truely I know her to be a young Woman of a good Reputation, and I
hope he has Wit enough to keep it. And o do I Madam, reply'd the Marhal, if he will take my Word for it, I aure you I Love her as much‚ÄîThe Lady having oon undertood the Marhal's meaning, Pray Couin, aid he, don't you go about to Debauch this young Gentlewoman, for whom I have a particular kindnes; it is a trange thing that you Gentlemen cannot employ your time better, than to put Love-tricks into the young Womens Heads, who of a udden turn Fools, and are undone by it. Your Amourous Intreagues are as dangerous as your Martial Exploits: You talk of nothing when you are together, but of conuming of Hearts as well as Villages by Fire, and by your good will you wou'd reduce every thing to Ahes: Come employ you Firelocks in another Place, than in my Houe which you ought to Honour and Repect. But Madam, reply'd the Marhal briskly, uppoing this Fire you peak of hou'd firt break out in your Houe, may not a Man complain of 'it, or make himelf atisfaction? Ay, Ay, you are never unprovided for a Repartee, reply'd the Lady, but let me deire you, if you will oblige me, not to talk of Love to Janneton, whenever you ee her. Then the Devil take me my dear Couin, aid Monieur de Boufflers hatily, if any thing in the World can make me do that; at that rate I mut go and cut out my‚ÄîI dare not name it. Oh! cry'd
the Lady laughing, you are not half o deperate as you wou'd make us believe. Farewel, you are only ick in Fancy, I leave you to your elf. But Madam, reply'd the Marhal pleaantly, and hall I not have the liberty to love Mademoielle de la Fleur, and to tell her‚ÄîNo, No, not her, cry'd the Lady, Declare your Paion to ome Body ele, where it will turn to better Account: Janneton was not made for uch Sparks as you. You may ay what you pleae my dear Couin, aid the Marhal, jut as he was going, but this I am ure of, I am reolv'd to adore her.

No ooner was the Marhal gone, but Madam Garenne call'd for Janneton, who was at that time making a piece of Embroidery-work, which was the Figure of Diana, wrought with Silk and Gold; he had repreented this Goddes o lively, itting jut upon the Banks of a mall Current, that it was charming to behold, and one cou'd not chue but extremely admire both the skill of the Work-Woman, and the exactnes of the Work. When he was come down to Madam Garanna, he began to give her a very ober Leon concerning the Marhal de Boufflers, whom he told her, he mut by no means hearken to, but fly from his preence, as that of her greatet Enemy; if you did but know my Dearet, aid he, unto what danger a young
Woman expoes her elf, whenever he lends an Ear to the flattering Courthips of your Soldiers, it wou'd make you tand amaz'd; nothing but what is terrible and frightful belongs to 'em, and a vertuous Woman mut inevitably looe her Reputation, if he be converant with 'em; if they happen to meet with any one that is o foolih as to be catch'd in the Snare, he will be ure to be rewarded with a certain loathome Ditemper, which is not fit to be nam'd, and makes a great many Women undergo the Martrydom of Love. Young Women, who deign to make their Fortune in the World, mut not et up for light Houe-Wives, but fly from the Company of Men, as it were o many evil Spirits; this is the ready way to advance themelves the ooner by a good Match. I remember that the firt time that I aw my Husband, I had not till then poke to any other Man; in omuch that he was more taken with my innocent Behaviour than with my Beauty and Portion, tho' both of 'em (if I may ay it without Vanity) were not depieable. I having at that time the Reputation of being one of the mot beautifull VVomen in Paris. You have till a great hare of it, reply'd Janneton miling, you are till worthy of the ame Character. Let us et jeting a ide, reply'd the Lady, and let us return to Boufflers, who is one of the mot dangerous Men in the World; to hear him talk of his Paion, you wou'd imagine that the whole Univere was not able
to contain it, which often comes to no more than a Viit. I don't know Madam, reply'd Mademoielle de la Fleur, with a very erious Countenance, why you hou'd give uch a Leon to me, who never knew any thing of the General, but what I heard you peak, and to whom I never poke in my Life before, till now. Well, Well, Janneton, aid Madam Garenne, that advantage is not very great on your ide: For to tell you the true motive, which makes me talk thus to you; you mut know that he has declar'd to me, that he is fall'n in Love with you: Jeus Maria, reply'd Janneton, much urpris'd is it poible that he hou'd be o Silly, as to tell you a thing of this nature, which I am apt to believe he carce ever dream'd of? Madam if you will take my opinion in the matter, it was only to divert himelf; don't you oberve what delight he takes to banter the Women. He banters 'em often to ome purpoe, aid the Lady laughing, he has by thee bant'ring Tricks got many a young Soldier to defend our Frontiers. 'Tis not above two Months ago that a young Country-Damel brought forth at one Birth two luty Boys of his begetting which I believe lye a little hard upon him at preent, becaue he is oblig'd to take care as well of the Mother, as of the Children, whom he ays, he will make his Foot-men, as oon as they are able to wear a Lavery-Coat. He does very well, reply'd Mademoielle
de la Fleur, to find out o honourable an Employment for 'em in time, Madam, I wou'd have you be at ret as to this Point, for I aure you that I never hall love Monieur de Boufflers.

But Alas! how difficult a task it is for a young tender Heart to forwear Love, which by degrees Triumphs over all the World. This fair One was no ooner gotup into her Chamber again, but he began to feel ome extraordinary Emotions for the Marhal, whoe Idea was firmly fixt in her Mind, tho' he had poke of him with o much indifferency to her Lady: It eem'd as if the Leon which he had receiv'd from her Mouth, had only erv'd to raie ome kind of tendernes in her Heart, of which he was not o enible before. I Love him in pite of what reitance I can make, aid Janneton, while he was ruminating upon the matter; the Idea I have conceiv'd of him, begins to be very delectable to me; if I had not been o much Tutor'd about it, perhaps I hou'd never have lov'd him: What trange Fatality! They decribe him to me as a Man equally terrible both in Love and War, but good God! notwithtanding all this, I am not able to controll my growing Paion, I am enible I hou'd tifle that ecret Voice which calls to me, Love, Love, and I hou'd not make the leat return to the
Marhal's Protetations, which like Thunderclaps oon trike down to the Ground a Heart o feeble as mine.

She was making thee Reflections with herelf, when Madam Garenne, who began to repent of having aid o much to her upon that Subject, coming up into her Chamber, ask'd her, whether her Work went on a pace? Yes Madam, reply'd the young Gentlewoman, in a very Melancholy Tone, I do what I can to bring it forward! What is the matter with you Janneton, aid the Lady, looking in her Face, you eem to be much dicompos'd; what is it that diturbs you? Nothing Madam, reply'd he, 'tis impoible for any Peron always to retain an even Temper; there is none that is not out of Humour at certain times. I don't deny that my Dear, anwer'd the Lady, but at the ame time, a young Woman as you are, mut not give way to Melancholy Fancies, What can be the caue of it? Janneton made no further anwer, but under pretence of looking about for omething that he had mi-laid, he got free of her Lady, who began to be troubleome to her at that time; for the Lady imagining that her ilence proceeded from being to over diligent at her Work, left her to her elf in her Chamber, and went down into her own, where he pent her time in reading a
Book of Devotion, which bears the Title of Moral Reflections upon the Lives of the Saints.

But let us leave thee two Lady's for a little while, and ee what is become of our Marhal, who went to his Lodgings as enamour'd as ever he was in Life-time: He repreented to his Imagination the perfections of Mademoielle de la Fleur, which had uch an influence over his Spirits, that he did neither Sleep nor Eat, as he us'd to do, becaue he never went either to Bed or Table, without being diturb'd by his amourous Diorders: He appear'd always penive, being overwhelm'd with a thouand ditracting Cares, which almot reduc'd him to the extremity of Depair, when he conider'd with himelf all the obtacles which he was to urmount before he cou'd have the leat hopes of obtaining his aim; for Madam Garenne his Couin had peremtorily declar'd that he wou'd not allow of the leat Intercoure between him and his Mitres, from whom he as yet had receiv'd but very mall encouragement;‚Äîbut that which afforded him mot Conolation was, that he had oberv'd in her whole deportment a natural inclination to tendernes, tho' he feign'd in ome of her Actions a great deal of haughtines and cruelty. This hope (the common attendant
of Love) made him ruminate a long time what means might be mot expedient for the accomplihing of his Deign, which was contrary to the Will of his Friend; to whom he ow'd infinite obligations, becaue it was her Husband who had lent him the Mony, with which he had purchas'd the Royal Regiment of Dragoons, which he commanded as Colonel at that time. However, all thee coniderations were not trong enough to divert him from puruing his former Intentions.

But before he went again to his Couin's, he took a Reolution firt to go and give a Viit to his Counellor, Monicur Niguee, being now reolv'd to break quite off with his Wife, for whom he cou'd not any longer have either Love or eteem: When he came to the Counellor's Houe, he ask'd him for his Writings, at which the Lawyer being much urpris'd, told him that he carce had time enough to perue'em, deiring him to let him know the reaon of his calling for 'em o uddenly. No other Reaon Sir, reply'd the Marhal, but that both Parties have agreed the matter; pray let me know how much I am indebted to you for your trouble. Monieur Niguee who was a Mater at his Trade, as mot of that Profeion are, made him a Bill; which amounted to as much as if
he had manag'd the whole Caue from the beginning to the end. What the Devil, aid the Marhal de Boufflers, whilt he was paying the Mony; Do you thus manage all your Clients Pures? I think he was in the right on't that was wont to compare you Counellors and Sollicitors to Familiar Spirits, who uually get all the Mony they can, to carry it along with 'em to Hell into Lucifer's Treaury. The Lawyer perceiving an Affront to be put upon him by this Expreion, told him that he cou'd find a way to make him hold his Tongue, and taking him by one Arm, was ready to thrut him out of the doors. How now Block-head, anwered Monieur Boufflers, I'll make you know whom you have to do withal, and no ooner had he poke thee Words, but he econded 'em with his Sword, which he very martly laid over the Counellor's Head; take this for your Pains, aid our General, Mr. Cuckold, take this, it may erve to polih your Horns a little, which as yet are omewhat rugged.

Madam Niguee the Counellor's Wife having heard a udden noie in the Entry, came running out with all peed to ee waht might be the matter: She happen'd jut at that time to be in Company with a Frier, who as 'twas uppos'd, was accutomed to kis her in Private, and being urpris'd at the Scuffle, had forgot to put down her
Petty-coats, which were till up as high as to her Knees: When he aw her Husband and Gallant thus engag'd, he was o extremely amaz'd, that he was not able to peak one Word, but eeing the Marhal lay his Sword over her Husband's Horn's without intermiion, he cou'd do nothing ele but make a mot lamentable out-cry, which oon brought the Frier out to her aitance, but in as bad a Condition as her elf: For the good Father had forgot in the fright to put up his Buines in its right place, which was all expos'd to the view of the Spectators; Monieur Boufflers as angry as he was (having receiv'd ome blows from the Counellor) cou'd not forbear laughing out aloud; How now, aid he, Religious Father, if a Man may call you o, are you not aham'd to act thus above board? You pretend to teach us Chatity, and you appear in our ight jut recking from your unchat Embraces; fy! what a hameles ight is this! And pulling him by the Sleeve, at leat Sir, aid he, put up your Concerns. The Frier and the Lady being in the mean while recover'd from their firt urprie, began now to be enible of their mitake, but being put all into confuion, they run away as fat as they cou'd, without making the leat anwer. The poor Counellor was no les urpris'd than the
other two, becaue he had een his Horns in their Natural hape, without diguie, which made him retreat as fat as he cou'd to his Study, after he had been oundly drub'd by the Marhal, who thus remaining Mater of the Field of Battel, decamp'd immediately from thence with his Writings in his Poeion.

A few days after, being now pretty well recover'd of his Paion, which he had had for the Counellor's Wife, he intended to make a viit to Madam Garenne, to give her an account of this lat Adventure, but conidering with himelf, that he wou'd only laugh at him, he deferr'd it till a more convenient Opportunity. The next day, paing by chance by her Houe, about four a Clock in the Afternoon, and the Door being jut open, he epy'd Janneton, who was conducting out one of her Acquaintance: The Marhal perceiv'd her to bluh at the ight of him, and as he was drawing nearer to accot her, he made away with all the hate he cou'd. Boufflers, who never wants preence of Mind, upon uch an occaion as this, follow'd her cloe, and why, aid he, Mademoielle do you hun me, what is it that is o frightful about me? Yes Sir, reply'd Janneton not with out ome diturbance, I dread you in a mot terrible manner, and that too not
without a great many weighty Reaons; but for Heaven's ake don't force me to declare 'em to you; if your Kinwoman hou'd happen to ee us together, he wou'd not think very well of it. I am not ignorant of that matter, my dear Child, reply'd the Marhal, but for God's ake tay but one Moment: Never any Mortal uffer'd o much as I have done, neither Lov'd to that degree as I do. All thoe pathetical Expreions commonly us'd by Lovers to make their Mitrees enible of the Vehemency of their Paion, fall far hort of what I can ay of mine. You have robb'd me of my Liberty my fair Angel, and I must be the mot unfortunate of all Men living, except you take compaion of my Sufferings.
