He cou'd not utter thee lat Words without hedding ome Tears, which wrought no ill effect upon the the fair One, that was the occaion of 'em, and who anwer'd in Terms o obliging, and with o charming an Air, to what he had aid to her, that the Marhal was no longer Mater of himelf, but reolv'd to proecute his Deign in pite of his Kin-woman's endeavours to the contrary, But Janneton who conider'd that if this Lady hou'd return ooner from Viiting than he expected, he wou'd be chid everely, and be in danger of utterly loing her Favour, begg'd with all the Civility imaginable, her Lover to leave her for that time
which he did, not thinking it reaonable to dioblige her, who run o much hazard for his ake. Among the ret of the Servants of the Houe, there was an old Maid, whoe name was Toinette, he was the Governes of the Kitchen, and having oberv'd our two Lovers prattling together, he advertis'd Madam Garenne of it as oon as he came Home, who being tranported with Anger, chid Janneton mot everely, which he wou'd have endur'd patiently enough if this Lady had not econded her Words with uch a ound Box on the Ear, that he tumbl'd down upon one ide; calling her at the ame time wanton Slut, an impudent and diembling Wretch, &c. You will e're long find the effects of his Courthip, aid he, if you are Fool enough to hearken to 'em: He is the mot fickle Man in the World; he never loves above one Moment; he has as many Mitrees as he has Shirts to his Back, and he changes 'em twice or thrice a Week. Is this your modety? Is this your Conduct, which made you to be o much repected among People of vertuous Principles?

Thee his amourous Protetations were accompany'd with uch Paionate Tranports, and intermingl'd with o many weet Kies, which he tole from his fair Angel, that ix or even Hours pas'd thus away no otherwie than if it had been one Moment; in the mean while Night began to approach, and Mademoielle de la Fleur reflecting upon the matter, how unbecoming it was for a modet Gentlewoman to be thus late in an Officer's Chamber, who was one of the greatet Gallants
about the Town, and ruminating hovv he hou'd bet dipoe of her elf; becaue her Lover had not in the leat taken notice of it, he was not a little urpris'd to ee the Land-Lady come in, who immediately told her that if he pleas'd there was a Chamber ready for her in the Houe, not far from the Marhal's, which he had caus'd to be furnih'd very handomely for her ue. You need ay no more Mrs. Borgne, aid the Marhal, my Siter whom I have not een a great while, will tay here for ome time; Pray let Supper be got ready. The Land-Lady went down to look after Supper, leaving the Brother and Siter at their own Liberty, who did not live long together in the ame condition; as you'll find by the equel of the Story: Supper being ready, Monieur Boufflers order'd it to be brought up into his Chamber, becaue he intended to Sup in private, and poor Janneton at there like a Carthuian Frier, that is to ay, without peaking one Word, being hy of the Marhal's Servants who waited at Table, and look'd upon her as a chance-Lady, the Marhal oberv'd it as well as he, but there was no Remedy for it.

Having Supp'd and dimis'd the Servants, he conducted her into the Chamber which was prepar'd for her, where he tay'd a good part of the Night, which was pent
at the Feet of his Mitres, and in reiterated aurances of the incerity of his Paion. 'Tis eaie to be imagin'd, what ort of Language two Perons, that lov'd one another did make ue of, at a time when all the World was at ret. Janneton being now omewhat weary'd with the Carees receiv'd from her Lover, was willing to go to leep, notwithtanding the continual entreaties of the Marhal, who has ince proteted to me, with all the incerity imaginable, that he never met with any young Lady o Lovely, o Modet, and o worthy of his Heart as he was: Having at her deire quitted her Room, he went likewie to his own Chamber, to take ome ret after his Love-toils, which by this time had caus'd him to endure no mall Fatigues.

Let us leave thee two Lovers for a little while, to enjoy their Ret, whilt we go and oberve how Madam Garenne takes the Elopement of her Companion: This Lady having mis'd her, caus'd Candles to be lighted immediately, and order'd the Houe to be earch'd from top to bottom. What is become of this Impudent Baggage, wou'd he cry, being ometimes in the Garret, and anon in the Cellar, after he had look'd long enough for her in all the Chambers of the Houe; I hope, aid he, he has
thrown herelf into the River or ome Pond, what an unfortunate Woman was I, when I took upon me the charge of this wanton Slut, who has play'd me a trick that I did not in the leat dream of? What can become of her? If the Marhal de Boufflers hou'd get the leat cent of this michance, he will quickly be with her. I believe Madam, aid Toinette, that that is not to be done now, for I am almot ure that he is with him already: If you had been an Eye-Witnes of thoe Carees which he o Liberally betow'd upon her, you wou'd not quetion it any more than I do. Alas! a perfidious Man as he is, reply'd the Lady, he loves all handome Women; but God is my Witnes, that it is eldom for above two or three Weeks, to obtain his aim, and then he wihes 'em in another part of the World. Don't let us talk any more of the Paion of a Man whoe inclinations are o fickle and incontant; 'tis impoible that he can have any real Friendhip for any one living; I am convinc'd of it by the treatment I have receiv'd from him: After my Huband has done for him what he has, he was o much indebted to me; that he ought to have Sacrifis'd every thing in acknowledgment of uch a Friendhip, intead of which, he caues me thee Vexations.

But pray, aid he, tell me, in what manner did he cares her, who never undertood any thing of thee matters, having carce ever een a Man in private ince he was a Child, when her Father gave her into my Charge? Sure Madam you are not in earnet, anwer'd the old Maid laughing, thee things are natural to us, they are learn'd without much exercie. But pray tell me, aid Madam Garenne, what did he do to her? What hou'd he do to her Madam? reply'd Toinette, he kis'd ometimes her Hands, and ometimes her Lips; he lay down at her Feet jut like a Fool; he embrac'd her, calling her at the ame time his Deity, his Angel, and a thouand uch like extravagancies. Oh! that idle Baggage! aid the Lady, he will like this port mightily for ome time, till he be put out of tate with it. Madam Garenne wou'd have continu'd her dicoure, if her Dometick Affairs had not call'd for her preence another way, where we will leave her, and return to our two Lovers.

The Marhal de Boufflers now in full poeion of his Mitres, was not waning to give her every day new Proofs of his Love; auring her that it hou'd always be inviolable, which promie; he made a hift to keep for ome time, beng very generous to her in all repects:
But as all things are ubject to change, o it happen'd here; for our General being order'd to march into the Field, he was oon forc'd to quitt his Mitres; There it was that he provided a Husband for her, having found out a certain Gentleman of his Acquaintance, who was willing to wear that Coat of Arms, which the Marhal had prepar'd for him, provided he wou'd encourage him with his Favour.

Madam de la Garenne his Kinwoman, who not having had the opportunity to peak to him before his departure, and therefore had writ everal mart Letters to him, was overjoy'd at this Match, but poor Janneton, as I am to believe, was of a quite contrary Opinion, who now was to be made enible that the Promies of Lovers are as wavering as the Billows of the Sea. It is to be known that the Marhal in the height of his Paion, had promis'd to marry her, and to confirme it the more, had ign'd this Engagement with his own Blood: I have alo been credibly inform'd that when he was upon concluding the intended March in the Camp, he rode Pot from thence to Paris, where having found out his Mitres at her Lodgings, my Dearet, aid he, let me ee the Contract which I ign'd, I am come on purpoe to alter ome particulars in it, which are not done as they ought to have been;
He had no ooner poke thee Words and having receiv'd the Paper from her Hands, who took him upon his Honour, but he tore it in a thouand peices; Mademoielle de la Fleur being horribly urpris'd at thee Proceedings, ask'd him all overwhelm'd with Grief and Tears, what was the reaon of his o doing? Only for that reaon which I told you before, my Dearet, aid he, giving her a Kis; and finding her to take the matter o much to Heart, the better to cover his deign, he put the point of his naked Sword to his Breat, feigning a Reolution to kill himelf, tho' he had not the leat thought of it: The poor illy Gentlewoman, who doted upon him, natch'd his Sword from him, declaring that he wou'd rely upon his Word, which oon after was tranmuted into that Marriage we poke of before.

Some Years after, which was A. D. 1683. His mot Chritian Majety upon ome Complaints receiv'd of everal Hotilities committed by the Spaniards againt his Subjects, order'd the Marhal de Humieres to beiege Courtray, where alo were preent the Princes de Conti and De la Roche ur yon, the Count de Vermandois Admiral of France, and everal other Perons of Quality: I have not been able to learn whether the Marhal de Boufflers at his return into the Dominions of his
mot Catholick Majety, was for making another Conquet among the Spanih Lady's, who are only charming to the Eye. We will let this Year pas by in ilence, and proceed to the next, when the Spaniards by everal Acts of Hotility forc'd the French to a total rupture with Spain: But Monieur de Boufflers oon made 'em enible of their Error by ravaging thro' all the Villages between the Fort of St. Margreat and the City of Mons, where having epy'd a certain Gentlewoman, the Widow of a Dutch Officer, who had been kill'd in a late Engagement; he alone was able to move him with Compaion.

This Lady was wont to go every Morning and Evening to viit the Place where her Husband was bury'd, which he bedew'd very frequently with her Tears. The Marhal, who had taken ome liking to her before, going one Morning the Rounds according to his uual Cutom every Day, found her at her Husband's Grave, at three a Clock in the Morning, and ask'd her whether he had een that Ghot he look'd for. Alas! no Sir, aid he, my dearly Belov'd has not as yet appear'd to me, but I very impatiently deire to ee him. Sure Madam, reply'd the General, you cannot be o imple as to expect the Dead to come back into this World; and tho' it be the
general Opinion, for my part I cannot believe it: Wherefore young Lady, I wou'd not have you thus betow your time in running after a hadow, which has nothing Solid in it: I wou'd have you look after the Living; you ought much rather to conider of one who may be able to comfort you for your los. The Lady not diliking the Marhal's Propoal, began to hearken to his dicoure, and Sir, aid he very briskly, do you know one that is willing to upply the Vacant place? Yes, aid Monieur Boufflers, (who meant otherwie than he) I know a certain Cavalier, who perhaps may give you more atisfaction than he, whoe los you o much bewail.

Madam Backenbroodt, (this was the Name of the Lady) having oon undertood the Marhal's meaning gave him no anwer, at all, either out out of Modety or Fear, the latter being a common infirmity among Women of that Country. Boufflers, who at firt ight judg'd very right of her natural dipoition, did in very obliging Terms ask her where he Lodg'd, which he told him. The Marhal who is never backward in paying his viits to Lady's for whom he has ome kindnes, went to ee her, and repreented to her his Paion o incerely, that he receiv'd his Addrees without much reluctancy, believing
that he had now got another Husband; but poor Creature he was not well enough acquainted with the French Fahion. They continu'd their amourous Commerce thus for ome time, till one Evening, when the Marhal being in a very good Humour, after having drunk plentifully with ome of the Generals in their Tents, was reolv'd to have ome relih as well of the weets of Venus, as he had had of thoe of Bacchus.

In order to proecute his Deign, he went to viit Madam Backenbroodt, who receiv'd him very Courteouly, and after ome little time pent in amourous Protetations and paionate Expreions, he at lat begg'd of her the utmot Favour. The Gentlewoman (according to the practice of a great many Women of that Country, who think they have made a fair tep towards Marriage, if they refue not to betow every thing upon their Lovers) made no great reitance, but upon that Condition, granted him all what he deir'd This was enough to put our General out of Conceit with his Amour, he not being in the humour to Marry at that time But to come to the Concluion of the matter, he found no great atisfaction in the enjoyment of this Stranger; for tho' after he had done this gallant Exploit, he continu'd to pay her ome few viits out of Compliance
and in acknowledgment of the favour receiv'd, yet they did not turn to that account which the Lady did propoe to her elf: he wou'd ometimes upbraid him with his indifferency, but he excus'd himelf as well as he cou'd, laying all the fault upon his Military Employments, which as he aid, took up o much of his time that he had not leiure to ee his Friends. No other Lady beides her, wou'd have been o eaily atisfy'd with thee Reaons, but as good luck wou'd have it for her, he had been engag'd with a Peron who eldom leaves any Proofs of his Love behind him, o that in conideration of that, he had the more reaon to comfort her elf for the los.

Monieur de Boufflers went oon after to be preent at the Siege of Luxemberg, which was undertaken in the ame Year; the Marhal de Crequi who commanded that Army in chief, having inveted it in the Month of April, A. D. 1684. Here the Marhal again ignalis'd himelf by his Valour, as well as the Counts du Pleis and St. Geron, as did alo a great many other brave Captains, who gave very remarkable Proofs of their undaunted Courage, nevertheles a great number of excellent Officers were lot during that Siege; among whom was the Marques de Humieres, Colonel of a Regiment of Foot,
only Son to the Marhal de Humieres, who was kill'd at the very beginning, in a Sally made by the Beieged. The Marhal de Boufflers was o griev'd at the Death of his Friend, whom he always lov'd extremely, that he carce cou'd enjoy himelf all the remainder of that Year. He wou'd needs put himelf in Mourning Apparel, which prov'd a means to ininuate himelf into the Favour of his deceaed Friend's Father, who was in great eteem at Court.

Winter drawing near, ome of the Officers repair'd to their repective Garrions, the ret to Paris or ome other Prices. I cannot ay any thing here to our Marhal's amourous Adventures, for ome time after, becaue I know that he then made a reolution to take ome ret, and intead of puruing the ports of Venus, to apply himelf entirely to the Art of War, and the tudy of ome other Sciences, for two or three Years; during which time, he became uch a Proficient in every one of 'em, that he attain'd to the highet perfections, urpaing even his Maters, epecially in the Mathematicks, to which his Genius was naturally inclin'd. The King having made him oon after, a Knight of the Order of the Holy-Ghot, he was all of a udden inpir'd with o much Devotion, that he went every day
to Mas, and to hear Sermons, of which he never mis'd one. He was wont alo frequently at that time, to pay his viits to the Jeuits in the Profeed Houe of Paris, who by that means became his particular Friends, and they prevail'd with him to make a Vow to St. Amable, who is in great eteem in the City of Rion in Auvergne, both for his antiquity, and the great number of miracles which he is aid to have wrought. This Saint is to be een in the great Church of that City, and it is reported of him, that if any one does but touch, (with a true faith) a certain great Tooth which he has, it ecures him from ever dying of his Wounds receiv'd in the Wars, or otherwie, as well as from any others, got by the biting of mad Dogs or Venomous Beat.

The Reader may eaily judge from thence, that the Marhal had rais'd his mind to the highet pitch of Devotion, and ome began to be of Opinion, that he was in a fair way of turning an abolute Bigot, if Love, which is not a fit Companion for uch ort of People, and which had always the chief Acendant over his Heart, had not quickly made him change his Inclination, and oblig'd him to re-aume his former Liberty. Let us now ee him go to the Battel of Fleurus, which happen'd in the Year 1690 in the Month of June,
under the Command of the Duke of Luxemburg, who. was then General over the King's Forces in Flanders. No ooner were the Enemies beaten out of the Field, but Monieur Boufflers, who had had an ample hare in the Victory, took his ret in the Arms of a new Mitres, who poes'd all his thoughts for ome time. This was one Mrs. Montberg the Daughter of a certain Flemmih Officer, who had been kill'd in the ame Battel. It mut be aid to her advantage, that never was een a more beautiful Woman of a brown Complexion in the World, and who had a more gracefull haughtines in her whole Behaviour than he; and it was not without a great deal of trouble that the Marhal cou'd find an opportunity to addres his Courthip to her. The los of her Father, who was one of the bet Officers the Allies had in the whole Army, had afflicted her to that degree that he refus'd to admit of any Conolation, having by his Death been bereav'd of all, what he cou'd call her own, as having no other Subitance but what depended abolutely upon her Father's Fortune.

Monieur de Boufflers having been inform'd concerning her preent Condition by one of her Acquaintance, according to his generous inclination, which extended it elf more particularly towards the fair Sex, offer'd
her his Pure. It was not without great reluctancy that he accepted the offer of a Man, whom he upected did not make his Preents for nothing; and the truth is, why hou'd any Man, hew o much kindnes toward a Woman, unles with a propect of receiving ome favours? They ought not to take the Liberality of their Gallants in any other ene, becaue they very often pay dearly for 'em. Our Marhal has often found it o, by his own experience, and to his Cot. But let us return to Mrs. Montberg, who by her paionate and Engaging Air had o Captivated the Heart of our General, that he has proteted to me ince, that he never was o much in Love in all his Life-time before; he appear'd to him o full of charms and weetnes in her whole Deportment; beides her Beauty, which tho' it was always extraordinary, yet appear'd at certain times with uch a lutre, that it quite dazzl'd his Reaon; o that in a little time he turn'd tark Fool, and her perfect Idolater, as he one day, when he lay at her Feet, was pleas'd to tell her himelf.

p.q:
You then Love me indeed, my dear Boufflers, aid he very pleaantly. Yes my incomparable, reply'd the Marhal embracing her, but I intend to dicount with your Heart for all the ufferings it makes me
endure. You have Complaiance enough to make me a return of ome mall Favours, but you will not grant me‚ÄîWhat is it you wou'd have me grant you, my dearly Belov'd, anwer'd the young Lady laughing, and interrupting his dicoure, If I had in my gift the mot eminent Offices in the State, or any thing ele that is worth your acceptance; nay, if it lay in my power, continu'd he with a charming Air, to put a Crown upon your Head, I protet to you, that you hou'd not tay for it till to morrow. The weight of that Madam, reply'd the Marhal modetly, wou'd be too heavy and troubleome for me. It is in your power to make me, a Preent no les precious than that: That agreeable Throne environ'd with Purple, the weetet eat of Love, added he all tranported with Paion, is that to which my Ambition leads me. This is that Soveraignty which is in your poeion, and which if you will put into my Hands, I'll make you my Queen, and all my deires hall center in you: My Scepter hall only be touch'd by your fair Hands, and you alone hall have the whole way and management of all the Affairs of State.

div.p:
Mrs. Montberg cou'd not forbear laughing out as loud as he cou'd, at the ingenious
interpretation which her Lover had made of her Words, to whom he anwer'd with a mile; Sir it is a Talent peculiar only to the French Gentle men to expres themelves in o extraordinary a manner; other Nations cannot pretend to that ubtilty of Wit. And pray Madam, reply'd the Marhal with a great deal of feigned incerity, what great Subtilty can there be in Expreing things naturally as they are. Is there any thing more common among Men than to endeavour to be happy? And as it is in your power my Divine Creature, to make me the mot Fortunate of all Mortals; I come here to embrace your Feet, and to pray you not to delay any longer my Happines. There is another Thought, reply'd the young Lady, no les witty and pleaant than the former, I cou'd wih my elf now a larger hare of Wit than I have, that I might have the atisfaction of giving you a uitable return to thee excellent Expreions. Madam, anwer'd the Marhal, you'll certainly make me a uitable return, when you hall vouchafe to grant my Requet. And what is it then Sir, reply'd the Lady abruptly, that you deire, for that I ee, you are not very eaily atisfy'd. Yes my lovely Creature, pretty eaily, aid the Marhal kiing her fair Hands, you are not ignorant what it is that will content
me. I don't know, reply'd Mrs. Montberg with a bluh all over her Cheeks, you Cavaliers have a very nice tate and‚Äî here he topt, which made her Lover pres her very earnetly to proceed in her Dicoure, and to let him know his doom, how long he was to live in this languihing Condition, before he wou'd let him enjoy thoe trancendent Delights which he o earnetly long'd for.

The Lady having for a coniderable time in mot obliging Terms oppos'd his amourous ininuations, was at lat contrained to tell him in a languihing tone, that as oon as that piece of Work, which he hew'd him, was compleated he wou'd do what he cou'd do to make him les unfortunate. Then make hate my Dearet, cry'd the Marhal queezing her cloely between his Arms, give me one half of it to finih. The young Lady taking him at his word, gave him the hinder part of a Cornet of Point la Reine which he had begun to work upon, No, No, anwer'd the General miling, and feigning as if he were about to throw it away I mut have the fore part, there I can work to ome purpoe. Well, well, Sir, reply'd he as pleaantly, you hall have it, when I have gone on a little further with it, then you hall have it to finih. Madam, reply'd Boufflers, I believe I hall do more work there with my Needle in one moment, than all
your Work-women can in a very coniderable pace of time: I am very expeditions in all my buines, but epecially in the ervice of the fair Sex. Well, well, Sir, ince you are uch a nimble Work man, reply'd the young Lady, giving him a Needle and Thread, and all the other Implements belonging to the Work, take notice that you are to have nothing for your pains before it be quite finih'd; and likewie that you are to have no pay till mine be brought to perfection as well as yours: Thus having kept the hinder part of the Cornet to work upon herelf, he gave the fore part to the General according to his deire, which he got finih'd in eight days.

But the Lady, who was reolv'd to let him languih for ome time longer, was o malicious as to unrip at night (as formerly Penelope did) what he had done by Day; o that when our Marhal thought himelf almot ure of his pay, according to her promie, he was as far off as ever. O Cruel Detiny! O unaccountable Fatality! cry'd he one day protrating himelf at her Feet; Alas! when I think that I am arriv'd at the very Goal of Felicity, I find my elf at the greatet ditance from it. He had carce utter'd thee words but a palenes overpreading his Face, he fell into a Swoon. Mrs. Montberg being tartl'd at the uddennes of the thing threw cold Water in his Face, which proving frutles, he rub'd his Hands and Temples
with the Queen of Sweden's Balam, which is accounted mot powerful againt uch Love-Fits. But neither was all this efficacious enough to cure him of his Ditemper, he wanted another ort of Remedy to be apply'd to him, which Lovers term in their Language, the extreme Unction of Love, or the charming Viaticum, which makes 'em dye the mot pleaant Death that can be.

Our fair Lady, who did not know which way to turn her elf, having no body to ait her, at lat reolv'd to unbutton his Coat and Wate-coat, and to lay her Hand upon his Stomach, which felt omewhat cold; and having back'd her tender Carees with a douzen or more hearty and weet Kies, thee had the wih'd for effect, having oon awaken'd our General out of his Love-trance, o that now he began to open his Eyes, which were half hut before. Then you are return'd from the other World, cry'd his Mitres, looking in his Face, if you were enible how you have frighted me, you wou'd have prevented your Swooning thus: I did verily believe that you were gone to the Elyian Fields, but I now perceive your Hour was not yet come. Alas! my fair Angel, reply'd the Marhal with a very deep igh, I am jut ready to expire at your Feet, except you take pity of me. While he was peaking thee lat Words, he drew out a Knife all Bloody, which he had put in his Pocket on purpoe, feigning that he
was about to thrut it into his Heart. The Lady having natch'd the Knife out of his Hands, and perceiving it all Bloody, was o extremely terrify'd at the ight of it, that he actually fell into a Swoon, out of which he did not recover till ome coniderable time after; he turn'd as pale as Death, not having the leat ene left her, o that the Marhal, who was only in jet, had now made work enough for himelf in good earnet. Having firt try'd all poible means to recover her, which prov'd ineffectual, he was forc'd to call for aitance, and while they were coming, he did not let lip the opportunity of taking more freedome than her haughty temper wou'd have let him o much as ue for, at another time.

The Lady having been oblig'd to keep her Bed for ome time, by reaon of the weaknes it caus'd in her, enquir'd after her Gallant, who being come, he entertain'd him with the mot tender Expreions in the World: He who had now the Opportunity to rove about his Mitrees Boom, to play with her two lovely plump Bubbies, and whiter than the very Snow, and to advance even as far as to the little Mount of Venus, where Love keeps its Throne, did anwer to her obliging Expreions in o Paionate a manner; that hou'd any one have been an Eye-witnes to 'em,
they wou'd have believ'd him bewitch'd or turn'd Fool; and this was as I take it, the occaion of a rumour then pread all about Paris, that the Marhal de Boufflers, after the Battel of Fleurus, was o deperately fall'n in Love with a certain young Lady in Brabant, that he was quite Ditracted; 'Tis probable that the General in one of his amourous Tranports, had been the Occaion of having this jet put upon him, it being then the common dicoure of the Town.

But to return to our charming young Lady, who being now recover'd pretty well from her ilnes, did receive every day more evident Proofs of the Marhal's Love. One Afternoon having been oblig'd to leave her ooner than ordinary, becaue he was to ait at a Council of War, he was o ditracted in his Mind, that when the Duke of Luxemburg ask'd his Advice concerning the buines in hand; he anwer'd him as if he had not been in his right Wits, at which the Duke having laugh'd heartily, Sir, aid he, ure your Thoughts are o taken up with ome Amourous Intreague, that it diturbs your Brains. By my Faith Sir, reply'd the Marhal de Boufflers, being much aham'd that they had dicover'd his Ditraction, and taking the Duke by the Hand, you peak truth, I am in Love with the mot amiable Peron in the VVorld, who has robb'd me of my Liberty. And who for God's ake, reply'd the Duke of
Luxemburg, is this fair Lady, miling. It is,‚ÄîIt is‚ÄîIt is‚Äîaid Monieur de Boufflers jeting, it is one Mitres Pretty Mount, ome Spies coming into the Tent at the ame time, broke off their further dicoure.

The next day, the Marhal de Luxemburg, and ome other Officers came to give him a Viit in his Tent, where they began to jeer him about his new Mitres, whoe true Name he was unwilling to declare to 'em. But Monieur de Luxemburg told 'em, Let me alone Gentlemen, I'll engage that to Morrow you hall ee that Beauty, whoe Name you are o deirous to know. And he was as good as his word, for I know not by what ort of Magick, Mrs. Montberg appear'd there, asking for the Marhal de Boufflers. The dres he was in that day, made no mall addition to the lutre of her Beauty, o that all the Generals were as much dazzl'd at the ight of her, as if he had been an Angel. This poor young Lady being incited by omething he knew not what, to go and eek after her Gallant; at the ight of the Company, bluh'd for hame; which having rais'd her Colour to its utmot perfection, it was o great an addition to her natural Complexion, that they were all trangely urpris'd at it. The Marhal de Boufflers being not inenible of the Confuion he was in, and much vex'd
that he hou'd have committed uch a fault, told her, as he was Conducting her home; VVhat was it my Dearet, that cou'd induce you to come and enquire for me in this crow'd? They are a Company of unlucky Birds, that always make it their buines to banter me, about thoe little Favours you are pleas'd to betow upon me.

For GOD'S ake Sir, reply'd Mrs. Montberg, being vex'd to the very Soul, talk no more of this fatal moment. Some unknown evil Spirit did hurrye me on; I fany'd that ome Ghot or another did drive me to the place where you were, and I cannot devie what hou'd be the Original caue of this Inchantment; I may very well call it o, for I am ure I was forc'd to act contrary to my own Inclination. Good God! aid he, hedding ome Tears, that I hou'd go after a Man, and epecially in that place where you were. Certainly I cou'd never be guilty of uch indicretion if I might gain the VVorld by the Bargain, and tho' I love you very affectionately, yet my Paion cou'd never have made me commit o irreparable, a fault. Now I think on't, there was the Duke of Luxemburg in your Company, who has the name of being the greatet Sorcerer in the VVorld, hou'd it not perhaps be that old Necromancer, who has play'd you this Game, on purpoe to divert his Friends. Boufflers having ruminated for ome time upon what his Mitres had aid, and being convinc'd that he had hit the Nail upon the
Head, the Duke being taken for uch a one, throughout the whole Army; did not think it convenient to put her any further into a fright; on the contrary, he endeavour'd to reettle her Mind, which was quite dicompos'd by this unlucky Accident.

I am apt to believe my Child, continu'd the Marhal Careing her, what you did was only out of an ardent deire to ee me. No indeed my Dear, reply'd he miling, I told you before, that my Paion hou'd never be capable of carrying me o much out of the way of my Duty. If you are an Admirer of Secrecy in Love-concerns, o am I in no les a degree. What in the name of God, will thee Gentlemen be apt to ay about my enquiring after you with o much earnetnes? Let 'em ay what they pleae, reply'd Boufflers much vex'd, one thing is, they don't know you. But for that reaon I wou'd not have you do o again another time. Oh! great God! cry'd the young Lady much diturb'd, I wih rather that I may dye the mot cruel Death that can be invented, than to commit a econd time uch an horrible Fault; for God's ake, don't tell me any more of this fatal Accident, or I mut leave you.

The Marhal perceiving the great diturbance his Mitres was in, chang'd his dicoure into a Thouand amourous Protetations, and having again aur'd her of the Vehemency of his Paion, he left her and return'd to his Company. O brave
Boufflers, aid they laughing, thou art the happiet Man living, to enjoy o charming an object as this. I never aw, added Luxemburg, o Beautiful and engaging a Creature in my Life-time, and who deerves better to be ador'd by Men. The Marhal de Boufflers made no anwer to what they aid, on the contrary, he appear'd very Penive and Melancholy; his Thoughts being wholly taken up with this piteful trick of that old Devil the Duke of Luxemburg, unto whom he had hitherto bid defiance with all his Works. This General was o overjoy'd at the Victory obtain'd in the Plains of Fleurus, againt the Prince of Waldeck, General of the Conederate Army, who had been forc'd to quit the Field of Battel; that he play'd a great many of thee tricks, which were urpriing to all that aw 'em; but they not having any relation to our preent Subject, I will pas 'em by in ilence: I hall only mention this by the by, that he was o confident of his ARt, that he attempted to retore to Life ome of the chief Officers, who were Slain in the Battel, and among the ret the Marques de Verderonne, whom he lov'd as dearly as his own Soul; but all his Magick was not powerful enough to reach o far, Almighty God having reerv'd to himelf that power of raiing the Dead.

But it is time to return to our Marhal,
who being extremely afraid let the old Duke hou'd play him ome other Game about his Mitres, was fain to carry matters very wimmingly with him; which the Duke having taken notice of, told him one Day, That he was enible that he tood in awe of him, but that he needed fear nothing farther; for he was ready to give him his parole of Honour, that he wou'd never be an Obtacle to his Amours, or engage in any thing ele, which he thought might be troubleome to him. The Marhal de Boufflers being very well atisfy'd with thee aurances receiv'd from the Duke, afterward pay'd his Viits to his Mitres, without any diturbance, in the ame manner as he had done before.

But as all Human Affairs are Subject to perpetual change, o things did not remain between thee two Lovers long in the ame Station. Winter began to approach and Bou. cou'd no more than the ret of the Generals, avoid going to Paris; being therefore oblig'd to part from his dearly Beloved Mrs. Montberg, he took his leave of her with the greatet marks of grief imagnable; he wou'd fain have perwaded her to have pas'd five or ix months away in Paris, but he wou'd by no means conent to it, pretending that he was oblig'd to viit that Winter, an Aunt of hers at Bruels, who was very deirous to ee her. Our Lover was o enibly afflicted at his approaching Separation, from
a Peron whom he lov'd with o much Paion, that he fell Sick; but being by the care and aiudous Viits of his belov'd Mitres, oon retor'd to Health, he cou'd not think of parting o oon; it being a common Principle among Lovers, who Paionately Love one another, not to be able to endure a long Separation: But alas! within a few Weeks after, this young Lady, who had given uch extraordinary Proofs of her Love to our General, fell Sick of a violent Feaver, of which he dy'd not long after. Never did any Man hew o much concern for a Mitres, as the Marhal de Boufflers: He did not tir from her one moment, and tho' her Ditemper was not without ome infection, nevertheles, as if he had been chain'd to her Bed-ide, he was continually giving her what Comfort he cou'd, and taking care that he took every thing exactly, according to the precription of two or three Phyicians, who came to Viit her every day: Finding her at lat, pas'd all hopes of recovery, he had o much influence over her, that he prevail'd with her o far as to renounce the Protetant Religion, and to embrace the Roman Catholick; when he was jut ready to expire in his Arms, recommending her Body to his dipoal after Death. But the Marhal, who was unwilling to take upon himelf a charge of that Nature, gave orders to the Ghotly Fathers
who attended upon her, to take care that her Funeral Rites hou'd be decently Solemnis'd as oon as her Friends cou'd be preent. In the meanwhile, not being able to ee the Interrment of a Peron whom he had o dearly lov'd: He et forward on his Journey the very next Morning early: The only thing he ask'd for, before his departure, from a Jacobine Father, whom he had entruted with all her Moveables, was a little Picture of her's, enamell'd very finely, which he did not part with, for a long time after.

Upon his arrival at Paris, every one was for putting hard upon the Marhal, with repect to his late Gallant Adventures, but he not being of a humour to be much diturb'd at a Jet, was forc'd to join iue with 'em in their Raillery; o that finding him inenible as to that point, they quickly grew weary of the Sport. He wore for ome time, a econd Mourning Suit, very neatly trimm'd in remembrance of his Mitres, which purchas'd him the Favour of all the fine Lady's at Court, who were extreme'y well atisfy'd to ee him hew o much eteem to the Memory of one of their Sex. For a coniderable time after, if Madam de Maintenon, and Madam de Guie did but mention her, he wou'd igh and burt out into Tears like a Child; o that 'twas not without great perwaions that at lat they made him top
the Current of his Tears. The Winter pas'd thus without any further diturbance on the Marhal's ide, his Heart till keeping the impreion of his late belov'd Mitres, as omething precious, and not to be rac'd out in o mall a pace of time: For tho' there were everal Lady's of Quality in Paris, who endeavour'd to make him wear their Chains, yet he o vigourouly oppos'd their Deigns, that he gain'd the Victory over thoe, who wou'd willingly have conquer'd him, to make him their humble Adorer.

At the beginning of the next Spring, his mot Chritian Majety having given Orders to his Generals for the beieging of Mons; the Capital City of the Province of Hainault: And being to go thither in Peron, mot of the Nobility at Court were to follow him: The Marhals and Dukes de Duras, de la Feuillade, de Luxemburg; the Princes de Soubie, and de Conti; the Dukes de Vendome and de Bourbon, the Marquees de Joyeeue, de Villars, and de Boufflers open'd the Campaign before the eaon the Year, was carce fit for Travelling; the mot Lady's of note wou'd not tay behind, but follow'd the Court. Then it was, that the Marhal de Boufflers was enamour'd with the Countes de‚ÄîI hope the Reader will excue me for not mentioning her name, for very weighty Reaons: This Lady having hew'd o much aiduity in her Love engagements
with the Marhal, that ometimes they carce gave themelves leaure to eat or to drink. In the mean time Monieur de Buofflers, whom nothing ever was able to withdraw from his Prince's ervice, was oblig'd to go where Honour call'd him; he hunned neither Dangers nor Fatigues, to ignalie himelf upon all occaions, where Glory was to be purchas'd at the expence of his Blood. It was in one of thoe Engagements which was fought with a great deal of obtinacy on both ides, that he was Wounded with a Muquet-Ball in his Thigh, as well as the Duke de Montfort, who having ecretly given notice of it to the Countes his Couin, he took it o to Heart, that it eem'd as if he wou'd not have liv'd one Moment longer: But being a little recover'd from her firt urprie, he was for revenging (with Sword in Hand) her Gallant's Quarrel; and as he was as dextrous at handling a Pitol and Sword, as one of the bet Officers; he diguis'd her elf in the Habit of an Officer, to come and viit the Marhal in his Tent: She was there three or four Days, before he had the leat Supicion of it, imagining that it was ome young Officer, who upon this Occaion, was willing to purchae his Favour by his Services

One Day, our General's Wound being in pretty good Condition, he took a reolution to write two or three Lines to his new Mitres,
whom he uppos'd to be at her own Lodgings near Mons, with the ret of the Lady's of her Acquaintance: When he had writ the Billet doux, he cat his Eyes upon that young Officer, who had been o ready about him, to carry it to this fair Lady: While he was writing, he cou'd not forbear to look upon him from time to time, peaking with himelf: Can any thing be more like my Countes than this young Gentleman? He has the ame charming Eyes, the ame Features, and the very ame Beautiful Complexion. Having made thee Reflections to himelf, he ask'd him, whether he knew Madam de‚Äî. Yes, reply'd the Countes, who was o well diguis'd as not to be known by any one. I know her as well as my elf, and I can aure you in her behalf, that he Loves you as well as her own Life. This Anwer avouring of o much Familiarity, omewhat tartl'd our General, who told him, whom he took to be a Man, and pray Sir, who cou'd tell you this, has he made you her Confident? She has not told me in o plain Terms as I peak Sir, reply'd the Countes, but I might eaily perceive by the trouble which your wound occaion'd in her Mind, that he was as deeply Wounded as your elf; and tho' her wound appears to be but light outwardly, her Heart is nevertheles mot enibly touch'd by a more dangerous Weapon, and‚Äî. Here the Marhal interrupting the young Officer, (according to outward appearance) ince you know, aid
he, the Countes o well, pray deliver to her this Letter, which I give you; and tell her from me, that I mot impatiently deire to ee her.

The Lady, who admir'd her own dexterity in Peronating herelf o well as he did; took the Letter with a great of Repect, to carry it to his Mitres. But he was not gone far from the place, where he had left the Marhal de Boufflers, e'r he retir'd into an adjacent Wood, where having unfolded the Mytery of Love, with which he was entruted; he read thee following Words:
Dear Countes,
IF the rigour of my Detiny keeps me one day longer from your ight, I mut reolve to embrace death, but a death a thouand times more cruel to me, than that which my Wounds cou'd have procur'd to me Heaven has againt my will retor'd me a Life, that I might love you more now than ever before: But alas! how can I be ure whether you Heart continues till the ame as to me? It's poible it has chang'd it's inclinations, and parhaps ome fortunate Rival poees‚ÄîBut oh! I dare not enlarge farther upon that Subject, let the very thoughts of it hou'd Kill me in an intant; I will rather flatter myelf with ome weet hopes, which may prolong my Life at leat for ome time. Don't therefore put me out of your Remembrance, my mot incomparable Queen; conider with your elf, that you have Captivated a Heart which adores and loves you, even to an exces of Paion: When I receiv'd my Wound in the Heat of the Engagement, I than believ'd I hou'd never have een you again; but ince I begin to grow better, and that I am likely to tay ome time longer in this
World, on purpoe to erve my Prince and you, I will employ the precious remainder of my days, in making you enible of the incerity of my Affection. Farewell, my incomparable, and believe that my Love is far urpaing what can be conceiv'd in that kind, by any Mortal. I remain if I live till to Morrow;
The mot tender and Affectionate of all your Lovers.

After the Countes had read this Letter, which was altogether agreeable to her wihes; Is it poible, aid he to her elf, that thou my Dearet houd't not know me? It is four or five days, ince I have been with thee in the ame Tent; and does not thy Heart tell thee, that it is he that Loves thee? Alas! I have a great deal of Compaion for thee, and I attribute this want of knowing me, wholly to thy Ditemper, which appears to me very violent, altho' it eems as if thou woud't ininuate the contrary. And notwithtanding all the pains thou enduret, thou till keepet me in Remembrance; nay, thy Remembrance is founded upon incerity, I am my elf an Eye-witnes of this ecret, which nevertheles, thou hat put into the Hands of an unknown Peron. Thy Integrity and eager deire of hearing news from me, have made thee hazard all; but dot thou not O Soveraign King of my Heart, conider unto what dangers thou hat expos'd me, and that if my Husband hou'd dicover the leat of this Paion, that I have for thee, I am infallibly
undone: Thou know't that he abominates Horns, and that nothing in the World cou'd touch him o enibly, as to find himelf a Cuckold, and epecially to be o dignify'd by the means of uch a one as thee, whoe ingular merits and charms he ought mot to dread.

The Countes was making thee and uch like other Reflections, when the Marhal, who had taken a walk into the Wood for alittle Air, and being come by chance near the place where he had eated herelf, undertood ome part of what he had aid. Never was any agreeable Surprie greater than this, he having immediately known her Voice, which was then without diguie. Having embrac'd her everal times, Is it you aid he, is it you my adorable Angel? Unto what dangers do you expoe your elf for my ake? Alas! I am at preent in an unpeakable pain for you. You ee my Dearet, reply'd he with a languihing tone, what one is willing to do to enjoy the ight of an Object one Loves, and how a genuine Paion triumphs over all the mot frightful Obtacles. I have hazarded all to ee you, and I have Sacrifis'd even my Honour for your ake: I am ready to own it Madam, aid the General kiing one of her pretty Hands, which he had given him without a Glove; And I protet to you, that I at the ame time acknowledge my elf unworthy of thee Favours you betow upon me. I Will endeavour to give you the mot enible and livevely
Marks of my Gratitude. Some Officers, who were at the ame time walking in the Wood, and knew Monieur de Boufflers, coming up towards 'em, broke off the Intercoure of our Lovers for that Time. The Countes, who was afraid of being dicover'd, made the bet of her way to her own Lodgings, being well atisfy'd that he had een and poke to her Gallant, who was not long without repaying her Viit. When this Lady went firt from her Lodgings, he told her Gentlewomen and the ret of her Dometick Servants, That he was going to ee one of her Acquaintance, who was in a Monatery near Mons; which was the Reaon, that during her Stay with our General, which was about Five or ix Days, they were not diturb'd at her Abence. She had made one of her Waiting Gentlewomen, whoe Name was Gvion, and one whom he had a more particular Repect for than all the ret, her Confident in the Buines; he waited upon her in one Corner of the Wood, with her Woman's Apparel, which he had there chang'd for the Man's Cloaths he had worn before. Thus our Heroine Lady return'd Home to her Lodgings, accompany'd only by this Damel, leaning upon her Arm as if he had been the mot harmles Creature in the World, and as if, during her Stay, he had employ'd her Time in nothing ele but praying
with thoe Religious Siters for the Preervation of her Husband, from the imminent Dangers of War.

The Marhal de Boufflers, after he had got clear from the other Officers that met him in the Wood, pent all that Night under mot terrible Agonies, not knowing what was become of his Mitres, whom he had earch'd for all over the Foret; but no ooner did the next Morning appear, but to eae himelf of the Trouble which ditracted his Mind, he mounted on Hore-back, teering his Coure directly to the Place where he knew his Beloved lodg'd all that Time. He found his lovely Countes as yet in Bed, who having receiv'd him with incredible Joy, and clos'd him between her Arms, told him a thouand paionate things, in Terms o engaging and charming, that they are pat all Expreion, except by him who had the good Fortune to be made enible of 'em. Nothing cou'd appear more Charming than he did, as he lay in Bed: A careles Head-dres, ty'd behind with a Carnation Ribbon, in the nature of a ingle Top-knot, together with a weet engaging Air, which was natural to her, made her appear the mot lovely Woman in the Univere. The Marhal having now met with a favourable Opportunity to enjoy the happy Minute, told Guion, who had introduc'd him that Morning to
the Countes, Mademoielle, Let me be with your Lady for two or three Hours in private, becaue I have ome Matters of Moment to impart to her. This young Damel, who very well undertood his Meaning, ask'd her Mitres, Whether he wou'd have her withdraw? Yes, aid the Lady, and if any hou'd come to enquire for me this Morning, tell 'em, That I am indipos'd and not to be poke with at preent.

The Young Woman, having receiv'd her Lady's Orders, left the Room, and our Marhal finding himelf now at liberty, threw himelf upon the Bed, by his fair Lady, kiing and embracing her without Intermiion; and finding nothing that was likely to obtruct his Paage, if he advanc'd farther, he, in very paionate Terms, begg'd of her, to grant him the lat Favour. Alas! cry'd he, half vanquih'd, and entangl'd in his Embraces, Who can deny you any thing, my Dear? Alas! I am ready to faint, pray pity my Weaknes! Oh! what ravihing joys, my Soul, my Soveraign! The Marhal, now in the midt of his Enjoyments, thought himelf the happiet Man in the World, and keeping her till in his Arms, proteted to her with a great many Oaths, That he never in all his Life-time had receiv'd o much Satisfaction as with her. He deir'd her, after having by a thouand Oaths aur'd her of his Fidelity, and that he
wou'd love her for ever, To keep their Intriegue ecret, and to let no Body in the World know of it, let that if the Count de‚Äîhould get the least cent of it, it might prove of dangerous conequence both to her and himelf, who cou'd not uffer her to be mius'd by a Jealous Husband. The Countes told him, with a Kis, That he needed not in the least fear her; that he did not admire Confidents in Love,; that he was o tender as to this Point, that he carce truted her own Heart, lest it hould betray her.

Thee Aurances were ign'd by both Parties everal times over, and the poor Countes, who was of a very tender Contitution, eal'd 'em with ome Drops of her Blood, in hopes that their mutual Promies hou'd outlat their Lives.

The Marhal, now more contented than a Prince, left his Beloved in Bed, having reiterated his Promie, to come and ee her often. But before a few Days were pas'd, the King being diatisfy'd with the Inhabitants of Liege, who had by ome Acts of Hotility incurr'd his utmot Dipleaure, order'd, That ome Batteries hould be rais'd againt that City, and the whole Management of this Affair being left to the Conduct of the Marhal de Boufflers, he prepar'd himelf to put his Orders in execution againt Whitontide. Our General having therefore taken Leave of his Countes, and repeated his
former Aurances of an everlating Love, Bombarded the City of Liege for Two or three Days, cauing a great Conternation among the Inhabitants, very many of whom were ruin'd by it. But, while he was taken up in this Expedition, the Count‚Äîcarry'd his Lady back to Paris, and tho' he hew'd her all the Complaiance imaginable, yet he, who cou'd not think upon, nor be pleas'd with any thing but her Gallant, receiv'd all her Husband's Carees very coldly. The Count, who was not inenible of her Indifferency, and lov'd her extremely, was ready to dye with Vexation, not imagining that he cou'd love any one but himelf, after he had o much advanc'd her Fortune; he having marry'd her not for her Portion or extraordinary Quality, but merely for her Beauty; he being, by Birth, the Daughter only of a Private Gentleman in Poictou.

But, to return to our Lady, who never having had any great Love for her Husband, was eaily comforted for his Death, which happen'd oon after; pleaing her elf with a Fancy, That the Marhal de Boufflers wou'd marry her, conformably to thoe paionate Protetations he had often made to her: But he was much deceiv'd in her Aim; for having notify'd to him the Death of her Husband, in uch Terms as were convincing enough to the Marhal, That he lov'd him
ufficiently to invet him with the ame Quality; he turn'd the whole into Raillery, and anwer'd her in Terms full of Equivocations; which mot enibly afflicted her: And the Marhal, who after the Campaign was ended, return'd to Paris, told her with his own Mouth, That he cou'd not as yet reolve to Marry; but that this hou'd not hinder him from loving her as well as if he were his Wife, and more; for, aid he, Marriage often upprees the vehemency of Love, and ometimes quite extinguihes its Flame. But thee Reaons were not cogent enough to make her lay aide the Thoughts he had of Marrying him. On the contrary, he conceiv'd uch an Averion toward him, perceiving her elf thus depis'd, after he had done o much for him, that Hatred ucceeded in her Heart intead of Love, to that degree, that he refus'd to ee him; nay, he wou'd not o much as hear him poke of, as if his very Name were terrible to her: Which vex'd the Marhal to the very Heart, who lov'd her to the highet degree, notwithtanding he cou'd not reolve to make her his Spoue.

One Day, as he was walking in the King's Gardens at Verailles, it being a very fair Day, he epy'd from far his Countes's Coach; and drawing nearer, and finding no Body in it but one of her Footmen, he ask'd him where his Lady was; who having told
him, That he was taking a Turn in one of the Walks of the Gardens, with the Marchiones de lae Mothe, the Marhal, with all poible hate, made up to the Place where his fair Lady was: But being willing to overhear their Dicoure, he hid himelf behind ome Trees, hard by where they were walking, and heard the Countes de‚Äîwho was wiping her Tears away with her Handkerchief, ay thus to the Marchiones: My dearet, let us bury my Misfortune in Oblivion; 'tis pas'd Expreion, when I conider what I have done for that ungrateful Man; the very Thoughts of whom now are frightful to me. This perfidious Wretch has not only given me his Word, but worn a thouand Oaths; That, if the Chance of War hould happen to take off my Husband, I hou'd alone dipoe of his Detiny. But, good God! continu'd he, what is become of all thoe Oaths? He ays he loves me more than ever, and yet refues to keep his Promie.

You are a very good-natur'd Lady indeed, reply'd the Marchiones de la Mothe, laughing, are you to learn yet, that Promies made by Lovers have nothing of Reality in 'em, they being founded upon a Paion which goes as fat as it comes; and conequently all the Oaths they make return to their first Principle; which is next to nothing, being only a Fancy, and what Woman of any Sene would
lay the least tres upon 'em? As for my part, continu'd he, I hou'd make no more of loing a Gallant, than to part with one of my Ribbons. I hope you are not in earnet thus to torment your elf for a Los, which is not worth taking notice of. Come, come, Madam, o beautiful a Lady as you need not want Gallants, if you have a Mind to be troubl'd with 'em. This is not enough, Madam, reply'd the Countes, ighing, but all Men don't pleae us alike. I am enible what a difficult Task it was for me to hew o much Complaiance as I did, to my deceas'd Husband, whom I lov'd but indifferently; and therefore I wou'd fain, if I cou'd, avoid to undergo the ame Trouble. But how ingenious I am at tormenting my elf, cry'd he, looking towards the Place where the Marhal had hid himelf, Let us trive, my Heart, to do Violence to our own Inclination, let us not think any more of the Raviher of our Liberty. Oh Heavens! what do I ee? aid the Lady all on a udden, Is not that this faithles Man, whoe Love hss cost me o many Sighs? The Marchiones perceiving the Marhal coming up towards her, follow'd the Countes, who run with all Speed towards her Coach, and having order'd the Coachman to drive as fat as he cou'd to Paris, he with a didainful Frown drew up the Glas, and away they went.

The Marhal thinking himelf above her Scorn, and being by this time got on Hore-back, rode cloe after the Coach, and having preented one of his Pitols at the Coach-man, Stop, aid he, top you Dog, or ele I'll hoot you thro' the Head. The Poor Fellow, being extremely terrify'd, leapt out of the Coach-box, leaving the Coach to the Marhal's Dipoal; who having put one of his Servants, who had been with him at Boulogne, (a mall Village near Paris,) in his Place, made him top at the next Inn. The Ladies, that hitherto had not een who it was that puru'd 'em, and had made mot lamentable Outcries, all a-long the Road, were much urpris'd when they aw the Marhal de Boufflers; for imagining that it was ome of their Gallants, who intended to carry 'em away, they had not had the Courage till now to lift up their Eyes. At that ame intant, all the Countes's Hatred uddenly vanih'd; he gave her Hand to the Marhal, who led her out of the Coach into one of the bet Appartments of the Houe. The Marchiones perceiving this udden Change in her Friend, did not ay one Word, but pray'd one of the Footmen, who had been all-a-long behind the Coach, to drive her away to Paris, and that he might return immediately afterwards to fetch his Lady.

Thus the Marhal having got his Mitres by himelf, cou'd not forbear laughing at this bold troak he had made, knowing that it had often tood him in good tead before, upon the like Occaions: Well, Madam, aid he, looking upon her tedfatly, you are now in my Power; cou'd you imagine that after we have been o cloely acquainted you might diintangle your elf with o much Eae? Ladies that love Gallantry as well as you do, ought not to carry Matters o haughtily; your manner of Proceeding appears very uneaonable. And, after all, what is it I have done to you? continu'd he, with a omewhat more compos'd Countenance; I have lov'd you very tenderly, and love you till, in pite of all your Scorn. You have propos'd Marriage to me, and you don't know the Reaons why it was not in my Power to comply with your Deires in that particular. You may poibly tell me, That where there is a great deal of Love, Reaon eldom takes Place, but as my Circumtances are at preent, I am oblig'd to conult Reaon, and to tell you, That I cannot Marry at this Time. If you have the least Kindnes for me, you'll eaily perwade your elf, That all that was in my Power to do for you, I have done already.

The Countes was not capable of giving him one Word in anwer, her Speech being topt by a Torrent of Tears, which he
hed: Notwithtanding all thee diadvantages, he till appear'd to the Marhal one of the mot lovely Women in the World, And as he has always a great Tendernes for the fair Sex, o he cou'd not but endeavour to allay her Grief. He threw himelf at her Feet, and embracing 'em, My Angel, my Dearest, aid he, 'tis impoible for me to ee you thus torment your elf, let us pardon one another all thoe Crimes which have made us both culpable. Grant me your Pardon, and I will grant you mine, and freely forgive thoe charming Eyes of yours which have et me all in a Flame, and do you forgive thee tender Expreions, which were the true Interpreters of my Heart; it did not addres it elf to you, mot charming Creature, added he, in a very paionate Tone, before it had conulted yours, which it found o worthy of its Choice and Affection.

The Lady, whom the great Surprie he was in, had kept ilent till now, was not able to hold out any longer againt the Power of uch Charms and tender Carees of a Lover, who was belov'd by her, but was forc'd to yield, in pite of all her Indifferency, which he had hewn to him in outward Appearance. 'Tis in vain, my Dear, reply'd he at lat, that I endeavour to hate thee; thou know'st how to diarm me by thy most engaging Charms,
and my Heart, as oon as it ees thee, loes all its Force, which it hou'd make ue of againt thee. Away, away, aid he, with all my Haughtines and Scorn, you only erve to add Fuel to my Flame, and to render my Paion more violent than before. To be hort, my illutrious Lover, added he, throwing her elf about his Neck, and queeing him between her Arms, I love thee, and all the Coniderations in the World hall not be powerful enough to eparate us for the future, ‚Ä¢ nd not o much as for one Moment. I will leave it to your Judgment to gues what pat afterwards between two Perons who lov'd one another with o much Paion.

By this time, Night beginning to approach, the Countes began to be uneaie, not becaue he was with her Gallant, who entertain'd her with o much weetnes, but becaue he heard no News of her Coach, and that he thought it wou'd look very ill in her, not to return to Paris that Night; he was jut a talking of it, as much as he thought convenient to the Marhal, when putting her Head out of the Window, by chance, he aw one of her Footmen coming, who told her, That the Coach was ready at the Door; And what is become of Adventure? (which was the Coachman's Name who run away out of the Box before) cry'd the Lady very angry,
What is become of that Coxcomb? I can't tell, Madam, reply'd the Footman, we have heard nothing of him ince his overhaty Flight. Certainly, reply'd the Countes with a Smile, he did not act very dicreetly, in leaving me thus; but 'tis you, Marhal, aid he, that is the occaion of all. By my Faith, Madam, reply'd Bouflers, if your Coachman has no more Courage than he has hewn to Day, he is a mot damnable Coward; is it poible that a ingle Pitol hould frighten a Man out of his Wits? If I aw an hundred Fire locks dicharg'd at me at once, they hould n'er make me hrink. All the World has not uch a warlike Soul as you, my Dearet, aid the Countes; you were born to conquer the nivere, and to make every thing ubmit to you; your Power even extends it elf over me and‚ÄîHere he topt, not thinking it convenient to proceed in her Dicoure, by reaon of the Footman, who tood by, and heard what they aid; but having order'd him to withdraw, he renew'd her Love-Protetations, and began to prepare for going; but the Marhal, who did not intend to part with her as yet, detayn'd her for ome time longer, telling her, That ince he had frighted her Coachman away, he wou'd upply his Place himelf; which he accordingly did: For having pay'd the Reckoning, he wrapt himelf up in his
Scarlet-Cloak, and drove the Coach to Paris, as well as if the Coach-man himelf had been in the Box; it being dark Night he was not diturbed at the Frolick, but being come to her Lodgings, he entreated the Marhal to tay with her at Supper. All her dometick Servants were extremely urpris'd at this udden Change: What an alteration is this, aid they to one another; our Lady, not long ago wou'd not o much as hear him nam'd in her preence, nor wou'd allow us to peak of him, and now he eems to be as much in her avour as ever. But Mrs. Guion, her Lady's Confident, gues'd without much difficulty at the true reaon of it, not quetioning but that there had been a reconciliation between 'em.

After Supper, the Marhal tay'd for a coniderable time with his Mitres, in her Bedchamber; where they began afreh to argue the true Reaon of their Quarrel; they being now at Liberty to talk with more freedom, than they cou'd do at Boulogne, where they were in danger of being overheard by every one belonging to the Houe. The Lady then, no longer making any difficulty of dicloing her Heart to the Marhal, and their mutual Reconciliation, having been Seal'd by ome Kies, he left her to her Repoe. But, alas! in vain; the poor Lady was not capable of enjoying one moments
Ret. The urprie of this lat Adventure, and that too by a Man whom he had reolv'd to Banih from her Heart for ever; together with the behaviour of the Marchiones de la Mothe, who had left her to the Mercy of a Gentleman, whom he cou'd not but know to be very dangerous to her Repoe, had mot horribly ditracted her Mind: She made a thouand Reflections upon the trangenes of the Accident, and not being able to be at ret at home, he went the next day to pay the Marchiones a Viit, who did not fail to upbraid her with her wanton Humour. How, aid the Marchiones, in a mot cornful manner, are not you that ame Lady, who wou'd never ee Monieur Boufflers any more; nay, that wou'd not o much as hear any one peak of him; and carce had you cat one Eye at him, but without any further conideration, you threw your elf into his Embraces? I cannot deny it, Madam, reply'd the Countes, not without ome Confuion; but what is it one will not do when one is in Love; alas! Love makes us all ubject to Frailties, and that to uch a degree, that we carce know what we do. Alas! good Heavens! the Marhal, at his firt ight, diarms me entirely and makes me, in pite of all my anger, recal all my former Reolutions, which immediately vanih in his preence. I know, Madam, reply'd the Marchiones, that he will prove very dangerous to your
repoe, and therefore you ought to force your tender Inclinations; you ought not to urrender your Heart upon o eaie Terms, after he has had the boldnes to carry you away along with me, who did not know him any farther than by ight. His manner of proceeding avours of too much familiarity, and a Peron of his Character ought to have treated us with more Repect. My greatet trouble, my Dearet, aid the Countes, interrupting her, was, that you hou'd leave me to the management of a Man of his Humour. Come, come, Madam, reply'd the Marchiones maliciouly, I was well enough atisfi'd that you were very well acquainted with him before; and that his Courthips were not diagreeable to your Inclinations: 'Tis not ince Yeterday, that you have perceiv'd his Amourous motions: You are not ignorant of his intentions; you are not inenible how far he is likely to carry it; and whatever you may pretend to the contrary, I am not bound to take your word as to this particular. When any Perons are in Love, they eldom think themelves oblig'd to peak truth; they take delight in diguiing the matter, and upon the whole, I am of opinion, that no account ought to be made of any thing that they aert. The Marchiones de la Mothe wou'd not have top't here, but that one of her Acquaintance coming in, very earnetly entreated her to go with her to hear a Sermon at Verailles. The
Countes, who wou'd rather have taid at home, went along with her more out of Policy than Devotion, and in the evening, being return'd to her Lodgings, the Marhal de Boufflers, after he had for ome time entertain'd her with his Paion; told her, that his mot Chritian Majety deign'd to beiege Namur (the Capital City of the Province of that Name) this Year, which was that of 1692. and that, to facilitate this Deign; his Majety intended to go thither in Peron, with the Dauphin and the ret of the principal Officers of his Court.

You will, without doubt, my Dear, reply'd he very Sorrowfully, have your hare in this glorious Enterprize; and perhaps I may be o unfortunate as to hear of your Death, which will unavoidably haten my own: What wou'd you have me do, Madam, reply'd the General, with a erious Countenance, I am oblig'd to obey my King's Orders; If it hou'd be my fortune to perih in this Campaign, continu'd he, I hall dye your Lover; and I hope you will take care that Prayers may not be wanting for my poor Soul, which perhaps will be fluttering about in the airy Regions, without finding any repoe: O good Sir, reply'd the Lady, don't be prepoes'd with any uch thoughts, that cannot but be detructive to your own welfare. We Religious Siters will take care of you, we'll prepare
your Soul for Paradie: O Lord! Madam, aid he, I hope you'll pardon me, If I can carce believe it; how is it poible that uch a Devil as I, whoe whole practice has been the detruction of Mankind by Fire and Sword, hou'd be av'd from Hell; tho' I have heard ome ay, that there is a particular place of Ret appointed for us Soldiers, but who can rely upon uch fantatick Notions? I am afraid I hall be leiurely Roated by the heat of Purgatory, the Flames of which as they tell me, urpas in fiercenes all the artificial Fires in the World. How foolih you are, Boufflers, anwer'd the Countes, thus to fill your head with uch Melancholy Thoughts: Don't you know that our good Works will deliver us both from the Fire of Purgatory, and of Hell? And as you have done more good than bad Deeds, I don't question, but that you'll pas directly to Paradie. But let us have no more of this; pray who are to be the General Officers, that are to Command this Year under the King and Dauphin?

Madam, reply'd the Marhal, thee are to be; the Count d' Auvergne, the Marhal de Humieres, the Princes de Soubie and Conde, and his eldet Son, the Duke de Villeroy, and a great many more, whom it wou'd be uperfluous to name to you, in regard that you have not the leat concern with 'em. 'Tis true, my Dear, reply'd the Countes ighing,
I don't pretend to any interet, but what I have in you, and good God! what a trouble wou'd it be to me, if I hou'd chance to loe you? Are not you a very pretty Gentlewoman? aid the Marhal miling, I'm ure I know the time, when you wou'd not have aid o: How often have you, when you were in your freekih humours, wih'd that the Earth might open to wallow me up; how often have you call'd me ungrateful Wretch, Monter, Villain, and uch like fine Names? Thee are the Weapons of an angry Woman. Oh! how extremely does your Sex take delight in Revenge? If you had the ame trength in your Arms, that you have in your Tongue, you wou'd defeat an Army of ten Thouand Men, in an hours time. I take it to be a very great misfortune for a Man to have a Woman for his Enemy; as for my own part, I wou'd rather be oblig'd to fight againt a whole Battalion of Enemies, than to tand the brunt of o Beauful a Lady as you, when put into a Paion. Do but ee how cruelly you deal with us; you are not content to overthrow us by the force of your Charms, but you wou'd alo trample upon us by your Threats, and drive us to the utmot Extremity of Depair. But e're I leave Paris, I'm reolv'd to make you lower your Topail, and to bring you to more reaonable terms.

p.U:
aid the fair Lady with a charming Air, is capable of making me do whatever you hall think fit. I can compare it to nothing o appoitely, as to that Head of Medua, which Metamorphos'd every thing, and chang'd its Situation: I have often taken a reolution to hate you as long as I hou'd live, and no ooner had I een you, but all my Averion to your Peron, and my eemingly firm Reolutions immediately vanih'd. 'Tis not long ago, ince the Marchiones de la Mothe upbraided me with this frailty: How, Madam, reply'd the Marhal briskly, that remedy aagint Love, durt he talk thus to you? Certainly, continu'd he laughing, a Man mut be very hard put to it for a dainty Bit, that wou'd venture to thrut his Dagger into her Scabbard, Vah! that naty hole, if I may believe the decription which the Abbot de la Trape has given me of it. This Prior has worn to me, that he never met with o ugly, black and deep a Gap in his Life-time. Fie, Boufflers, aid the Countes, as if he had been dipleas'd at his Dicoure; are not you aham'd thus to repreent that pretty retiring Place of the Marchiones, as he her elf uually calls it when he is in a good humour; and truly, if he knew you thought otherwie of it, I can aure you, you wou'd be but a very unwelcome Guet to her. She told me one day, that the Abbot de la Trape, of whom you poke jut
now, had indeed once et up his Candle before her Altar, and had Sacrifis'd upon his Knees in her preence. Then Monieur Boufflers interrupting her; 'tis a pleaant ubject to init upon, aid he, the Devil take me, if this Lady wou'd let me‚ÄîI wou'd rather chue a Cow for a Play-fellow: But away with it, let us talk no more of it, for I begin to be ick at the very Heart. It is you, aid he, my lovely Creature, embracing her, that carry about you that weet retiring Place, which is the very Seat of Delight and Pleaure: I am very enible of the tendernes of your Heart, which rewards it's Friends with plenary atisfaction. 'Tis true what you ay, anwer'd he, this is the chiefet Ambition which I ever pretended to.

div.p:
This Conference wou'd have lated longer, if one of the Marhal's Servants had not come to tell him, that Madam de Maintenon was deirous to peak with him, as 'twas uppos'd by the King's Order, he having been wholly employ'd for everal days after, in aiting at the frequent Councils of War, that were then held at Verailles. A few Weeks after, he was oblig'd to enter upon the Campaign, which began very early this Year. The King to encourage his Generals, march'd in Peron at the head of his Army; and Namur was Beieg'd in the Month of May, in the Year 1692. as it has
been already intimated; and the Trenches being open'd before it, between the Twenty ninth and Thirtieth, the Place was carry'd by Capitulation. The Marhal did ignalie himelf there at everal Times, as did alo the Marques de la Valette and de Gae, Marhals de Camp; after the urrender of the Town, both the Armies remain'd for ome Time without Action; during which Interval, the Marhal de Boufflers was captivated by the Beauty of a certain young Gentlewoman, who was retiring, with her Mother, into a Nunnery, and by the King's expres Command pas'd through the Camp, in order to go to a certain Abby of Religious Siters. At the very firt Sight of this young Lady, who was of good Quality and extraordinary Beautiful, he was touch'd with o tender Love and Repect for her, that for a coniderable Time he cou'd not be at ret; and that which vex'd him mot was, that he was in a Place where he had not the Opportunity to ee her, when he had a Mind to it. At lat, being grown impatient, at the Abence of his Belov'd Mitres, and conulting more his Paion than his Reaon, he reolv'd to diguie himelf in Woman's Apparel, on purpoe to give her a viit.

Having in this Diguie met her in the Parlour of the Nunnery, he did not delay to declare his Paion to her; unto which he anwer'd with o much Modety, that he was extremely charm'd with it. After his Departure, his Mitres thought it mot adviable not to peak any thing of her diguis'd Lover, either to her Mother, or the ret of the Religious Siters, for fear of putting ome Jealouie into their Brains, by which means he might loe the Advantage of entertaining him another Time. The next Day our General, being advertis'd that her Mother wou'd be abroad, had the Satifaction to viit his Mitres in her Chamber, which was jut at the Entrance of the Abby; and the ret of the Nuns believing it to be ome particular Acquaintance of her's, did not concern themelves any farther, allowing him the Freedom of enjoying the Preence of his Beloved for the pace of Two Hours. I leave it to the Judgment of the Reader to determine, whether he did not make ue of all the affectionate Expreions, which his Paion cou'd ugget to him; but this I have undertood ince, That one of the Religious Siters, whoe Name was Coline, and who upply'd the place of an Apothecary in the Abbey, had epy'd (in paing by her Chamber into the Garden, where he was going to gather ome Herbs)
the Marhal kneeling down before her, and kiing her Hands. For this Reaon it was that this Bigot, upecting omewhat of the Matter, let the Marhal, who in two or three Days return'd to renew his Viit, tand at the Door almot an Hour, without opening it; the Marhal, upecting the Truth, made uch a Noie, with the Bell, at the Abbey-Gate, that all the Religious Siters came running down Stairs, and peremptorily demanded what his Buines was? I wou'd willingly reply'd he, counterfeiting his Voice, peak to Mademoielle Orton (which was the Name of his Mitres.) The young Lady, being then call'd for, receiv'd him very courteouly, but with ome Retraint, her Mother, and Siter Coline being preent. The Marhal, after a little Stay, finding himelf o narrowly watch'd, thought it bet to decamp for that Time, and to defer his Courthip till a more favourable opportunity.

No ooner was he gone, but Madam Orton ask'd her Daughter, How he came acquainted with this Gentlewoman? Mother, reply'd he, he is a certain young Lady of a very good Family of Namur, who has a great Affection for me. Siter Coline tanding by, began to mile at her Anwer, which made her Mother ask the Name of this Lady. This Quetion put her to a
great Non plus, becaue the Marhal and he had not agreed upon any certain Name; yet having a good preence of Mind, he told her Mother, not without bluhing, That her Name was Mademoielle de Bouffline, being a Kinwoman of the Marhal de Boufflers, of whom they had receiv'd o many Courteies, during the Siege of Namur. Her Mother having as yet in freh Remembrance the great Obligations receiv'd from the Marhal, ask'd no further Quetions, being well atisfy'd with this Anwer. If Siter Coline, that piteful Baggage, wou'd have been as much contented, Matters were likely to go very well upon Mademoielle Orton's Side. But that Demi-Devil, having taken notice that he was a Man in Woman's Apparel, communicated her Thoughts to two or three more of the Religious Siters, who unanimouly reolv'd at his next approach to have him earch'd, by a certain ancient Matron belonging to the Nunnery, who hou'd watch his coming to adore his Goodes; and indeed, they were no wore than their Words, for he had not long been there, but he aw a grave old Woman entring the Room, with a great pair of Spectacles upon her Noe, and a large pair of Sciors in her Hand, follow'd by a goodly Train of Nuns of the ame Abbey. The Marhal eeing himelf detitute of all Arms, even o much as a
Stick, began to be afraid of their Motion, and made what hate he cou'd to get to the Door. Being got pretty well clear of 'em, No, no, good Matrons, aid he to himelf, I am not as yet fond of being gelt. I know what your Deign was, you wou'd have cut off what you found did not belong to the Female Sex, becaue I had been o bold as to come in without your Leave: Otherwie, I'm ure, if a Gentleman gives you a private Viit, with your own Conent, you wou'd not upon any account treat him o unkindly.

Mademoielle Orton eeing her elf, by this Contrivance, bereav'd of the Sight of her Gallant, appear'd much dicontented at his Abence, and having no other means left her, he went one Morning to Mas to another Abby, where he had the good Fortune to meet with him: She told him all that he had endur'd ever ince he aw him lat; adviing him to come and ee her in the Nunnery, without a Diguie: Adding, That her Mother wou'd be extremely glad to ee him, to pay her Acknowledgments for the great Obligations he had receiv'd from him. You mut be ure, aid he, to talk of Love to the ret of the Siters, for they take great Delight in having a Man touch upon that String. The Marhal, after having parted with his Beloved, began to conider with himelf, for ome time,
whether it were expedient for him to return to the ame Place, where he had been o lately in danger of uffering an irreparable Los; but Love oon prevail'd o'r all other Coniderations, epecially being animated by the Hopes of obtaining his Aim, if he went without Diguie, inomuch that beides his Sword, he took care to provide a Pair of Pocket-Pitols, and having taken along with him a luty Fellow, his Servant, arm'd Capapee, he enter'd the Abby with an undaunted Courage. The Nuns quickly taking notice of a Man of o gallant and engaging an Air, came all to receive him, making him Preents of divere Relicks and Agnus Dei's, and among the ret one of the Religious Siters, as fair and bright as the Day, preented to him, a Heart made of her own Hair, which was all over pierc'd with Darts.

The Marhal having dicover'd the Advantages of this Charming Beauty, which had enchanted him even at the very firt Sight, oon became forgetful of Mademoielle Orton. He frequently repair'd to the Nunnery, where he wou'd entertain ometimes one, ometimes another, but his Franon (which was the beautiful Nun I poke of before) was all his Delight and Comfort. Her Companions were o tranported with Jealouie, that one Day they
threw an Ink horn full of Ink in her Face, on purpoe to diguie it; which being told to the Mother Abbes, he made 'em do Penance for their Trepas, enjoyning 'em for Eight Days together to dig the Ground, and to manure it with their bare Hands till it hou'd be as fine as Ahes.
