Beides this, they were to draw out of a deep Pit ten Tuns of Water into a leaky Veel, which run out as fat as they pour'd it in. The Marhal was overjoy'd to ee what Satisfaction his Mitres had receiv'd for the Affront put upon her, but to counterballance his Joy, he was much urpris'd to hear the Mother Abbes (who was above Threecore Years of Age) tell him, That he was fall'n deperately in Love with him. Indeed he was o amaz'd at it, that he tept two or three Paces backward, and if he had not been upheld by a Table that tood behind him, he wou'd have carce been able to keep himelf upright. The good Woman took o much Pains to repreent to him the vehemency of her Paion, in Terms o lively and natural, that he tood quite atonih'd at it. Perhaps it will not be improper to give you a Character of this old Hag. She was of a very mall Stature, and crooked; her Noe very hort; her Eyes and Mouth bigger than all the ret of her Face; her Fore-head about the Bignes of a Finger's Breadth,
and two great Teeth tuck out of her Mouth before; but for the ret, he was very ingenious, and had an extraordinary Wit. She made a very fine Sonnata concerning her Paion for the General, which begins thus, I having forgot the ret.

lg.l: Thy Praie, thou greatest Herce of the Age:
All things on Earth and Sea do dread thy Rage,
And till new Lawrels to thy Triumphs bring.

div.p:
The Marhal was very hardly put to it how to manage o unuual a Love-concern with this old Beldam, whom he was unwilling to dioblige, in regard that he was the upreme Governes of the Nunnery; when one Day, not being able to have any longer Patience to expect his Reolution, he laid hold of him in a Corner, as he was going to a Chamber of one of the Nuns, where he hugg'd him o cloely with her two rawbon'd Arms, which were as tough as Sticks, that 'twas impoible for him to get looe from her Embraces. The Marhal being afraid that ome of the Siters might urprie 'em told her, Pray, good Mother, do your Matters a little more in private, for fear of
giving Scandal. You are in the right on't, my Son, cry'd he, drawing him by main Force into a Cloet, hard by, where he begg'd him, Not to deny her any longer that Favour which he o much wih'd for. And what Favour is that? aid the Marhal de Boufflers, laughing. That is my Son, continu'd he, haking her Head, to put your Sword here, after I have beprinkl'd it with Holy Water, to drive away the Evil Spirit (for o the Nuns of Namur uually call Love) that thus torments me. The Marhal, who cou'd not but undertand her Meaning, and being uncertain what to reolve upon. You trangle me! don't trangle me! and o having hut his Eyes, Come, aid he, let us enter the Breach, in the Dark; all Cats are Grey. The Mother Abbes, who was extremely well atisfy'd, deir'd him to renew the Attack the next Day; but he was not o well pleas'd with the firt, and therefore having made the Sign of the Cros all over him, he aid, in a Language unknown to her, Away from me Satan. The good Woman being exaperated at this Repule, flung her elf about his Neck, laying her Fits about his Ears: All which he took very patiently, but perceiving that he was about to vent her Anger upon his Perriwig and Ruffles, he turn'd up her Back-ide, and having oundly clapp'd her Buttocks, which were as red and lean as
an Ape's; the whole Nunnery was alarm'd at the Outcries: The Nuns came running, with all poible peed, to the Chamber of their Abbes, whom they found crying like a Child, whilt the Marhal was not able to forbear laughing, and to ave himelf was oblig'd to tell the whole Story. Whereupon the Old Beldam took it o heinouly, that not being able any longer to bear the Confuion he was in, and the Reproaches which mut needs attend uch a Dicovery, he hang'd her elf for Grief the next following Night. The Marhal taking the advantage of thee Diorders, hunted about the Nunnery till he met with his belov'd Franon whom he had debauch'd; and having afterwards caus'd her to be diguis'd in the Habit of a Page, he follow'd him in the Camp, and was preent at the Battel of Steenkirk, which was fought in Augut. Under this diguie he waited upon him in his Tent, and in all other places, without the leat upicion of her being a Woman, except that the Prince de Turenne ome few hours before he was lain, began to upect the Truth, who without doub't wou'd have dicover'd the whole Intrigue, if Death had not prevented him. Monieur Boufflers was o careful of his Page, that he went no where without him, and he was call'd by no other name in the Army, than The handome Page.

During thee intrigues, the Marhal receiv'd Letters from the Countes of‚Äîwhom he had left at Paris, and from Mademoielle Orton, who was as yet in the Nunnery near Namur. Thee two fair Ladies were not paring in upbraiding him with his Indifferency and Ficklenes. But, alas! thee are weak Efforts againt Men of o changable a Temper as our General then was, who eldom are concern'd at the Reproaches of an abandon'd Mitres. He receiv'd very frequent Letters from both, which were immediately acrifis'd to the Flames without o much as reading 'em. Franon, was generally a Spectatrix of it, and had the atisfaction to hear him ay, that it was done for her ake. Winter approaching, the Army was divided and ent to the Garrions, the Marhal taking his way (incognito) directly to Paris, attended by his Page: The Countes, who had got Intelligence that he had been ix or eight Weeks in Town, without eeing her, at lat came to find him out at his Lodgings; where he upbraided him in a mot outragious manner: But he did not anwer her one Word, and having order'd one of his Servants to hut the Door upon her, he look'd above to ee her depart, without being in the leat dicern'd by her. This Lady having omewhere or another got notice that he was in love with a young
Woman who liv'd with him under the diguie of a Page, happen'd jut to meet her upon the tairs as he was going down, playing with a little Dog, one of the finet that ever was een, which the Marhal had brought along with him from the Campaign. This Dog, after he had firt had everal lices with a Knife at the beautiful Page's Face, he threw out at Window, which was next to her, and o made the bet of her way. The poor young Gentlewoman, being thus mierably handl'd and calling to mind what befel her not long ago, as to the Ink-horn in the Nunnery, Alas Heavens! cry'd he, am I not very unfortunate, that every one has a deign againt that little Beauty which Nature has betow'd upon me. The Marhal, who oon knew the Voice of his female Page, opening the Chamber-door, run out with all imaginable peed to ee what accident had happen'd, and found her all over cover'd with Blood. He had never been more heartily vex'd in all his Life-time, but all that cou'd be done at that intant, was to end for an able Surgeon who heal'd her Wounds in a little time, with o much Skill, that not the leat Scarr appear'd.

However, the Marhal conceiv'd o great an Averion toward the Countes, that all the World was extremely urpriz'd at it, conidering to what a degree he had Lov'd her before. One evening during the Carnaval, the Marques de Boufflers came in Maquerade, to a Ball, made by the Order of the Duke de Villeroy; of which the Countes having had ome notice, he alo went thither in a diguie, and took out our General to Dance with her; but he by ome ecret intinct, uppoing it to be her, excus'd himelf, and to avoid any further confuion, immediately left the Company. The next Night was wholly pent by him in running thro' the Ball diguis'd in the Habit of a Satyr, with his Page, who with her fair Hair pread all over her houlders, Danc'd to the admiration of all the Spectators; every one being amaz'd at the becoming Air and Meen of Franon, who pas'd for a young Man among thoe that did not know her; to the great atisfaction of our General, who cou'd not forbear laughing at it.

Not long after, Madam de Chatillon, Siter, of the Marhal de Luxemburg fell deperately in Love with her, which was a mot pleaant Scene to Boufflers, and erv'd as an agreeable Diverion to him for a long
time after. She never made him a Viit, but all her Dicoure run upon the excellency of this Page, whom he thought as fair as an Angel; beides aid he, that there is omewhat o uncommon and o amiable in his Air, that 'tis impoible for a tender Heart to reit uch engaging Charms; 'tis very well for you Men that he was not born a Woman, for he wou'd certainly have et you all in a flame, and burnt you to ahes; I mut confes, Madam, reply'd the Marhal with a mile, a Beauty o fair as my Page, might caue great diorders in the World, and therefore prudent Nature having foreeen this evil, judg'd it most expedient to make him a Man, as he appears to be: But Sir, aid Madam de Chatillon, interrupting him, and cating a very Paionate look upon Franon, Don't you believe that a Man who is endow'd with extraordinary perfections, may caue as many Commotions among our Sex, as a fair Lady does among yours? Yes very well Madam, aid our General, I am throughly convinc'd that your Hearts are as tender as ours, nay that you out do us in certain repects. You Love with more contancy and reality, whilt we Men are continually upbraided with Levity in changing our Mitrees as often as we pleae: For my part, if I were oblig'd to peak incerely, I mut confes that I have een great
variety of Countries in the Empire of Venus, and have made thoe Ladies ufficiently enible of it, with whom I have had any Love-concerns for ome time. For I never et up for much Contancy, it being a thing I never was ambitious of. An Engagement which lats above two or three Months becomes burdenome; and variety is mot agreeable to my Humour, epecially in matters of Love; which, nevertheles, eldom uits with the Temper of the Female Sex, who take a particular Delight, and make it a point of Honour to preerve the remainders of an old Paion, almot quite worn out, meerly to have the atisfaction to ay, Such and uch a one till continues to Love me, a convincing proof, that my Charms have been o powerful as to keep him in Chains even to this very Day.

Truly Sir, reply'd the Lady, you peak very favourably of our Sex, when you tell us, That you take 'em to be more Contant than yours. We are at least as fickle as you; and if it were not for a certain kind of Modety, ineparable from our Sex, believe me, we hou'd be as forward to eek for new Gallants, as you are to find out freh Beauties. I know not what to ay to it, Madam, aid the Marhal, laughing; this I ee plainly, that none in this World can be free from Faults, if Changeablenes is to be counted o. Franon, who was almot tir'd
with hearing her thus Prattle without intermiion, and knowing that Monieur de Boufflers paid her a great deal of Repect, more out of Policy, than any thing ele, went into a Room over head, from whence, through the Clefts of the Planks, he pour'd ome dirty Water upon her Head-Dres, of which he was the nicet Woman in the World, and which was always exactly et in the Quills, whilt he affected to imitate the motions of a Puppet.

Monieur de Boufflers eem'd to be very angry with his Page, chiding him, and calling him an awkward Fool. But the Lady immediately took Franon's part, telling the Marhal, That 'twas of o little conequence, that he ought not to chide o pretty a Creature as that, about it; epecially ince it was done by michance, without any malicious Intent. No, Madam, reply'd the Page with a great deal of affected Simplicity, It was my Mater's Ape, that in running after me, overthrew the Water-bowl: We are Play-fellows together, and I often uffer for his Tricks, of which 'tis impoible to break him. She poke all this, with o much eeming Innocency, that he charm'd Madam Chatillon to the highet degree, who went home more amorous than ever. She had no ooner enter'd her own Houe, but having firt
chang'd her Head-cloaths and Linnen, he lock'd her elf up in her Cloet, to make Reflections upon her growing Paion.

The Marhal, after he was gone, ask'd Franon, Whether he had pilt the Water upon the Duke of Luxemburg's Siter on purpoe? Yes, my Dearest, reply'd he, embracing him, I had only a mind to be rid of this prattling Creature, who is continually Talking without intermiion. You are an unlucky Baggage, reply'd the General with a Smile, thus to abue a poor Gentlewoman, who hews o much Affection towards you. O, reply'd Franon, that is, becaue he verily believes me to be a Man; but if he hou'd go about to earch me, he wou'd oon be convinc'd to the contrary, o that is behoves me to take a great deal of care not to let her come thereabouts; for in regard that he has no great hare of Dicretion, it wou'd not be long e're he wou'd divulge the Matter to all the World. I only wonder that the Marhal, her Brother, has not found out the Mytery before this time, by the help of his Magical Art: Indeed I am orely afraid of that old Devil, as often as I ee him. My pretty little Creature, aid the Marhal, he has the misfortune to be a Scarecrow to the handome Ladies; he never has had any ucces in Love concerns. I don't know by
what means he ininuated himelf into the favour of the Countes de Soions, he being the only Woman that ever lov'd him in his Life-time; as he has often told me with his own Mouth, not without much regret, he being a great admirer of the Fair Sex. But my dear Boufflers, anwer'd Franon, with a languihing Air, I have been told that the Duke de Montmorency and the Count de Luce are very accomplih'd Gentlemen, and very dextrous in the Art of Courthip. That is true enough, reply'd the Marhal, but they have not uch a dangerous Head piece as their Father, they are of a weet and agreeable Temper; they are not for ranacking Heaven and Earth to find out their depth, and to dive into the mot abtrue Secrets of Love; neither is there any need of all that tir, ince the Charms of this Paion are altogether founded upon Innocence.

Franon was accutom'd frequently to dipute thus with her Gallant, and that too in o charming a manner, that he for ome time was the abolute Mitres of his Heart; when, upon a udden, he took a Reolution, either to Marry her, or ele to put her into ome Nunnery for the remainder of her Life. The lat of thee two Means was more eaie to be accomplih'd than the former, wherefore he propos'd to her this Retirement, as the mot honourable and
mot advantagious in her preent Circumtances. The Gentlewoman was in the greatet Agony in the World e're he cou'd reolve upon it, becaue he lov'd him o affectionately, that he cou'd rather have dy'd than live without him. But notwithtanding all her Sighs and Tears, Monieur Boufflers, who was reolv'd to be rid of her, having in view a mot advantagious Match for himelf, of which we hall have occaion to peak hereafter, put her into a Nunnery in the Suburbs of S. Marcellus, without having made any one privy to the Buines, except the Abbes, whom he had perwaded that he was his Kinwoman; having preented her beides this, with a coniderable Sum of Mony, in recompence of her former good Services. Thus this fair Lady once more put on the Habit of a Nun. But before he did it, he was deirous to be upon tryal for ome time, under pretence that it was expedient for her to oberve whether that coure of Life wou'd agree with her Contitution. But this was not the true reaon of her delay; he was in hopes till that her Lover, before this time was expir'd, might repent of having hut her up in a Nunnery, and that he might be prevail'd upon to Marry her, conformably to ome light Promies which he had made her
to that effect, during the height of his Paion. But Words poken by a Lover to a Woman, when they are in the heat of their Paion, cannot be compar'd to any thing more appoitely than to the floating of the Sea, which depends upon the variablenes of the Winds.

Our General, finding himelf now diengag'd from all his Mitrees, began to lead a very regular and olitary coure of Life, o that Madam de Maintenon having oberv'd him o much alter'd from what he had been before, made no difficulty to peak in his behalf to Mademoielle de Grammont, Daughter of the Marhal of the ame Name, who, having formerly commanded the King's Armies, had ignaliz'd himelf on everal Occaions. The Abbes of St. Cyr did not forget to give her an Account of all his rare Accomplihments, unto which the young Lady reply'd but very little, being not unacquainted with ome of his amorous Inrigues, and believing him only to act the Hypocrite like a Jeuit. But our General, being a great Favourite of Madam Maintenon's, had often an opportunity to ee her there; and having always hew'd her a more than ordinary deference and repect, he began by degrees to have a better Opinion of him and his Actions. One Day being left
alone with her, he began to declare his Paion to her by halves, but was o extremely over-aw'd by her Preence, that he was not able to proceed in his Dicoure; the exces of his Love made him tammer almot at every Word; which caus'd Mademoielle to laugh at his Tranports. He oon after, had a Quartan Ague for three Months, which was commonly call'd the Intervals of his Love; inomuch that he was oblig'd to take a good Quantity of Quinquina, or Jeuit's Powder, which cur'd him of his Ague, but occaion'd a mot violent Head-ach, for which he was advis'd to have recoure to the Waters of Bourbon, as he did. He was jut upon the point of getting a new Mitres upon the Road, but having recollected himelf, how prejudicial uch an Intrigue might prove to his preent Deign, he thought it more advieable in this juncture, to keep a trong guard over his Heart, which wou'd willingly have made an Elopement; and to fortifie it o well, as not to fear any Attack, except from Mademoielle de Grammont, unto whom all its Avenues and Paes were to be open'd.

Thus he pent ome time in this Solitude, but he cou'd not hold out long, for he oon after, began to fix his Eyes on a young Laundres, who was wont to bring his Linnen
every Day to his Chamber; and imagining that uch an Intrigue might be carry'd on privately, without any noie, he was reolv'd to try his Fortune; which prov'd very favourable to him, he having, without much reluctancy, hearken'd to his firt Propoal. His Valet du Chambre, who always found his Bed tumbl'd after he had made it, not in the leat upecting that his Mater had any concerns in it, made a Complaint to the Landlady. I have oberv'd, aid the good Woman of the Houe, that as often as Judith comes, I find the Bed in this condition; God forgive me, if I wrong her. You are not in earnest, Dame Roux, aid the Valet du Chambre, laughing: Do you imagine that my Mater wou'd meddle with uch a Drab as this, who has kis'd o many fine Ladies? Thou art a good honest Blockhead, Champonniere, aid the Landlady, laughing as hard as he cou'd, Dost thou not know, that a mad Dog falls upon every Thing that lies in his Way? Well, reply'd the Servant, joking, when all is done, no Body hall e're perwade me, That 'tis not a much greater Pleaure to kis a fair Lady of Quality than a dirty Drab. Oh! when I think of thoe pretty Buttocks, thoe Hands, thoe white and delicate Bubbies, which I have taken notice of in my Mater's Ladies, it tickles me all over the whole Body, but epecially
here about the Middle‚ÄîOh! I am quite beides my elf, I hall run tark mad, if I think on't any longer. As far as I ee, anwer'd the Dame of the Houe coffingly, your Skin is mightily tickl'd with this Fancy, which has et you all on a Flame. But, prithee, tell me, thou great Fool, Dot thou believe me o imple as to imagine that thy Mater wou'd make thee privy to his Mitrees Beauties? May the Devil take me, anwer'd he, if I have not often een 'em, in going and coming, in and out of the Chamber, when he was buie in‚Äîand was not at Leiure to take notice of me. Plague! on thee for a Beast, cry'd the Landlady, laughing as loud as he cou'd; Come Spark, I'll acquaint the Marhal de Boufflers with it, who I believe, will give thee a good Reward for the Pains thou taket to divulge his Amours. You'll have a care of that, Dame Roux, reply'd Champonniere, blowing the Smoak of Tobacco in her Face, or ele I hall go near to have your white Top knot dy'd Black, as Apollo erv'd the Sexton, who was officious in relating to him, what he had heard others ay concerning him. Boufflers having call'd his Servant, the Dialogue was broke off; and having ent him with ome Letters to the Pothoue, he went into his Cloet, where he wrote this following Billet Doux to Mademmoielle de Grammont.
Mademoielle.
AMong all the Mortals who have ador'd you, none e're lov'd you with o trancendent a Paion as my elf, beyond all that ever can be conceiv'd tender, for o adorable a Peron as your elf. I am at preent reduc'd to uch a Condition, as I never knew before; that is to ay, I am the mot unfortunate of all Men that ever were made for Love, except yon take Compaion of my Sufferings. I am to treat with you upon Terms altogether different from what I was wont to do with my former Mitrees, looking upon you, with a quite different Eye. All the Favours I ue for at your Hands (mot Charming Lady) is only to afford me one favourable Glance of your Goodnes, and to lend an Ear to ome of my Sighs, which are roving about in the Air, becaue they can't find a Reception from you. But if I cou'd once ee that happy Day when I might fix but one of 'em cloe to your Heart; then, then I hou'd have the Satisfaction of eeing you repent of all thoe Evils which you have made me uffer. As I know you to be a
very good Chritian, o I cannot but perwade my elf that you will reflect eriouly, that it is not a Venial Sin, thus to make a poor Mortal uffer and languih, who loves you better than his own Life: Heaven that hears me is my Witnes, that what I have aid falls very hort of what I feell, and that if it continues long I mut dye: This will be the firt News, Madam, which you will hear, if you don't alter your Mind, of being o inhuman as before. I remain even to the very lat Gap of my Life, the mot incere and paionate of all Mortal Lovers.

Mademoielle de Grammont happen'd to be at Madam Maintenon's, when he receiv'd this Letter, and after having perus'd it, he fell a laughing, and told Madam Maintenon; I mut acknowledge that the Marhal de Boufflers has a very pretty way of writing. I cou'd carce have believ'd that a Soldier cou'd be endu'd with o much Gallantry. Sure Mademoielle, reply'd Madam de Maintenon, you are not in Earnet; does not Love take its Rie even in the very midt of Arms, and is not Gallantry the most eential Character of a Warriour? Don't we ee your Alexanders, Caears and Pompeys
inclin'd to this tender Paion in the midst of their Conquets, depiing to reap the Fruits of their most glorious Victories, without the oft Embraces of their beloved Mitrees? Love has been in all Ages the Delight of Great Men, and is of all other Paions the mot innocent, provided it be us'd with Moderation and Dicretion, which indeed, are the Two Foundation-Pillars of Human Felicity. What is more natural than to love that which is amiable? The very irrational Creatures themelves, if they ee any thing urpriing, cannot avoid looking upon it; and can it appear trange to you, Mademoielle, aid the Lady very pleaantly, that our Marhal de Boufflers, who has a very dicerning Judgment, hou'd tand amaz'd at your Beauty, and a thouand other engaging Qualities, too too powerful for him to reit? Madam, anwer'd Mademoielle de Grammont, you hew as much Generoity as the Gentleman himelf of whom you peak, thus to conceal my Faults. I cou'd wih my elf Mitres of thoe Perfections, which you are pleas'd o freely to attribute to me. Ah! fair Creature, reply'd the Lady, don't oppoe a Truth which is really due to your Merits, Poor Boufflers is only too enible of it, 'tis that which has touch'd his Heart to the Quick. And do you really believe it, Madam, reply'd the young Lady coldly, Is it poible that the Heart of o genteel and o gallant a Man as he is,
can be wounded at this time? Oh! I much doubt it. And why o, 'pray? reply'd Madam de Maintenon; thoe that have o many Mitrees don't always part with their Liberty, but commonly keep their Heart to their own Dipoal. There is a vat difference between that ort of Love which is betow'd upon a Mitres, and that which belongs to a Wife. An unmarry'd Peron, without ome little Love-Exercie, grows dull and good for nothing. It eems as if ome little Love-Intrigue erves to animate his Vital Spirits, and renders him more acceptable among Women. I will allow it you, Madam, aid Mademoielle, provided thee Intrigues are not carry'd on to that height as the Marhal de Boufflers has been accutom'd to do; there is none that can be ignorant of his Love. Adventures. And what extraordinary Matter is there in all this, Mademoielle, reply'd the Lady, miling, he will be the better able to find the way that leads him to the Glory of pleaing you, a Man cannot be too well skill'd in the Art of Love. But, Madam, aid he, ometimes thee conquering Gentlemen pay dear for their Knowledge. Soft, oft, my Darling, cry'd Madam de Maintenon, don't you believe that the Marhal has very good Skill in Women? Indeed I know him to be o nice in this point, that I dare engage for him. Madam, your Surety is without Exception, anwer'd Mademoielle, and I will rely upon all that you have aid, and hope
you'll give me Leave to depart for this Time, that I may be at Leiure to give him a uitable Anwer to his Civilities. In hort, Mademoielle, aid Madam Maintenon, riing from her Seat, you'll do very well; for he is a very worthy Gentleman, who does not deerve to be lighted. You do not know what Time may bring to pas, perhaps he may one Day become your Husband. Mademoielle de Grammont had no ooner left the Abbes of St. Cyr, but retiring into her Chamber, he wrote the Marhal thee following Lines.
SIR,
IS it poible to believe, that you hou'd be o much in Love, as you pretend, after you have Travell'd through o many Countries? Perhaps, all thoe Ladies whom you have hitherto met with, wanted ufficient Charms to engage your Heart: Beides this, you wou'd induce one to believe, to your Advantage, that you have an inexhautible Stock of Affection for thoe, whom you wou'd perwade they deerve it. But, if one may take the boldnes to tell you, that ince that Fire you peak of, as often as it is tranplanted, loes every time omewhat of its innate Vigour, it mut of neceity
follow, that (according to your own decription) it cannot be o vehement, except it be upon the Paper, where, in my Opinion, it acts with its utmot Energy. I am willing, nevertheles, to believe thus much for your ake, that there may be left ome mall remainders of your Heart, which you are ready to offer me as a econd-Hand Sacrifice. In return of this your fine Preent, I will alo promie to you o much of my Inclination as is uitable to it; I mean o far as to accept it: This ought to be taken as omething not fit to be depis'd; for you know, Sir, that even the leat Boon that a Lady grants to a Gentleman, immediately is dignify'd with the Title of a Favour, which is commonly repreented through a magnifying Glas, much bigger than it is really intended: But let it be as it will, I am willing to betow omewhat upon it, to have the atisfaction of hearing it aid, that you have ome Affection for me, and that at preent I am the ole Mitres of a Heart, which formerly was har'd among o many Beauties.

The Marhal having read and kis'd the Letter a thouand times over, found it very witty, and extremely well writ. How! cry'd he, laughing, who has made you o well acquainted with my former Amours? You have a very pretty way of upbraiding me very wittily with all my former Mitrees. Ha! I don't dilike this Humour of yours, for out of what you ay, I am ufficiently convinc'd, that you don't hate me: And the lat Reerve which you offer me of ome part of your Inclinations, tho' but very mall at preent, is nevertheles very acceptable to me; Time, I don't quetion, will provide for the ret, and abate much of your Cruelty. While the Marhal was thus talking, Judith came into his Chamber with a pair of Point de Venice Ruffles, which were ome Days before torn in pieces in one of their amorous Skirmihes. Here, Mr. Dragoon, aid he, throwing 'em at his Face, thee are the Remnants of your fine Ruffles, which I have ticht together as well as I cou'd. How now, you little awcy Baggage, anwer'd Boufflers, where are you Manners? Is this your way of peaking to a Gentleman? I will promie thee, that to break thee of this familiarity, I'll make ue of a good Birch-broom: I am not ignorant that when a Man and a Woman have been o cloely acquainted as we, Love
knows no inequality; nevertheles, I wou'd have you keep your elf at ome ditance, for very good Reaons. And I Sir, reply'd the young Wench, wou'd have you do the ame thing with repect to me: Pray have a care, another time, not to make me Dance tark naked, without a Shift, round your Chamber, and then to pretend to put in backwards omething which I did not care hou'd‚ÄîO what a pretty ort of Clyter you were about to apply to me! And what great matter is there in all this, you wanton Slut, cry'd the General, I was applying it in the right place, and where it does most good: I know very well whereabouts thou art now, thou wou'dst have me put it in another place: No quetion, reply'd Judith, becaue that is the proper place where uch Applications ought to be made. Well, well then, aid the Marhal, throwing her upon his Bed, let us try whether I can Syringe you right there or not. Hold, hold, a little, Sir, aid Judith, giving him three or four good Poults with her double Fit upon his Back, What the Devil are you going to do? Your Tools are oon ready; you might have ask'd first whether mine were o too. You Gentlemen of the Province of Picardy, are o brisk and forward; but I wou'd have you not be o over-eager.

The Marhal, in the mean while, little minding what he aid, advanc'd a-pace, and that o furiouly, that he drew Blood from
the poor Girl, who then began to cry for her Maiden head, which, as he aid, he had kept entire till that time. The Land-lady coming ome Hours after, into the Chamber to make the Bed, found upon the Sheets ome few Drops, or Spots, the Marks of a lot Virginity, which made her not doubt any longer but that Monieur Boufflers was wont to kis his Laundres. The Woman, being acquainted with Judith's Mother, told her all that he knew concerning the Matter, and that he believ'd the General had debauch'd the illy Wench. Her Mother, who was a Herb-woman in the leer Green-Market, and who pretended to be very careful of her Daughters Honour, left all her Herbs and Seeds, running the ame Evening directly to the Marhal's Lodgings, with one Hand on her ide, and a great Stick in the other, where he thus began to accot him: I wou'd fain know, good Sir, with what Impudence you cou'd attempt to debauch my Daughter, whom I have brought up with o much care. I wih that S. Martin, who hears me, may punih me everely for all my Sins, if I don't tickle your Codpiece, except you retore my Daughter's Honour; a Pox! on your damn'd Tricks. The Marhal burt out a Laughing very heartily; And Mother Gobille (this was the
Herb-woman's Name) aid he, which way wou'd you have me retore your Daughter's Honour, whom you believe I have‚ÄîTruly thee orts of Breaches are never to be repair'd. I know that as well as you, good Sir, aid he, raving for Madnes, but then I'll make your Pure pay for it. What! hall I ee my Child turn Strumpet, and get nothing by the Bargain? No, before George, added he, lifting up her Stick, be you never o much a Marhal over the King's Armies, I'll lay this over your Head, except‚Äî Hold, hold, Dame Gobille, cry'd the Marhal, taking hold of her Arm, don't be o furious; how much do you demand for your Daughter's Maiden-head? You mut let me have a Pennyworth, becaue perhaps I had it not all entirely. Then you own you had it, my good natur'd Friend, reply'd the Woman with her Eyes rolling in her Head, I'll wear you hall pay for't, or ele I hall eie on your Field-Equippage, which is all you are worth in the World. And how dot thou know, my dear Bird, anwer'd Boufflers, that that is all what I am worth? Who has given thee an account of my Circumtances? Thou art very impudent to treat a Gentleman of my Quality o rudely. Get thee gone for an impertinent
Piece as thou art, thou deerv't to be oundly cudgell'd with the ame Stick thou hat the Impudence to lift up againt me. Pay me, ery'd the Herb-woman as loud as he cou'd, pay me for my Daughter's Maiden-head, or ele I'll go to my Lord Arch-bihop, who will make you pay dearly for it. This Holy Man knows the true value of a Virginity. You, Soldiers, are o inur'd to pillaging and ravihing whilt you are in the Army, that you make no Concience of it at home. She cou'd not utter thee lat Words without a whole Flood of Tears, o that our Marhal taking ome Compaion of her, threw her a golden Louis, telling her, That he thought he had paid dear enough for uch a Bit. But he threw the Piece at his Head, aying, Is not this a very fine ort of Payment for o dainty a Morel? You hall not come off thus, for I expect above Thirty of thee, and you may be glad if I am contented o. You that pretend to be o fine a Gentleman, are you not aham'd to offer a Pitole for a Maiden-head? Fie for hame! let no body hear of it. If all the Ladies of Pleaure in this Town have no better Pay, it will carce afford 'em Water to wah their Hands. And truly that is the reaon why I was o careful of my Daughter's Maiden-head,
till now; but ince he has let the Cat tate of the Cheee, I uppoe he will be no more at my dipoal There, Dame, aid Boufflers, who was quite tir'd with her Impertinencies, there are four Pitoles for you; Decamp immediately, or ele I will order the Cannon, which I have ent for, to be dicharg'd upon you. The poor Woman, being frighted at thee Words, was about to pack up her Awls; but the Marhal repenting that he had not giv'n her omething more for her Daughter's Virginity, threw her down two other Pitoles, bidding her to be gone, without any further delay, which he did.

Our General being left alone in his Chamber, and having recollected in his Mind all that had happen'd concerning Judith; he began to accue her of Indicretion in teling her Mother, of what had pas'd between 'em; not dreaming that it was his Landlady that had made this Dicovery. When therefore he came the next Day to ee him, according to her uual cutom, he upbraided her with her Foolihnes: But the young Wench wore that it never enter'd her Thoughts; telling him, That he ought not to take her to be o ottih, as to let her Mother know her Love-concerns, from whom he cou'd not expect any encouragement upon uch
an Account. And who cou'd peak of it ele but you? reply'd Boufflers briskly. This Adventure will hortly be the whole Town-talk, and I hou'd be vex'd to the very Heart, if ome of my Friends hou'd come to hear of it, partly for your own ake, it being certain that it cannot be but to your great diadvantage. I fanie, my Lord, reply'd Judith, having mus'd for ome time upon the matter, that this News came firt out of your own Lodgings, and it is your Land lady whom I mot upect; he having oberv'd me frequently to go to your Chamber, and that too ometimes at uneaonable hours: I know her to be an old Makebate that is always ready to thrut her Noe every where. Beides, he is a particular Acquaintance of my Mother's, who erves her with Sallets and Herbs at a cheap rate. I believe it to be true, aid the Marhal, much vex'd; but 'tis abolutely neceary to break off our Intercoure even at this very intant, and therefore I charge you to forbear coming to me any longer for very weighty reaons. Not that I ever hall have the leat averion to you, but on the contrary, I hall Love you better for the future than ever I did before, and I will continue to ee you from time to time incognito; but o, that no body hall have the leat knowledge of it; in the mean while take this, aid he, (putting ome Mony into her hands)
make the bet ue of it you can till we meet again. But above all things I expect you hou'd make me a olemn promie, that you will carry matters on with dicretion, and that you will not peak a word of it to any Peron living, but let all be bury'd in ilence, otherwie you'll have caue to repent it.

The Laundres having given her conent to every Article which the Marhal propos'd, was jut ready to leave the Room, but before he was well got out of the door, he turn'd back again aying: But, Sir, if I hou'd prove with Child, what mut I do then? Who will Father it? Who knows but uch a thing may happen? Go, go, my Child, anwer'd the General laughing, that fear is is needles, as for what I have done to thee; if ome body ele has got thee one, thou mut lay it to his charge; for my part, I wah my hands, knowing my elf innocent as to that particular. Certainly, Sir, you are in a very pleaant Humour, reply'd the young Laundres, have not you taken true pains for it, that you are o willing to excue your elf? Yes, my Dear, aid the Marhal, but I am ure of what I have done. You have done as much as others can do, reply'd he, going out of the Room; Adieu, till the next merry meeting. And art thou ure of that,
aid the Marhal? O, cry'd he, making a ign with her hands, I mut take my chance for that.

Monieur de Boufflers having thus got rid of his Laundres, he pretended to his Landlady that he was oblig'd to tay away from his Lodgings for ome mall time, but in effect to have another hard by Mademoielle de Grammont: He gave orders to all his Servants, that if Judith hou'd come to enquire for him, they hou'd tell her, that he was gone out of the Town. His next buines was, to purue with all poible care his Courthip to Mademoielle de Grammont, Who, by one of her Gentlewomen who was related to the Marhal's Landlady, had got ome notice of his lat Adventure? How, aid he very wittily, Monieur Boufflers, are you o hard put to it, as to be forc'd to take up with your Laundrees, who publickly proclaim your Feats, and boat of uch a Gallant as you? If I were to advie you, provided you will give me leave to be o much your Friend, I wou'd have you break off this Intrigue as peedily as poibly you can. Madam, anwer'd the Marhal with ome Confuion, You are every thing what you pleae to me: I am entirely at your dipoal; I confes my Crime, which is no longer to be hid, ince it is come to your Knowledge. I mut own I had ome engagement
with my Laundres, who was not worthy of it; But what wou'd you have me ay, my incomparable Lady, but that a Man is a Man in pite of all his endeavours to the contrary. If I were o happy as to have a Spoue, my Fleh wou'd not be o Rebellious, and I hou'd not want means to appeae its fury. But now I am troubl'd with a continual itching which‚ÄîHere Mademoielle interupting him with a mile: But aid he Monieur Boufflers, you know what our Holy Fathers teach us, that it is better to Marry, than to do wore. And ince it is a Sin to have an amourous Commerce with other Mens Daughters or Wives, why don't you provide one for your own elf, that may be able to bridle the Lut of your Fleh, and take away the caue of uch frequent Inurrections? What advice I give you is both for your own and the publick Good. 'Tis very true, my adorable Lady, aid the Marhal kneeling before her, But if I durt take the boldnes to tell you, that if‚Äî Go on, go on, Sir in what you were about to ay, cry'd the young fair Lady, I give you free leave to peak; What are your Words topt in their very paage? I will take courage then, reply'd he with a loud Voice, Since you give me leave to explain my Thoughts. Yes very well, Sir, reply'd Mademoielle
with a erious Countenance, I have not laid my Hand upon your Mouth, as the Pope does to his Cardinals; you have full liberty to deliver your mind.

p.q: Having receiv'd aurance from your own Mouth Mademoielle, reply'd the Marhal, that I hall not offend you in freely dicloing the Sentiments of my Heart, I mut tell you that I hou'd certainly believe my elf the mot happy of all Mortals upon Earth, if Heaven had deign'd me for a Spoue o accomplih'd as your elf; but being always mitrutful of my good Fortune, I am afraid that this o much wih'd for happines, will not fall to my hare. It is a coniderable time, ince I firt tiffl'd this thought in my Heart, without daring to let it come to light, for fear it might be in any wie dipleaing to you. Pardon therefore at this time the boldnes I take thus to lay open to your view, even the inmot recees of my Heart, which will at leat eae it of ome part of its pain, and don't refue to give one word in anwer, which hall be always mot dear and acceptable to me, provided it proceeds from your own Sweet Lips.

div.p:
Mademoielle de Grammont, being omewhat urpris'd at the ingenuous Confeion
of her Lover, and being willing at the ame time to atisfy him that he had no averion toward his Peron, made no difficulty to tell the Marhal with a mot charming Air; Sir If I were at my own Dipoal, I wou'd conult my own Heart as to what might be expedient for me to do in this Cae; But, you are not ignorant, that I am to be guided by my Kindred, epecially by my Brother the Abbot, who, without doubt will provide uch a Match for me, as he hall find uitable to his Inclinations. Beides, you know very well, that it wou'd be very unbecoming a young Virgin in my condition, to doe any thing of this nature diagreeable to the entiments of my Relations. I will not contradict you in this particular, Mademoielle, reply'd the Marhal, but at the ame time I hope you'll grant me, that your Kindred ought not to pretend to the dipoal of your Heart; You being the ole Mitres of it, as well as of the ret of your inclinations. Pray Sir, let us talk no more on this Subject, reply'd he not without ome diturbance; I have given you ufficient Reaons. I am then a very unfortunate Creature, reply'd Boufflers full of depair, in regard that I cannot obtain the favour to be heard o much as for one moment, by the Peron I adore, who ever
refues me the Liberty of declaring the real Sentiments of my Heart. I call all you Saints to witnes, whether ever any Sufferings were comparable to mine. I perceive very well, cry'd Mademoielle de Grammont laughing, that you are very much out of Order, good Sir, I believe it will be bet to end for a Phyitian, Alas! cruel fair one, cry'd the Marhal miling, you are the Phyitian, if you pleae, that can alone reto ‚Ä¢ e me to health, but at the preent you only apply Corroives to my Wounds intead of Balamicks. Is there any Concience in your Proceedings? Don't you believe that you mut be anwerable for this cruel Uage, and give account for all thoe Pains you have caus'd me to endure? If you hou'd make a real Confeion of it to your Father-Confeor, I cannot be perwaded that he wou'd grant you Abolution for o heinous a Crime. Nay, reply'd Medemoielle, if we hou'd acquaint our Father-Confeor with the flattering Expreions and Lies, which you Gentlemen are pleas'd to tell us, we hou'd e'n make a pretty Story of it: What Anwer wou'd thee Religious Men make us, but to ay, That thee, being Venial Sins of mall conequence, we may eaily be pardon'd in not believing you, who o eldom
or never peak truth, when you pretend to make Love? For ometimes you hall meet with one, who immediately runs deperate or mad; whilt another is jut at the point of Death, and talks of nothing but Daggers which are to pierce his Heart: Others are continually Whining and Pineing all in Tears, o that they can do nothing but igh and talk of their Sufferings and Pains, which (as they give out) can never ceae but with their lat Breath. This is a hort Panegyrick upon your Love-Paion, which is always Languihing, and is Variouly repreented by you to erve your turn, accordingly as you hall find a fit opportunity.

Very well then, Mademoielle, aid the Marhal, feigning to be urpris'd at the Learned words of his Mitres, That the Pains of Love did not ceae till Death; And who can pretend to procure the Death of o Powerful a Deity? Marriage, Marraige, Sir, reply'd the fair Lady: I ay, the Conjugal Union will quench the mot violent Flames of Concupicence, and annihilate their force. What is become of thoe mot violent Paions, what of thoe great efforts of Love, which once appear'd in our great Monarch Lewis XIV. towards a la Valiere, a Montepan, and everal others, whom
he has quite abandon'd ince, as if he never had had any knowledge of 'em. Madam de Maintenon told me the other Day, that the King wou'd not o much as uffer 'em to be poken of in his preence. Alas! take my Word for it, there is nothing in this Sublunary World, but what is continually ubject to change. You ought not, Madam, anwer'd the Marhal, to reflect upon thee matters at your Age; this part of Morality is too olid for you at this time, to take up your Thoughts: You ought rather, to endeavour to make ue of the advantage of your blooming Years, in making one of your Adorers happy by the weet enjoyments of the Matrimonial State, to your mutual Comfort and Satisfaction. This is that which you ought to apply your elf to, without loeing one Moment longer.
div.l: Fair CLYMENE, improve your lucky Day;
div.p: [continu'd he inging.]
div.l: For Time flies fat, and Pleaures glide away.

p.q:
No matter for that, Sir reply'd Mademoielle de Grammont, we eldom have occaion to repent of having been too Wie or Dicreet. Do you believe that there is any real Felicity in the enjoyment of the Pleaures of this World? I can aure you,
that I never thought my elf les happy, than ince the time I left the Nunnery, where I was before, and where I enjoy'd a mot delightful Tranquillity both in Body and Mind, which in the management of Worldly Affairs, is continually ditracted by a thouand troubleome Contingences, which are daily incident to us poor Mortals, during our abode in thee Terretrial Manions. If my Brothers had not engag'd me to come and live with an Aunt of mine, who upon her Death-Bed made me promie her to Marry, I wou'd never have left it, O cry'd the Marhal embracing her, I am overjoy'd my mot lovely Creature, to undertand from your own Mouth, that you are reolv'd to Marry. What a happy Man will he be, added our General tranported with paion, who hall be the poeor of o incomparable a Lady? Therefore I mut go to conult the Oracle at Verailles (Madam Maintenon) to know whether this hall be my Detiny.

div.p:
Mademoielle de Grammont, who very well undertood his meaning as to this familiar Oracle which is very advantagious to its Favourites, cou'd not forbear laughing, and aid he to her Lover, You have free acces to this Sibyl without the aitance of any Mediator; you are more in her favour
than any one at Court; and no Quetion, he will tell you your Detiny without diimulation. May Heaven be propitious to me, I will go to conult her to morrow, Madam, anwer'd the Marhal de Boufflers, but it mut not be without your good Company, you hall alo learn your Detiny from this Oracle. That is the leat of my Concerns, reply'd Mademoielle de Grammont, carelesly, let Heaven dipoe of me as it thinks fit. O what a good Chritian! O what a pretty Child is this! aid the General, who leaves her elf altogether to the dipoal of Providence; there are but very few Perons in our Age, who are o careful of the Welfare of their Souls, and are dipos'd to take o good a Reolution. I mut attribute it in ome part to your Holy Mothers, the relines, among whom you have been educated, and who have inpir'd you with thee noble Sentiments. When I ee the Abbot de Bonne Avanture, I will not forget to acquaint him, how prudent and devout you are. I uppoe he will not be dipleas'd at it, Sir, reply'd the young Lady, as he was jut ariing to meet Mademoielle de Pontriant, one of her Acquaintance, who was come to give her a Viit.

The manner of Converation being in an intant chang'd with the Company, they began to be much more Jovial than before: For this Young Lady, being of a very frolickome Humor, wou'd needs divert 'em with a Story of a Servant-maid of hers, who being Heart-ick for a Sweet-Heart, the young Lady told her, Yes, yes, Echalotte, he will hortly come to ee thee: For I have been told, that he is already upon the Road, coming on purpoe to give thee a Viit. I pray God that the Holy S. Miclotie may afely conduct him hither. Do you ay o, Madam, reply'd the poor Wench, and holding up her Hands,
I will, aid he, ay a Pater Noter and an Ave Mary for him; which he actually did, and that too, with o much Innocence and Devotion, that every one was amaz'd at it. A little after he came to her elf, I left her, and they tell me ince, that he is pretty well recover'd.

The Marhal de Boufflers and Mademoielle de Grammont, looking at one another, laugh'd heartily at the Story of Mademoielle de Pontriant, who having diverted 'em for ome time longer, with uch like Adventures, took her Leave of our Lovers, whom he left at liberty to renew their former Dicoure. But the Marhal having oon after,
recall'd to memory his intended Journey to S. Cyr, left his Mitres, and went directly from thence to pay a Viit to Madam Maintenon: No ooner had he enter'd this Lady's Cloet, introduc'd by Siter Nicolle, but, aid he, Madam, I am come hither to conult you, no otherwie than an Oracle or ome great Deity, whoe Power it is to dipoe of me, my whole Detiny being olely put into your Hands. Pray, tell me, whether I hall be happy or unhappy, and whether I hall obtain for my Spoue a certain charming Lady of your Acquaintance, who relies upon your Deciion of her Fortune, looking upon you as her Governing Planet, from whence he expects nothing but a favourable Apect and benign Influences. And, pray Sir, reply'd Madam Maintenon, who is this Peron, who puts o much Confidence in me? I'm extremely oblig'd to her for the good Eteem he has of that mean Ability I have to erve her, but I am not o skilful as you imagine, I did not at my Birth receive that Gift of Prophecy. How, Madam, reply'd the Marhal, can you be ignorant of that Beauty, over which you have o powerful an Acendant? he does nothing without your prudent Counels, and you are the very Soul that guides her
Inclinations. Don't you know Mademoielle de Grammont?
Yes, Sir, aid the Lady, he is a very charming Peron, for whom I have a mot ingular Repect, and whom I hou'd be ready to erve upon all occaions. Is it her then, continu'd he, my dear Child, whom you are deirous to have for your Spoue. Truly I ee you are endu'd with a dicerning Judgment; I can aure you, that you have made a Choice not unbecoming your elf, for, beides that he is vatly rich, he is very well look'd upon at Court, for her extraordinary Endowments, which make her to be admir'd by every one. Madam, aid Boufflers, with omewhat of Impatience, all my Felicity depends upon your Favour, in regard that he has ent me to you to know whether this Match is like to be properous on my ide. She referrs her elf entirely to your Determination. You are in Jet, Sir, reply'd Madam de Maintenon, with a mile, you peak thus to atisfie your own Inclinations, which are wholly bent upon this Lady. Mademoielle de Grammont is a young Lady, who has a great deal of Wit, and perhaps told you this, to free her elf from your amorous Importunities. Believe me, Sir, he her elf is not detitute of Subtilty, he knows
very well what he has to do, without conulting me as her Oracle If, nevertheles, it lies in my Power to do you any Service with her, I am ready to do it with all my Heart, for everal Reaons. You mut manage her oftly and by degrees, he being of a weet and quiet Dipoition, don't overload her with Complements, as it is natural for you Gentlemen to do when you make Love to Women, without conidering, whether it be uitable to their Humour or not. I give you this Advice, as to a Friend, for whom I have ome concern. You know that you have the Repute to have play'd the Gallant a little too much, in your younger Years, and perhaps omething of it may be come to her Ears, as well as your late Adventure with the Laundres. She has given me once already a Touch as to that, reply'd the Marhal, but I am in good Hopes, that this unfortunate Accident will not make any great Impreion upon her Mind, and that he will bury in Oblivion the ret of my Amorous Trepaes, which I have unluckily committed in former Time. I much quetion it, Sir, reply'd the Lady, for he has always been educated among the Religious relines, the trictet Order in all France, epecially as to enual Pleaures, upon
which they look as o many Monters, that trive to devour Mankind, and to exclude 'em from Paradie. If you are dextrous enough to ininuate your elf into her affection, you are a happy Man; but you'll find the Conquet not very eaie. Above all things, I wou'd advie you, to deal incerely with her, he being a great Lover of that Vertue. I will endeavour, Madam, reply'd the General (having made firt a profound Reverence to her) to follow your wie Counel, and I will trive to gain the Affections of this Beauty, by all the mot incere and honourable means that can be found out. Madam de Maintenon having given ome further Advice to the Marhal, concerning his Marriage, and receiv'd his humble Thanks; he return'd to his Lodgings, where he began to meditate upon the event of his intended Marriage.

The next Day, after Dinner, he gave a Viit to Mademoielle de Grammont, who being jut a little before, gone to S. Cyr, and he not thinking it convenient to interrupt the Dicoure that might pas between this fair Lady and the Abbes, taid at ome ditance from the Abby. But he making a longer tay than he expected, and being on Hore-back, follow'd only by one Footman, <> took a turn in the Wood of Vincennes,
He had not been there long, e're he epy'd the Livery of Madam de Maintenon afar off; and not quetioning but that his Mitres was with her in the ame Coach, which went on with a very low pace, he, with a Hand-gallop, advanc'd nearer to 'em. Mademoielle de Grammont being plac'd at the ame ide where he came, let the Glaes down, and aluted him not without Bluhing; which Madam de Maintenon having immediately taken notice of, he made a Sign to our Marhal, to make him enible, that this udden Emotion cou'd not be interpreted otherwie, than to his advantage. He oon undertood the meaning of the Sibyl of Verailles, and being unwilling to urprie his Mitres, he look'd another way, as if he had not oberv'd this change of her Colour.

Madam de Maintenon, who was ready upon all occaions to econd his Love, told him; And what, Sir, makes you come hither? What is it that enforces you thus to wander o far in this Solitude? Perhaps 'tis ome amorous Melancholy, which has carry'd you into this Wood. You have gues'd it to a Hair's Breadth, Madam, cry'd he, and I protet to you upon my Faith, That nothing ele has brought me into this olitary and delightful Place. The Marhal, aid Mademoielle de Grammont,
interrupting their Dicoure, is always employ'd in ome new Love-Intriegue or another, in which he eeks his Diverion. 'Tis true, Mademoielle, reply'd Madam de Maintenon, he was made both for Love and Wars, and his noble Heart, Hero like, triumphs over both. Madam, reply'd Boufflers, in a very ubmiive and repectful manner, you that determine all Matters before you, with equal Skill and Goodnes, pray don't deny me Jutice: My Heart is like a Slave, that is accutom'd to wear Chains without regret. 'Tis no hard matter to conquer it, provided the Peron who attacks it, be like Mademoielle, whoe force it is not able to reit. You always are very gallant, Sir, aid Madam de Maintenon; and what do you think of him, my Dear? Madam, reply'd the fair Lady, I cannot think otherwie than that you judge in favour of the Marhal: 'Tis a Character peculiar to a gallant Man, to be always tender and complaiant in Lady's Company; and tho' he hou'd not be o in good earnet, yet he ought at leat out of a Principle of Gallantry, to make 'em believe o. But, as to flatter my elf o far, as to believe that it is in my power, by any means, to diturb the Repoe of Monieur Bouflers, I am well atisfy'd 'tis much
beyond what I can pretend to. Ha! what do you ay, Mademoille, cry'd the Marhal tranported to that degree, that Madam de Maintenon cou'd not forbear laughing, there never was any Peron living upon the Face of the Earth, who cou'd be more capable of making me unfortunate, than your elf? Pray look, Mademoielle, reply'd the Abbes of St. Cyr, in a very obliging manner, what effects your Charms have produc'd upon the Marhal: Alas! how much alter'd he is ince the time that‚Äî 'Tis very true, reply'd the Marhal de Boufflers, I don't ret Day or Night; and from that very moment that I began to be in Love, I found my Heart o continually ditracted and tormented, that all whatever I felt before in my Life-time, is not comparable to it. I know who is the caue of it, and it's for this reaon that I cherih thoe Evils, which, when I rightly conider 'em, cannot but be very charming to me. As far as I ee, aid Madam de Maintenon, you are both happy and unhappy at the ame time, and I don't quetion but that Mademoielle, who is all Goodnes, will take ome care not to let you uffer o much for the future: She will undoubtedly take ome Method or another to make you more fortunate. Do you not give your Conent to what I ay,
incomparable Lady, added Madam de Maintenon, taking our young Lady by the Hand? I'll ee, I'll ee, Madam, reply'd he with a Smile, I believe the Pain which the Marhal talks of, not to be o violent, but that he may have a little patience, till ome body ele apply a Remedy to appeae it; I am not o skilful in giving Relief to uch Gentlemen as he, who are continually in want of the Aitance of fair Ladies.

The Marhal wou'd certainly have made ome gallant and agreeable Reply to his Mitres, if Madam de Maintenon and Mademoielle de Grammont, had not both tept out of the Coach, on purpoe to take a Walk upon the Gras, which was very green and pleaant at that Seaon of the Year. Boufflers walk'd contantly by his fair Mitrees ide, to whom he told a thouand tender and paionate Things. At lat he entreated 'em to go and refreh themelves at a fine Country-Seat hard by, belonging to a particular Friend of his, which he made ue of his own. But Madam de Maintenon not being willing to go, they agreed to defer it till another Opportunity. The care of the Abby, which lies altogether upon me, aid he, after a very devout manner, (not to peak now of the Engagements I have to ue a great deal of Complaiance to the King,
who has his particular Humours) does not allow me o much time, as to think of Pleaures: Not but that he is a very good natur'd Prince, but his Majety very often inits upon doing Things which I hou'd not approve of, if I had the liberty to explain my felf; o that being frequently oblig'd to pas a great many things by in ilence, it caues me many a vexatious Hour. I cannot but admire at what you ay, Madam, reply'd Mademoielle de Grammont, the whole World looking upon you as the mot fortunate Lady in Europe. You are belov'd by a great Monarch, who does nothing without your Advice, and who does every thing to pleae you: In aying thus, I avouch nothing but what is allow'd of by all the World. O Mademoielle, aid this Lady, conider, that all that gliters is not Gold. I often think of a certain Proverb, which was in ue a long time before I was born, and which I find to hold true till, That no Condition of Men is free from Troubles and Anxieties. It is very true, what the Princes de Conde told me the other Day, That a mean Shepherdes, often receives more atisfaction in the enjoyment of her innocent Pleaures, than the greatet Lady in the Kingdom.
It is not always Worldly Grandeur and Lutre, that makes us happy in this Life; or that we ought to look upon as our Soveraign Good. I don't diagree with you, Madam, anwer'd the young Lady, but I hope you will not alo deny, but that an eminent Station in this World, is very agreeable to Mankind. And I tell you, Mademoielle, aid the Marhal abruptly, to put an end to your moral Doctrin, which carries us too far from our purpoe, that of all the Pleaures that this Life affords, Love is the weetet; I mean when one Loves incerely, and is belov'd again; for if Love be not reciprocal, I am not for it, as knowing that it is o far from being delightful, that it is nothing ele but a continual Miery. All the World is for Pleaure, reply'd Madam de Maintenon; we Mortals carce think of any thing ele, not conidering that both they and we pas away like a Dream, and that one day we mut all be accountable for our Actions; and you Gentlemen of the Blade, don't think that you will be exempted from it. Good faith! anwer'd the Marhal with a great deal of indifferency, I don't overload my elf with thoe things, I lay 'em all, as often as I go to Confeion, upon my Father-Confeor's Back, and that is broad
enough to bear 'em. This good Religious Father, as oon as he finds the Pence come in, tells me always, that he will find out means to cleane me from my Sins, that I hall appear as white as Snow, tho' I were as black as a Chimney-tock before.

p.q:
You are very happy in your Father-Confeor, reply'd the Lady, for our Father la Chaie does not tell us o: He talks of nothing ele to us but Penances and Mortifications, and at lat of all perhaps he will tell you, We are uncertain what will become of us. But pray where cou'd you find out uch a Father-Confeor, who is o favourable to you Soldiers, who eldom believe Heaven or Hell? Madam, reply'd Boufflers, I found him out by good chance; yet he belongs to the Profes'd Houe of Jeuits in Paris, and for my part, I was never o curious as to enquire after his Name, provided he does but grant me Abolution of what they call Sin, I don't trouble my Head any farther. This is truly living like a Cavalier, anwer'd Mademoielle de Grammont, laughing outright; Madam may very well ay, that you Officers of the Army, believe neither Heaven nor Hell. O Lord! Sir, into what Errors do you run
head-long; the very thought of it makes me tremble: O Mademoielle, aid Boufflers, we are not o irreligious as you imagine; 'tis a ort of vulgar Error which has prevail'd throughout the World to our diadvantage. I hope to ee Heaven as oon as one of your mot Religious Zealots. I have a good tock of Indulgences, which I have pick't up in all Parts of Europe, enough to erve my elf and all my Dragoons. Make much of 'em Sir, anwer'd Madam de Maintenon, for they may tand you in good tead, when you are in Purgatory, where you may be in danger to burn all your life-time, without a good Preervative. I mean your Soul, which will never perih. By my Faith! Madam, you frighten me, aid the Marhall, teping ome paces backward, pray let us talk no more of thee everlating Flames, they put me in a fright: Thee little pretty Devils that poes our Hearts, are far more agreeable. I acknowledge it, Sir, reply'd the Lady, but thee are often the occaion of our eternal Sufferings. In the mean while let us implore Heaven to preerve us from them, and let us alter the Scene, for I perceive that this too much diturbs you.

div.p:
Our Ladies then being again gone into their Coach, and our Marhal having remounted his Hore, they return'd to St Cyr; from whence Monieur Boufflers accompany'd his Mitres to her own Houe, where having taken his leave of her, he went to up that evening with ome of his Brother-Generals. They having oberved a certain palenes in his countenance ever ince he courted Mademoielle de Grammont; the Count de Montal, who was among the ret at the Table, began thus to addres himelf to the Company. If Men were ubject to the Green-icknes, I hould be apt to believe, that the Marhal de Boufflers was troubled with it. But ince this Ditemper is not incident to us Men, I will peak no more of that. I am rather inclin'd to believe, aid the Duke de Villeroy, that it is his Maiden-head, which ending up ome Vapours to his Brain caues this palenes in his Face: 'Tis high time to marry him, let his Ditemper hould prove mortal. It is a great while, Gentlemen, reply'd the Marques de Boufflers, ince my Maiden-head is flown up into the Air, and if it be there till, I believe it to be a good way off. The Devil take me if that be the caue of my palenes; or ele I am trangely deceiv'd in my elf, for I am ure I have given it over and over a thouand times: if I hould hew you a Lit of all my Mitrees, you would be convinc'd of the
truth of it. O the very thoughts of it tickle my fancy at this very moment, continued he with a paionate Air. I am tranported with the very conceit of it, Sir, Sir, aid the Count de Montal, addreing himelf to the Duke de Villeroy, and pulling him by the leeve, let us deal a little more charitably with our friend, I ee his colour change, our dicoure may put his Animal Spirits into uch a ferment, as to make him faint away: Some Wine here, aid he to one of his Footmen, ome Wine here for the Marhal de Boufflers: come, Sir, drink to your own inclinations. Well then, reply d the General, pulling off his Hat; Here is a Health to that charming Beauty which I admire. You hould rather have aid, reply d Valleroy laughing, a Health to all thoe fair Ladies you love, for I am of opinion, that you have a good many of them in all Parts; and I am alo apt to believe, that ince you have erved the King, you have never been preent at the beieging of any Town, but that at the ame time you have conquer'd a Heart and forc'd it to pay you Hommage.

Sir, reply'd the Marhal, you are pleas'd to honour me beyond my deerts, in enrolling my Name among thoe of your great Conquerors: My amorous and warlike Expeditions are neither of them o coniderable as you think fit to repreent 'em, and my mot glorious Love-exploits have terminated in the Conquets of certain pretty
young Damels, who were not undeerving of what pains I took for 'em. But I have now laid aide all thee former light Engagements; I am reolved to be wier for the future, and wholly to devote my elf to one Mitres, whom I intend for my Spoue, if I can attain to that good fortune. I know that the ighs of an old Lover eldom find good reception among Ladies. They are commonly look d upon as your ancient Slaves, who have nothing to do but to wear their Fetters, rarely meeting with the lucky minute.

p.hi: Ha! Now you peak of the critical minute,
p.U:
aid the Duke de Villeroy; if I had been inclined to make ue if it, a very fair opportunity preented it el three or four days ago, when walking over the new Bridge, a pretty young. Fan-flap, pulling me by the Sleeve, whiper d me, Have you a mind to be merry to night, my Lord: I had a great mind to do it, but‚Äî
That But, Sir, aid the Marques de Boufflers, laughing, stopt your paage. Yes indeed o it did, reply d the Duke, I was afraid I hould be pepper d off for all my Life-time: We often pay at too dear a rate for uch orts of Commodities. Nevertheles, he was the bet humour d Wench that ever I aw. Surely, anwered the Count de Montal, if he were o charming a Creature, I wonder how you could forbear; I believe you were fain to put a great force upon your inclination: I ll lay you a Wager, if the Marhal de Boufflers had been
in your place, he would not have been o cautious as you; and I am apt to believe, that this perhaps may be the caue of his pale countenance. No, indeed, Sir, reply'd he very eriouly, it was never my humour to meddle with uch ort of Cattel, I had always an averion to them becaue I cannot endure to go into the Country upon that account. If all Mens tomachs were turn'd againt 'em as much as mine is, they would be all thrown over the Bridge into the Seine, without taking the trouble to end them to the Plantations in Canada, and other places, where they communicate their petilent Ditemper to thoe poor Wretches who have the misfortune to deal with 'em.

div.p:
By this time the intended Match between the Marhal de Bouflers and Mademoielle de Grammont, began to make a great noie among the peeple of the greatet quality at Court. Our two Lovers frequently received Viits of the Ladies, where the chief entertainment was of nothing but Gayety and gallant Diverions: Repartees, one of the bet exercies of Wit, were not wanting in thoe Intercoures, which ometimes were put o cloe, that it turn'd to ridiculing one or another of the Company; and tho ome of them were very mart, yet were they o well manag'd, that none could take any exception. One day, among the
ret, the Count de Surlaube had his hare of it. He had marry'd Mademoielle de... Daughter to the Marchiones de Bree, who was not above 12 years of age when he was engag'd to her Husband: A very tender age indeed, to endure the fatigues (epecially the firt night) of a Husband of uch a bulk as the Count was, he being one of the fattet and mot robut Gentlemen in France. The Marhal de Boufflers, having a mind to divert the Company, and addreing himelf to the Count ask'd him: How he could poibly overcome o difficult an enterprize? Sir, anwer'd the Count, As great a General as you are, I am very well convinc'd, that if you had been in my place, you would have ooner choe to undertake the Conquet of one of the mot coniderable Forts in Flanders.

At thee words all the Ladies that were preent, burt out aloud into a'laughter. But the Count, who is a very pleaant Companion, thus continu'd his Dicoure; Monieur Boufflers, we hall have hortly the opportunity to ee which way you'll go about it; if you'll permit me to teach you ome Leons, as to this particular, I only deire your leave to hold the Candle, whilt you perform the operation. If you hould perhaps be deficient in ome formalities, I promie you I will be your Aitant, if it may be without offence to Madamoielle de
Grammont, who could not forbear miling at it. Signior Count, reply'd Monieur Boufflers, You are come to that age that you cannot but be enible, that all you are able to do in uch a cae as this, is only to ait me with your good Counel. And if we may give credit to the common report, you could not at that time pas the Ditch without a great deal of difficulty; Nay, I have heard it affirmed for truth, that you were not able to make your elf Mater of the Counter carp till ix months after the Trenches were open'd. If this be true, I mut confes it is one of the mot famous Sieges that we have known of; and if you had not received Succors from the Relations of the Countes your Lady, it is a great quetion to me, whether you would not have been oblig'd to raie the Siege. The Countes, who was preent during the Contet, bluht at this Dicoure, but this Colour (which is o natural to all civil Women) being a little gone, he did like the ret, who laugh'd all as heartily as they could.

The Count then reuming the Dicoure: To compleat your Diverion, Ladies, aid he, I will give you an exact Hitory of what pat between my Spoue and me the firt night after our Wedding. The Marchiones de Choii a very grave Matron, told him, That the Ladies would not be againt it, provided he would be cautious in offering any thing
that might be offenive to the fair Sex. Ladies, aid the Count, In cae I tell you nothing but what is true, and that I give you a faithful Relation of the whole Hitory, I don't quetion but you will pardon the ret. The Countes, my Spoue, who is here preent hall engage for me as to that particular; and I give her free leave to ilence me, if I peak one word of untruth. Well, well, let us have it then, unanimouly cry'd the Ladies, except Mademoielle de Grammont, who being the only Maiden Gentlewoman in the Company, whiper'd her Lover the Marhal de Boufflers, in the Ear, That he was afraid that this tory would make her uneaie; that he foreaw the Count was preparing to give a relation o circumtantial as to thoe matters, as would make her colour rie in her Face, becaue he was upon the point of being marry'd her elf, and might perhaps be ubject to the ame frailties. But Monieur de Boufflers bid her have a good Heart, telling her, My dearet Child, you mut be inur'd by degrees to the hardhips and toils of War, your time draws near when you mut begin to carry Arms, wherefore I would be glad to ee you undertake the task with contancy and brave reolution; that when you ee the Enemy making an Aault, nothing may terrify you. Let us hear, continued he, what the Count will ay: the good Counels of a valiant Captain who has undergone the toils of Cupid,
Wars, often furnih us with a piece of Morality, which may have more influence as to the converion of a fair Lady, than all the inipid moral Doctrine of a Sermon preach'd by Father Craet.

Monieur de Boufflers is much in tke right on't, aid the Count, he has not betow d all his time in burning of Villages: he has learnt by experience, as well as my elf, how to give good doctrine to young people. I am of opinion, added he, peaking to Mademoielle de Grammont, that when you have made one Campaign under him, you will be skilful enough not to tand in need of my Intructions: Mademoielle de Grammont gave no other anwer to the Count, but by a Smile, which appear'd more eloquent at that time than all the Sermons of Father Bourdalou. The Marhal, her Lover, was o charm'd with her Modety, that he could not forbear to rob her of a Kis. Soft, oft, aid Madam de Tilladet, you will have playing time enough; a Fire that burns too fierce is not lating; a moderate paion is always the mot contant and durable. By my faith, Madam, aid Monieur Bouffiers, we are only making Matches now, that when the day appointed for bombarding the Place comes, every thing may be in a readines. Don't you know that I love Expedition; if I hould march into the Field, and hould find but one Nail wanting in my Train of Artillery, I
hould be tark mad: Then turning himelf to Mademoielle de Grammont, his beloved Mitres, whom he embrac'd; and aid he, I only deire this one thing of you, that you be willing to receive the directions of your General. The firt Attack is commonly fierce, but let not the ight of a little blood dimay you; every mall wound we receive in the Wars is not mortal. If Love does wound us ometimes he is as careful in healing of us; and it was not without great reaon, that Moliere nam'd one of his Plays, Love the Phyician. The Ladies, who were dipos'd to laughing, having ilenc'd Monieur Boufflers, that they might be diverted with the Story the Count had promis'd to tell 'em: I am content, my Ladies, aid he; and as for Mademoielle de Grammont and I, we will endeavour to profit by it as much as poibly we can.

The Countes, my Wife, was but twelve years of Age, aid the Count, when I marry'd her. She being o very young had not the opportunity to learn thoe things which he has been taught ince, and which he has now at her fingers ends, tho he be not now above eighteen. Our Nuptial Feat was celebrated at the Marchiones de Bree's, my Wife's Mother. About an hour before we were to go to Bed, I went up into the Chamber where we were to lie that
night, to inpect the Nuptial Bed which was prepared for us, and after I had carefully examined every thing, with all the Circumpection imaginable, I returned to my Spoue, whom I had left in the Hall among our Guets. The hour being come, when we were to go to bed, Wax-tapers were lighted, and the Gentlemen and Ladies having taken their leave, went every one to their repective Lodgings. Some of the Ladies at their departure, whiper'd omething, I know not what, in my Spoues Ear, which I never have been able to learn ince, neither from them, nor her own Mouth. I confes that this put me into ome tudy for a few moments, conidering with my elf what mall progres I had made over the inclinations of this young Beauty, which eem'd to be born with a general averion to all Men. Her early years nevertheles gave me ome hopes to believe, that time, which ripens every thing, would overcome her tubborn Heart, and render it more flexible towards me, who omitted nothing to ininuate my elf into her good Will, but all in vain. At lat, my Spoue being undret, and laid in Bed firt, according to the uual Cutom, and I having put on my
Night-cap and Wedding Shirt, I ordered my Valet du Chambre to withdraw, and to hut the door after him, which he did. When I came nearer to the Bed, I heard omething tir underneath it, which made me upect, that ome body was not far off ready to play me a curvy trick; my Wife being as much urprized at it, as my elf, I run all in a fury towards the Table where my Sword lay, which having drawn out of the Scabbard, I puh d with it under the Bed, with a deign to kill any one that hould have hid himelf there. I was much tartled to ee the Cavalier du Blee come out from under the Bed, begging my pardon a thouand times for his uneaonable curioity, and telling me, That he would willingly have given 100 Pitoles, if he might have remain'd in the Pot where he had plac d himelf, if he could have done it without being dicovered. I confes I tood quite amaz'd, yet it was impoible for me to forbear laughing heartily, when I aw the Cavalier creeping out from under the Bed, as black as a Devil, without a Perriwig, and cover'd all over with dut. By my Faith, Sir, aid the Cavalier, you have a very good Noe that you could o oon mell out a Rat. Indeed I hould have been mightily
pleas'd to have been a Spectator of the Engagement, and a Witnes of your Victory, if it had not been for this unlucky accident, which has poil'd all. You mut know, aid the Count, that the Chamber-pot which tood under the Bed being overturn'd, I was about to take it up, when I epy'd the Cavaliers Foot, whom I told, That I did not want either a Second or an Umpire in the Duel I was going to fight; and, aid I to him, the Devil take me, if I had not run you thro and thro, if you had tay'd one moment longer without dicovering your elf: And o, continued the Count, I took my Gentleman by the Arm, and led him out of the Chamber Door.

p.q:
This Adventure being over, which I then look'd upon no otherwie than fatal to a Man in my circumtances, who was amorous even to a degree of Frenzy; the only comfort I had left, was the hopes of having now urmounted all the obtacles which could by any means obtruct my Happines in enjoying that young Beauty, which I had hitherto eteem'd as the mot difficult Conquet in the world. Being boy'd up with this aurance, I put out the Candles, I pull'd off my Breeches, and o into Bed I went, like a triumphant Hercules, who had defeated all his Enemies.
But no ooner was I laid down, but I found my elf alone, and thinking to take my Spoue in my Arms, I found nothing but the Sheets. I might call as long as I pleas'd, My Dearet where art thou? No body would anwer me o much as one word. Now you mut know that my Spoue had a certain Chamber-maid, who was her Confident, unto whom he had repreented the averion he had to Men, adding withal, That if he did not find out ome way or another to prevent her being overcome by her Husband that night, he would take a Reolution againt her own Life.

This Chambermaid was at lat mov'd with Compaion by the Tears of her Mitres, whom, like a young Chicken, he aw in the Claws of a Bird of Prey, in danger of looing her mot precious Jewel, which was her Virginity: her Name was Paquette, and being very ingenious at uch like Inventions, and willing to favour her Mitrees frailties, or rather fantatick humour, becaue he lov'd her very tenderly even from her Cradle, at lat dicover'd a private door which he found means to open at pleaure, and thro which our new marry'd Lady, under favour of the darknes, was convey'd out of the
Chamber, and hid her elf in a Hayloft, with a reolution, rather to dye than to uffer a Man to touch her.

Ladies, continued the Count, I leave it to your own conideration, to judge in what a condition I found my elf at that time.
