No Enchantment that ever I heard of, eem'd to me o urpriing as this, not knowing in the leat that there was a Sally-port behind my Bed, becaue the Chamber was all hung with Tapetry, and having taken all the precaution imaginable to look before hand with a Candle in all the corners of the Room. I was tark raving mad, my Reaon having quite left me,
p.U:
aid I, except the Devil plays his Pranks here. I cry'd out, and made a hideous noie like one in Bedlam. I call'd her a thouand times by her Name, but I might call long enough there was no body that anwer'd me. After I had made a ufficient Outcry, I roe at lat out of my Bed, imagining that he might perhaps have hid her elf underneath it, as the Cavalier had done before, whom I had hunted from thence. The Love and tender Affection which I had for her, were motives ufficiently trong to hinder me from taking up my Sword to fetch her out from thence,
as I had done before to the Cavalier; beides, I was enible, that I ought to make ue of more gentle Arms againt a young Virgin. Wherefore, after a great many vain Reflections, which almot ditracted my Brains, I got under the Bed my elf, where I crawl'd up and down for a coniderable time, without being able to find any thing, o that now I began tobelieve in good earnet, that there mut needs be Witchcraft in the cae. No ooner had the Count poke thee lat words, but his Spoue, and all the ret of the Ladies laugh'd very heartily. The Count perceiving how overjoyed they were at the recital of this Adventure, which had cot him o much vexation, and had almot put him quite beides himelf, if he had not had courage enough to bear up againt that Daemon, the Enemy of his Repoe, could not forbear to give 'em this Leon: Ladies, aid he, you are thoe familiar Spirits, which are ent from the other world on purpoe to damn and torment Mankind, and to make them dye a lingering Death. Whereupon the Ladies laugh'd as if they had been out of their Wits, and deired him to proceed in his Story. Ladies, reply'd Monieur de
Surlaube, we are far yet from the end of our Adventures. My unhappy Detiny
which perecuted me, or rather that detetable Daemon, that would make me dye the mot cruel and violent Death that can be imagined, did not top here. He had prepared for me thee ufferings, which were ufficient to end the mot contant and bravet Lover that ever was heard of in any amorous Hitory, to his Grave. The Marchiones de Bree, the Mother of my new married Spoue, being at lat awaken'd with the noie I made, came running all undret into my Chamber, asking me, Where her Daughter was? I anwer'd her, all overwhelm'd with Grief, That I did not know what was become of her; that he had diappear'd like a familiar Spirit, without knowing which way he went, except he were gone out thro the Chimney, becaue the Windows were very cloely hut up. This good Lady having undertood what I told her, was in an incredible Agony about her Daughter, verily believing, that the ame Chavalier, who had hid himelf under the Bed, had tolen her away: She was o much troubled at it, that he would certainly have run ditracted, if Paquette, the Chamber-maid, had not whiper'd her in the Ear, that he knew where he was. And where is he then? aid the Marchiones, taking the Candle
up her elf, Let us look in all corners.
Paquette having told her Mother, that he believed he had hid herelf in the Hayloft, we all went thither in Proceion, where we found her lying amidt the Hay, without any Cloaths, but her Wedding Shift. I leave it to your elves, Ladies, aid the Count, to gues, how much urpriz'd I was to ee her peepout of the Hay, like a Moue out of a Net of her own making, where he intended to have pent that whole night. The Marchiones her Mother taking her by the hand drew her away by force, he being very unwilling to to tir from thence, and having firt given her a good Reprimand, he re-conducted her into my Chamber.

p.q:
Being once more gone to bed, I pent great part of the night in endeavouring to perwade her out of this avage and barbarous Humour; but after I had endur'd the utmot fatigues, I found my elf where I was before. Her Innocence and Youth, which were the caue of her crime, were all my Comfort, in hopes that time would work out that, which was impoible for my Love and Paion to effect. I might repreent to her what I thought fit concerning the acred Tye of Matrimony, which had join'd us
together, and that, for the future, we were to be but one Fleh, according to the true Principles of Chritianity: That this was the mot acred and inviolable Knot of matrimonial and civil Society, and the only one in which conited all the Pleaure and Tranquillity that we Mortals are capable of enjoying upon Earth. I did not forget to produce a thouand Examples of young Virgins, who having been married at the ame age, had before the years end brought forth the fruits of their tender Love, in having honour'd their Husbands with Children, which were look'd upon as the Pledges of Conjugal Love, and as certain Bleings from Heaven. All thee Reflections were in vain, and made no more impreion upon her Mind, than if he had heard a Fanatick, or Mountebank, making an Harangue.
p.U: aid Monieur de Boufflers, let us leave thee moral Reflections to the Priets: Father Bourdalou takes care to furnih the Ladies with 'em in his Sermons: Let us hear the end of your Story.

p.q:
Whatever pains I took, continu'd the Count, to obtain from this inhumane Creature the lat favour, it was all to no manner of purpoe, o 15 days were pent in vain Attacks; and the more Bravery
and Eagernes I hew'd to aault the Place, the oftner was I repuls'd with Vigor; the Governes of the Fort taking as much Pride in defending it, as the Vetal Virgins did heretofore in preerving the acred Fire. But pray oberve what another trick he plaid me to free herelf from my importunities. She having therefore again advied with Paquette, her Chambermaid, who is as unlucky as a Daemon, and more ingenious at a contrivance than Ariadne; this cured Megaera made her a Puppet about the ame bignes as my Wife; and, becaue I had been o cautious as to get the Key of that private door behind my Bed into my own Cutody, they had by omemeans or another procur'd a fale one, by the help of which, they intended to deceive me, tho I were as watchful as Argus. One night, uppoing that no body was with me in Bed, but this cruel fair One, and turning my elf towards her, I found in her place this Puppet, which they had taken care to dres up very neatly. Thus for everal nights together, my Wife was accutom'd to undres her elf before me, o that when I thought my elf mot ure of her, I found in her place a piece of Wood as cold as Ice.

p.hi: O Sir, not to interrupt your Dicoure,
p.U: aid Monieur Boufflers, this was mot convenient to quench your flame. 'Tis true, Sir, reply d the Count, but a Block of Wood is a very inipid thing for a paionate Lover. If you had been in my place, you would I believe, with all your Stratagems, Bombs, and Fire-works, have been put to a Non plus. You might have planted your Cannon, and fixt your Mortars, according to the mot exact Rules of the bet Ingineers of the Kindgom; you would have mis d your aim for all this, and that too, ome hundred paces beyond the mark; and if at lat you had not turn'd Fool you mut have had very good luck. Sir, reply'd Monieur Boufflers, the Art of War is of little ue in Expeditions of this nature. The Subtilty of a Fox, and the Nimblenes of a Cock, are ufficient qualifications for uch Exploits; thee will make the Pullets dance after their Pipe; take this Doctrine from me, Sir, as old an Engineer as you are. Sir, reply'd the Count, you are jut at the point of giving us ome proofs of your Bravery: Time and opportunity will quetionles inform us, with what skill you hall have brought your elf off thee Quick-ands, where the mot able Seamen have often uffer'd Shipwrack.

aid the Dutches of Artagnan, whilt all the ret of the Ladies were laughing out, and what iue had this fatal Adventure? Madam, anwer'd the Count, the end of the Story is, that it cot me a vat eries of cruel ufferings, which made me lead a languihing Life like a poor condemned Wretch, for the pace of ix months; inomuch that I was verily perwaded, that this time of Pennance ought infallibly to deliver me from the pains of Purgatory, if I hould be condemn'd to go thither after my death; for I give you my word for it, that all the torments of Hell cannot exceed thoe pains which we endure by the cruelty of a charming Beauty o much belov'd and admir'd as this unlucky Creature was by me, pointing with his finger to the Countes his Spoue, who laugh'd open-mouth'd, when he aw her Husband relate this Story with o much concern. But you have forgot my dear Huband, aid he, to tell us the circumtances of our Reconciliation. You are in the right on't, my dear Child, aid the Count, but give me but leave to cough, and to cleane my Lungs a little, and then Mr. Preacher will begin where he left off before.
Having thus uffered all this cruel uage which I have jut now related to you, and having taken no ret day or night for a coniderable time, I told my Mother-in-law frankly, and plainly, That I was reolved to give her her Daughter again, as good as I had found her, if by her authority, he could not prevail upon her to accommodate her entiments to the State of Matrimony. The Marchiones, being moved by my complaints, at lat reolved to call an Aembly of Ladies of her next Relations, and having given an account to 'em of her Daughters averion to the Conjugal Bed, and to all Men whatever, he order'd a mot magnificent Collation, which was to be the preparative of one of the mot famous General Councils that ever was held among Women. At lat, after the Doors of the Appartment, where thee Ladies were aembled were hut up cloe, the Defendant was call'd up to appear before her Judges, where he was examin'd concerning the preent tate of her natural Parts, to ee whether he were an Hermaphrodite, or whether he had ome other impediment, which might exclude her from the enjoyment of the Conjugal Union.

div.p:
All Parts thereabouts having been found in a very good condition, and conformable to the Rules of Anatomy, (according to the report made by a certain expert Matron, who was ent for on purpoe to ait at this Inquiition) and the Generation-box being found without blemih, they pat on to Interrogatories. The Marchiones, my Wife's Mother, being there preent in quality of my Lady Chief Jutice, demanded of her Daughter, What was the reaon that he refus'd to live as a marry'd Woman ought to do, with a Man whom Heaven and he had given her for her Husband; there being nothing wanting in her Peron which Nature had betow'd on the ret of her Sex for the bringing forth of Children; epecially ince the Count her Husband was a Man of a very coniderable Etate and Quality, decended from one of the mot ancient and noble Families in France. She added, That the hopes of begetting lawful Heirs, was the only motive that induc'd him to deire her in Marriage; there being otherwie a coniderable diproportion in their Age; that he grounded his opinion upon her being o young, and decended from a fruitful Family; for which two reaons, he thought himelf ure of Children that might inherit his Etate: And finally, that he was the lat of his Family, which was the chief conideration
that had made him reolve to marry at that Age. The poor Child anwer'd her Mamma, that the Count had o frightned her, that he would much rather go into a Nunnery, than to let that be acrific'd which was the mot precious to her in the World, meaning her Maiden-head. How! Daughter, what do you mean by this? aid her Mother, full of indignation. Explain your elf, what reaons have you for o doing? Mamma, anwer'd the young Countes, my Husband told me one day, I think it was jut the day before our Wedding, that he believ'd he hould not live long. And why o, reply'd her Mother. Becaue that he had‚Äîanwer d the young Lady: O Lord! Mamma, I dare not tell it. Speak out you Fool, cry'd the Marchiones, there is none but Women here. He told me, anwer d the Countes, that he had a certain Gut that would come out in... If it be o, Mamma, I cannot poibly lie with him, becaue I know not what it means. At thee words, all the Ladies fell a laughing as loud as they could for a coniderable time. But to come to the end of my Story, added the Count, my Mother-inlaw, and the ret of the Ladies who were there preent in Court as Aitants, did o tutor this ignorant Girl, and explained this Gut in Terms o lively
and natural to her, that the poor Child at lat was over-perwaded to acrifice her Maiden-Treaure, which he had hitherto o carefully preerv'd; o that after ix Months Marriage he was made a Wife: the Prodigy of our Age, and perhaps the mot extraordinary one that ever was heard of before.

The Count having finiht his Relation, Madam de Tilladet and the ret of the Ladies, taking the Countes de Surlaube on one ide, ask'd her, Whether her Husband had poke nothing but the truth as to all the circumtances of his Narrative. He has been very punctual, reply'd the Countes, laughing as loud as he could. My dear Child, aid Monieur Boufflers, addreing himelf to Mademoielle de Grammont; and how do you like this Story of the Gut? hall I be as unfortunate as the Count? I am devilih impatient, continu d he; if any thing like this hould happen to me, my Wedding-day would be that of my Funeral. Sir, reply'd Mademoielle pleaantly, if I thought I hould act with as good ucces as the Countes, I hould take it to be the greatet pleaure in the World to let you languih for ome time. She accompany'd thee words with o charming a mile, that the Marhal was eaily convinc'd, that at her Age he was not o ignorant as Madam de Surlaube had been,
and that whenever that time hould come, he would not top her Ears to his demands.

The Marhal anwer'd her by a thouand amourous looks, telling her, That he was not ignorant, what delight young Ladies would often take to play a piteful trick with their Gallants. I think, aid he, that 'tis much more excuable, when it proceeds from a Principle of Modety and Innocency, which is natural to o tender an Age. In uch a cae as this, I hould be o far from tormenting my elf about it, that on the contrary, I hould eteem it as the mot delicious and mot avory Dih Love can afford us: I hould then look upon my elf to be the Poeor of the whole tock of Charms and weet Fruits that Love is able to give to a Lover; and that I might flatter my elf, even to an aurance, that I was the firt who put the Plow into that ground, which I think to be the greatet, Charm peculiar to a Beauty that never aw day-light before. This is o great a rarity, continu'd the Marhal, in the Age we now live in, that uch a Mitres is to be accounted a Phoenix. Our modern Gallantry in ue among Ladies, is like an Academy of young Beauties, where at the Age
of 14 they are o well intructed in thee matters, that they will carce refue a good thing when 'tis once offer'd em.

p.U: aid the Count, de Surlaube. Monieur de Boufflers Morals tho omewhat remis, come very near the truth, and probability pleads trongly for what he has offered. Experience has ufficiently taught us, that he talks of it like a Mater, and that the Draught which he has given us of the Intreagues of the fair Sex is done to the Life. For my part, added he, I foreee already that he will have no reaon to complain of his Lady s cruelty, and that his Happines will be more compleat at the very beginning, than mine has ever been as yet; tho thanks to Heaven, I have no reaon to complain now of her, who made me uffer o much before. You ought to attribute your Felicity reply'd Monieur Boufflers, to the explication of the Story of the Gut, for without that, I believe your Lady would have been a Maid to this day.

div.p:
Monieur de Boufflers had carce poke thee lat Words, when a Page of Madamoielle de Grammont s came to advertie him, and his Lady, that Madam de Maintenon's Coach was at the door. This Lady had not een our Lovers for ome days lat pat; and as he of all the ret that were at Court, hew'd mot concern for their Happines, and had her
elf been the firt that poke in Monieur Bouffler's Favour to Mademoielle de Grammont; nothing was tranacted in carrying on the Match without her approbation. The Marhal and Madamoielle de Grammont, went immediately out of the Room to receive her at the Stair-head, he being accompany'd by the Abbot de Tellier, Brother to the late Marques de Louvois.

Madam de Maintenon at her coming into the Chamber, being overjoy'd to meet with o much good Company, all the Gentlemen and Ladies, of whom we poke before, entertain'd her with all the Courteie imaginable. The Marhal de Boufflers himelf preented a Chair to her, and the Marchiones de Maintenon having taken her Seat Nephew, aid he, (for o he was won't to call him) I have ome good News to impart to you. And what good News, pray Madam, aid the Marhal. I jut now came from Court, reply'd the Machiones, where the King told me, that his pleaure was, that thoe obtacles, which have hitherto obtructed your Match hould be removed, His Majety, added he, is reolv'd to beg in the Campaign very early and therfore will oon have occaion for your Service in Falnders. It is for this reaon that he will have the Marriage forthwith conummated, and that all hall be over in fifteen days. I am
very glad to bring you thee good tidings, that both you and Mademoielle de Grammont may take yorr meaures accordingly. I don't quetion but you are already o far advanced into your Mitres's favour, that he will not be diatisfied with this udden change. I know that young Ladies at her Age, are not o backward to tate thoe ecret enjoyments which Love offers; the firt night after Marriage, uppoing this to be true, I believe you both have an equal hare in this atisfaction.

Madam, anwered the Marhal, except I hou d differ from all the World, and that my Heart hou d be quite inenible; how cou'd I chooe otherwie than to be charm'd with the engaging allurements of uch a Peron as Mademoielle de Grammont. I am already all over in a flame, according to my natural dipoition, and this fire cannot but burn with great vehemency, when 'tis fed by an object more bright than the Stars. Give me leave, added he, looking upon Mademoielle de Grammont, with a very paionate Eye, give me leave, my mot Adorable, to peak what is due to your merits, and do you accompany my words with your charming miles and your weet and amorous glances, which being the interpreters of your Heart, may aure me of what your Tongue is unwilling to expres. The Mahral poke thee words with uch a grace and preence of mind, with o frank and becoming
an Air, that he was applauded by the whole Aembly; and his Mitres found her Heart aail'd by a thouand amorous tranports. The Eyes of this fair Lady, the faithful Interpreters of the tender paion and hamefac'dnes of a young Beauty, who always receives the carees of her Lover with ilence, becaue Modety requires it; made their addrees to him, giving him to undertand the mot ecret and incere motions of her Heart.

A Lover who is belov'd is Mater of the ecret of unfolding thee amorous Riddles, which are no mall addition to the variety of Love ports; o that if a Mitres will but favour that Peron with a mile, unto whom he has given her heart before, he needs not covet any thing more, to make him the happiet Man in the world. This was the condition in which the Marhal was at that time with Mademoielle de Grammout. The Marchiones de Maintenon, who was very expert in this noble Art, might eaily judge that her Nephew had no reaon to repent of the pains and trouble he had undergone for a Lady of that quality and merit as Mademoielle de Grammont was, whom he had firt brought into his acquaintance. And that which encreas'd her atisfaction, was, that he could now applaud herelf to
have been uccesful in the choice of one of the chiefet Ladies about Court for her Nephew, whom he ever look'd upon as her adopted Son, and in whom he took a more than ordinary delight.

All the actions of our Marhal have always met with the approbation of the Marchiones de Maintenon, who has hew'd all the kindnes to him that could be expected even from a Mother, from the beginning of his appearing at Court till this time; which has been the main caue of his Preferment. Whenever the King had a mind to talk of his great Officers, Madam de Maintenon wou'd eldom let lip the opportunity to enlarge upon the Merits, Vigilancy, Bravery, and undaunted Courage of her beloved Favourite: Thee Encomiums coming from the Mouth of one who had uch a way at Court as Madam de Maintenon; who both at that time and at preent, betows what favours he thinks fit within the verge of it; having by the continual care he has taken to pleae his Majety, got uch an Acendant over this Monarch, that he is, as it were, his right hand, and he eldom does any thing of moment without her Advice: Monieur Boufflers at lat, by her frequent Interceion, was advanc d to the Dignity of a Marhal of France. This was the
highet Pinnacle of her, hopes to ee her Favourite o dignify'd, not quetioning, but if the difficulty were once urmounted, he might find means to accomplih this Match, which he had projected long before; and which without that advantage carce would have come to a happy concluion: for, Madam de Grammont would hardly ever have been prevail'd upon, to give her Daughter in Marriage to Monieur de Boufflers, who was then but a Soldier of Fortune; having, as he was won't to ay, taken a reolution, to betow her upon none les than a Marhal of France, who might be anwerable to that high renown, which the Marhal de Grammont had acquir'd by his Heroick Atchievements.

But we will lay aide for ome time thee Reflections which only appertain to to the Hero of our Hitory, and give you a particular account of ome paages of that Augut Aembly, where were preent all the Noblemen and Ladies of the highet Quality at Court. They entertained one another with a thouand pleaant Stories, and among the ret with everal of their own adventures of Love and Gallantry. For the greater atisfaction of the Reader, we will make choice of ome few of the bet, and uch as eem mot
worthy to be taken notice of, they having been unknown hitherto in publick; and in regard that I was preent at this entertainment; o I will undertake to relate them with all the faithfulnes imaginable.

Madam de Maintenon having for ome time hearken'd to the dicoure of ome of the Ladies, concerning what News lately happen'd in Paris, began to peak thus. Ladies, I am about to give you a relation of a mot Tragical Story, which will appear to be the more particular in its kind, the more extraordinary and urprizing it is in it elf. I have it, added he, from Father La Chaie's own Mouth, not above two days ago, when I was with him lat, and it is o much the more certainly true in regard that it hapned to himelf not above fourteen days before. When you have heard all the circumtances of the whole matter you'll be convinc'd, that ome things are tranacted in Paris, which are bury'd in eternal oblivion. And if it o fall out ometimes that uch like things are dicover'd, tis owing to Providence which brings them to light to convince us of the Vanity of this World, and to make us enible of what abues are daily committed among Men. At the ame time it mut be acknowledg'd, that Gallanary is the famous Theatre, where, thee Tragick Parts are diplaid; this occaions more horrible
crimes than any thing ele that I know of, The following Hitory will furnih us with a notable example to prove my Aertion.

Father La Chaie told me, that on the 24th of April lat pat, about a quarter of an hour after twelve a clock at night, when the whole College of Jeuits were in Bed, there came to the Door of the Monatery a Coach with ix Hores; and a Footman coming from behind the Coach, rung the Bell at the Gate. The Porter, being in his firt Sleep, did not hear him immediately, which made the Footman ring again o loudly, that the Porter was awaken'd at the noie he made. The Porter having ask'd, Who is there? the Footman anwer'd, That he deir'd him to open the Gate. Brother Ambroe (which is the name of the Porter) told him, That 'twas not in his power, becaue the Rector of the College had forbid him to open the Gate o late to any one whatever. The Foot-man made anwer, that they wanted a Father Confeor for a Peron of great Quality, who was jut at the point of Death; and that it was a cae of very urgent neceity. Brother Ambroe, having undertood thee words, open'd the Gate, when the Foot-man told him, That he was come to fetch Father La Chaie; that the ick Peron of whom he had poke before, whoe Name
he was not to tell, was deirous to have Father La Chaie, and no body ele, for ome very weighty reaons, which related to the atisfaction of a wounded Concience, and the Salvation of an immortal Soul. Brother Ambroe told him, That he would go up to Father La Chaie's Chamber, and let him know what he aid. The Foot-man pray'd him to make all poible hate he could, by reaon that no time was to be lot. Brother Ambroe having awaken'd Father La Chaie, inform'd him of what he knew of the matter. Father. La Chaie having ask'd him the Name of the Lord or Lady that ent for him. Brother Ambroe told him, That by the Train and Equipage it hould be a Peron of the highet Quality. He alo told him, that there was a mourning Coach at the Gate, drawn by ix black Hores: That the Coachman, Potilion, and four Foot-men, who attended it, were all cloathed in black; that they appear'd as black in their Faces as Negroes; and that they had no Flamboys along with them, neither could he devie what might be the meaning of it, becaue they refus'd to tell the Name of him who had ent them.

Father La Chaie being by this time got out of Bed, went down to the Gate himelf, where the ame Foot-man, who had poke before to the Porter,
aid, Good Father I entreat you to get up into this Coach with ix Hores. Who is it that ent you to fetch me? reply'd Father La Chaie, Good Father, aid the Foot-man, We came from a Peron of the firt rank in the Kingdom, who deires to impart to you omething of great conequence before he dies. He is not inclin'd to have any other Confeor, but your elf, and we dare not tell his Name, becaue we are forbid it. Father La Chaie, who could not dicover whoe Equipage this was, the Foot-men being all diguis'd by their black Faces, like your very Negroes, thought it mot convenient to advie with the Rector, Praefect, and other Superiors of the Order, whether they would approve of his going along with thoe unknown Perons. He began to make erious reflections upon the matter; his Head being fill'd with jealouies, that perhaps ome Peron of Quality digrac'd at Court, and excited by dicontent, hatred, or revenge, againt his Peron, might by this means endeavour to get him into ome private place or another, there to erve him an Italian trick, without being any more to be heard of for ever.

All the good Fathers being got out of their Beds, and having weigh'd the matter with deliberation, it was reolv'd,
that Father La Chaie, who was o dear to theirwhole Order, ought not to expoe himelf to this hazard. The Rector being of opinion, that ome body ele ought to be ent in his tead. Father Bourdalou generouly offer'd himelf. But being come down, the Foot-man who had poke to Father La Chaie before told him, That they had orders to bring along with 'em none ele but Father La Chaie, and that he need not make any cruple to trut himelf with 'em, they being aur'd that he would be in no more danger, than if he taid in the Convent. For the ret, they deir'd him to conider, That the Welfare of a Soul lay at take, and that it was one of the greatest Men at Court, whoe Concience could not be atisfy'd till he had een him; that there was not much more time to loe; that if he tarry'd one quarter of an hour longer, it was to be fear'd it would be too late, becaue the ick Peron was almot at the lat gap.

p.q:
Father La Chaie, who hews much zeal in matters relating to the Salvation of Souls, being mov'd at thee words; entreated the ret of the Fathers to let him perform his duty in a place whereto his Concience call'd him; and o, in pite of all the diwaions of the Rector, Praefect, and Father Bourdalou, who went down with him to the Gate, he reolv'd
to go, whatever might come of it. Having therefore cros'd himelf three times with the ign of the Cros, he went into the Coach. The Coach-man, lahing the Hores oundly with his Whip, drove away with a full Gallop. Father La Chaie, tho it was very dark, did take as much notice as poibly he could of all the Streets and by-lanes thro which they pat; and tho he knew exactly all the places throughout that vat City; yet he was never able afterwards to find out any of thoe parts thro which he was convey'd; the Coach-man being order'd to drive round about ome parts of the Town, paing and repaing everal times the ame Streets, the better to deceive the Father, and to prevent any dicovery of thoe places thro which they went.

In the mean while Father La Chaie lying along the bottom of the Coach, began to make a thouand ominous Reflections, accuing himelf of Imprudence to have o lightly expos'd himelf to the utmot hazard of his Life. But as the cae now tood, the bet advice he could take was, to et his Concience at ret, and to prepare himelf for Death, in cae he hould have occaion to dye at that intant. Conformably to this Reolution,
he made a full Confeion of his Sins to Almighty God, begging pardon for thoe that he had committed ince his lat Confeion, and for all uch as might not then occur to his Memory, adding, that if he had done ome ill office to ome great Man or another with the King, who tir'd up by his hatred againt him, had reolv'd to make ue of this opportunity to draw him into a Snare, which hould cot him his Life; he pray'd God to forgive him, becaue the Station he was in, of being Confeor to the greatet Monarch, made him againt his Will, often liable to the Dicontents of the Courtiers, who laid claim to ome office or another, which were often betow'd upon others, by his ollicitation.

Having been thus perplex'd in his thoughts for a good half hour, he came to the place where he was to be et down. The Coach having topt, he aw a Foot-man coming out of a great Gate, which was all hung with black Cloath, that hid the Coat of Arms belonging to the Family, to keep it from his ight. The ame Foot-man, having in one Hand a Flamboy made of black Wax, open'd the door of the Coach, and with his other Hand helpt our Father out, who
was conducted into a great and and very fine Palace, all hung with black; everal Foot-men all with Flamboys made of black Wax in their Hands tanding at the Stair-foot, from whence they led him up Stairs, two tories high backwards into a very fine Appartment. All the Dometick Servants were cloathed in black, as were likewie their Faces, hining as if they had been true Black-moors. This was contriv'd on purpoe to deceive Father la Chaie, who perhaps had een them a thouand times in his Life time, but was not able to give the leat gues at them under this diguie.

This Appartment was like all the ret, hung all over with black, and as oon as Father la Chaie was entered, all the Candles were put out at once, o that all upon a udden he was left quite in the dark, and conducted up to the other end of the Room, where a Chair was et for him under a Canopy, upon a piece of Tapetry pread upon the floor. When he was et down, he could hear the voice of a Lady bewailing her elf, and imploring the mercy of a Peron, who as he undertood, was about to put her to death for her unfaithfulnes. Come, come, Madam,
p.U: aid the Nobleman, your Father Confeor is ready, you have but a few moments to live, which you may betow, in ettling your Concience. The time draws near, for me to revenge my elf in puting an end to your Life: I pray God to forgive you your in.

div.p: Immediately after, the Lady was conducted out of an Appartment hard by under favour of the darknes, directly to the place where our Father expected her coming: Father la Chaie by her Confeion, was inform'd of the crime, which was the occaion of her death, but he did not ay one word, either concerning her own Name, or his, who intended to put her to death, and whatever pains he took, he could not bring out one word from her as to that matter; till at lat, the Lady perceiving the curioity of her Confeor, told him, that he was afraid, let his Curioity might prove fatal to him, and that therefore he advis'd him not to dive any farther into the matter, or to oblige her to commit an indicreet Act, becaue, if her Lover hould get the leat notice of it, he would certainly be the death of him, and would perhaps provide for him the ame entertainment, which he was about to receive,

p.q:
There needed nothing ele to ilence our Father; for in an intant
he lot the ue of his Tongue, not peaking o much as one word more, but employ'd the ret of his time in hearkening to this diconolate Lady, whilt he made a particular confeion of all her ins, which, having ask'd pardon of Almighty God, he received Abolution from the Mouth of her Confeor. It is to be oberved that during the whole time, as well as before, that the Lady was with him, they were without light; o that he had not the leat opportunity to know her. But, to come to an end of this Tragical Hitory; no ooner had the Father Confeor pronounc'd thee words: Abolvo te, or I abolve you, but a certain Gentleman-Uher came to re-conduct this unknown Lady into a Room next by, where a Bath was prepar'd for her. After he had been undres'd by her waiting Gentlewomen, he enter'd the Bath, and being et upon a Chair, the Veins in her Arms and Feet were open'd, till all-her Vital Spirits having left her with the Blood, he dy'd in the ame manner, as Seneca did heretofore, this being look'd upon as one of the mot gentle kinds of death.

Father la Chaie was re-conducted to the ame Coach, which had brought
him thither, attended by the ame Coach-man and Foot-men, who carry'd him back to the Convent, but by a quite different way, than what they had pas'd thro before, having made o many turnings and windings, that 'twas impoible for the good Father to remember them, who, beides this, was very glad to ee himelf return afe and ound, and to have paid no dearer for his Journey. As oon as they were come again to the Gate of the Monatery, one of the Foot-men open'd the Coach-door, and rung the Bell to awaken the Porter. Father la Chaie coming out of the Coach, had no ooner et his Feet to the ground, but away drove the Coach-man, whip and lah immediately out of ight, not taying to ee whether the Gate were open'd or not. As oon as the Porter had let Father la Chaie in, he went up directly to the Chamber of the Rector and the Praefect; O my good Fathers! aid he, I never heard of any decription of Hell more terrible than what I have een, ince I left you. Every thing about me was black and frightful, the mot dimal Funeral pomp that ever was beheld. Then Father la Chaie gave 'em an exact account of all that had pas'd, without being able to tell 'em one word, which
might contribute any thing towards the dicovery of the Noble Man's Name, or of that of the Lady, who had received Abolution from him. The good Fathers were extremely urpriz'd at the trangenes of the Matter of Fact, which appear'd to 'em o terrible, and o Tragical, that the like had not been known in Paris, in the Memory of Man: And what I have told you, added Madam de Maintenon, is true even beyond contradiction, Father la Chaie being the Man who was concern'd in that Affair, no longer than ome few weeks ago; from whoe own Mouth I have received it, with all thee circumtances, which I have related to you.

div.p:
Madam, anwered Monieur de Surlaube, Love is a trange capricious Paion, it is the caue of great Evils in this World, the fewet of which come to our Knowledge, the ret being bury'd in Eternal Oblivion. If Men are once poes'd with jealouie, it makes 'em furious, and incapable of Compaion towards their Mitrees; the leat lip they make, is ufficient to raie in 'em a upicion of Unfaithfulnes, which is enough for 'em to render their Mitrees Criminal in their ight. I cannot deny it, Sir, reply'd Madam de Maintenon, but Methinks this Crime ought not to be look'd upon as o enormous, as not to be expiated without
death. A Gentleman of Honour ought to take Compaion of the frailty of the Fair Sex. And if they will needs make it a rule to be inexorable upon that account towards their Mitrees, why hould not they with jutice, pretend to the ame right, to inflict uch rigorous Punihments upon their Lovers when they prove treacherous. We are pretty well acquairted with the Qualities of your Sex, added the Marchiones, if Women are ometimes unfaithful, you I am ure a thouand times more; the leat thing in the world makes you changeable. How many do you think there are of your Men of Fortune in the World whom Baron has o lively repreented in his Comedys? I believe there are very few among you all, but what may find their true Character there; and turn it which ide you will, you do us the greatet Injutice in the World, thus to exercie your Tyranny, in exacting a blind Obedience from our Sex, and to deprive us of that mall hare of Liberty which is allowed us. If you Gentlemen were all to be put to death, as this poor Lady was, of whom you have heard this Tragical Relation, as often as you prove perjur'd and unfaithful to thoe everal Ladies unto whom you have worn one after another an inviolable Love, confirm'd by mot acred Oaths, the common Language of Lovers; I believe verily there would carce be any one living but that deerv'd to undergo the like Capital punihment.

p.U:
aid the Marhal de Lorge, you have fairly hewn your skill in pleading the Caue of your Sex; but I hope you will give me leave to tell you, that their natural contitution eems to require from them more Reervednes, Contancy and Fidelity, than from us Men. This is the only Heroick Vertue in your Sex, to be faithful; this is the only Charm by which you captivate us, and which makes Men o paionate towards you, and which beides this, ditinguihes Vertuous Women from the crowd of wanton Jilts, and common Protitues; who ought to be eteem'd as Monters; and for whom a Man of Honour can never have thoe entiments which are, as it were, Spice to make Love avoury to the tate. Inomuch that upon the whole, this fickle Humour in Menought to be conider'd as a light Trepas, and not as a Capital Crime; as you would willingly repreent it. If a Man has more Mitrees than one, he may be repected for all that, as a Gentleman of Honour and Probity; whereas a Woman that protitutes her elf to many, loes inevitably all that modet and innocent behaviour, which are the ineparable Companions of Vertuous Women; and without which 'tis impoible for a Man to be charm'd, or to be made enible of any real atisfaction from a Lady who does not poes thee Endowments. The Marhal de Lorge is in the right on't, aid the Count de Surlaube. Your too forward Women are jut like your parkling Wines, no body cares to buy them.
That which renders Love delicious, and which makes Men amorous and paionate, is that Innocence which we admire in the Peron belov'd. The mot real and weetet pleaure, a Man is capable of enjoying with his Mitres, is, the delight he takes to intruct and breed up a young tender Heart, which may be compar'd to your pure Wines, which are till upon the Lees; or to a Roe gather'd early in the Spring, when it jut begins to bud: And that is, what properly ought to be call'd a Maiden-head, without eeking any further for it, as mot Men do, who eldom find it any where ele, but in conceit, when their Brains are heated with amorous Fancies.

div.p:
Madam, added the Count, addreing his Speech to Madam de Maintenon, We are here teaching a Doctrine, which may eem to avour omewhat of Libertinim, and which I don't know how it may relih with you: All I have to ay is, that conidering the circumtances of the time, our Friend Boufflers being o near his Wedding-day, we could carce pick out a more agreeable and diverting Subject. One may, without Flattery, continu'd the Count laughing, tell him, that he is the happiet of all Men in the choice of a Mitres, who will make him enible of all thoe Charms we have poke of jut now with o much Commendation. Mademoielle de Grammont is one of thoe rare Beauties, which have not as yet been brought
to light, and whom the God of Love himelf takes care to intruct in his Charms, and to make her enible of all his myteries. The Abby of St. Cyr, where he has reided of late, has not been a little intrumental in preerving thee charming Qualities, which few of your young Ladies in Paris can boat of, who perhaps have been more converant in the Affairs of the World, and have had the opportunity of making more Conquets, but which, if truly conidered, are nothing but Vanities. For example, why mut we be peter'd with o many Abbey-Lubbers about the Town, who make it their chief buines to viit Ladies, and to talk to them of their Paion? How many beautiful Damels are there in Paris, who are fond of the flattering Praies betow'd upon them by thee ininuating Tartuffs, who ought to ay their Breviary, intead of playing the Gallants? I am not able to endure, Madam, continu'd the Count, all thee Extravagancies, I cannot but pity on one ide thoe poor imple Creatures, who uffer themelves thus to be cajoled by thee Sparks with their little Bands; and on the other, I am at the ame time urprized at the Impudence of thee Racals, who acting the Libertine, do not make any Concience of educing abundance of young Gentlewomen of very good Quality, who quite poil their Fortune by thee extravagant Coures.

p.q: I do declare to you, reply'd the Marchiones de Maintenon, that I am no great Friend of thee Sparks of the Collar-band; and if his Majety wou'd follow my Advice in this particular. I wou'd have 'em meddle with nothing but their Breviary, without giving 'em the opportunity to camper about to Debauch our young Women. If they have not the Gift of Continency, and the Frailty of their Fleh will not admit of this Doctrin taught by the Holy Fathers; I wou'd have their black Coats pull'd over their Ears, to give 'em intead of it, a red Cloak and Sword, that they may have liberty to Marry.

O Madam, anwer'd the Count, 'tis under the Cover of their long Robes that they play the bet of their Game; not to take notice here, of their Revenues and fat Benefices, which make 'em appear o frehcolour'd and of o ruddy a Complexion: It eems to me, as if thee Sparks had alone the Touch-tone in Hand, to try the goodnes of all orts of Metals; there is not a avoury Bit in Paris, but they have it at their Devotion. The mot part of young Women are led away by 'em, as it were by o many Sirens, which inchant 'em by their Allurements, and the weetnes of their Voice; for mot of thee Gentlemen are well skill'd in Muick, which is in great
eteem among the Fair Sex, who love to have their Ears tickl'd with harmonious Strains, by which Bait they may eaily inchant 'em o far, as to catch 'em in their Nets.

Let us not be any longer diturb'd with thee Abbots, aid Monieur Boufflers, let us talk of us Men of the Blade, who are the truely generous Souls; being very erviceable both to the State, and to the Common-wealth of Beauty, whoe Repreentatives they always treat upon Honour. We are, added he, like Gold, the truet and bet of all Metals, and if we were concious to our elves of having the leat wrong'd the Female Sex, we hou'd think our elves unworthy of wearing a Sword. Hold, Sir, reply'd the Count de Surlaube, you run too fat; you do very well to Hector it in o good Company: For if we hou'd begin to reheare all your amourous Exploits, I quetion whether you cou'd with Jutice, make appear o much Sincerity on your ide. But come, added he, we will not be too hard upon you at this time; Marriage is likely to cure you of this Volatile Humour, which was wont to carry you from one fair Lady to another; and you will be forc'd at lat, in pite of your elf, to ubmit to thoe Chains and Fetter-Locks, which Love has prepar'd for you
by Mademoielle de Grammont. I am perwaded, you will look upon 'em as very glorious for you, becaue you have all the reaon in the World to flatter your elf, of having obtain'd the mot precious Jewel in France, and having marry'd the mot accomplih'd Lady of the whole Court.

div.p:
The Duke du Maine, who had not as yet been to complement Monieur de Boufflers and Mademoielle de Grammont upon their intended Marriage, coming into the Room, did for ome few moments interrupt their former Dicoure. And the Marchiones de Maintenon, having look'd upon her Watch, to ee what a Clock it might be, roe up from her Seat, and told the Company, That he was, by Order from his Majety, to be at Court at a prefix'd time, about ome Buines of great Conequence. As oon as he was gone into her Coach, the Lords and Ladies began to it round again, every one in his own place, paing away the time, till the Collation hou'd be ready, which was preparing for 'em. The Duke du Maine told 'em, That he was jut now come from the Abbot Tallement's, where he had pent an Hour the mot agreeably, that ever he did in his Life-time. The Ladies ask'd him, With what? The Duke du Maine told 'em, That he had een there, ome of the finet Pictures that cou'd be, and among the ret,
a mot curious Piece, in which the Ladies have a more particular Concern. In this Picture, aid he, are contracted all the Perfections of the Fair Sex, to that degree, that there is not any one wanting, to make the Copy abolutely like the Original. To be hort, it is an univeral Piece, where all at once, are repreented both their good and bad Qualities. And, what is the mot urpriing, all is done at one and the ame time, without the leat alteration.

The Ladies being over-curious to be better inform'd concerning all the Circumtances of this Picture, which eem'd to be a Riddle to 'em, and urpas'd all their Imagination, begg'd heartily of the Duke, to give 'em a full Decription of it. This I will do, reply'd the Prince, with a certain malicious Smile, but it is purely out of Complaiance and Obedience to your Commands. I am enible, that Ladies love to hear a Declamation in their Praie, and that they wou'd willingly have their good Qualities made known to the World; and I know not any thing which will uit better with their Humour, or pleae 'em better, than this following Decription. I was jut now, continu'd he, with the Abbot de Tallement, one perhaps of the mot curious Men in Europe. After he had conducted me into
his Cloet, he hew'd me a Piece, in which was repreented a very ugly Head: It had 3 Mouths, 6 Eyes, and 3 Noes, o that it appear'd to me like a Monter. Beides this, there was painted on one ide a Magpye and a Peacock; and on the other, a moaking Chimney.

The Abbot ask'd me, Whether I undertood the Riddle, and whether I was enible of the rarity of the Piece? I anwer'd him, That I cou'd ee nothing, but what appear'd to me very gros and confus'd. And that beides, I did not undertand the meaning of this Hieroglyphick, deiring him to explain it to me. Sir, aid the Abbot, pray hut your left Eye, and with the other, look through this Hole. I did as the Abbot had directed me, who having taken a Cylinder, made of a piece of polih'd Steel, he fix'd it oppoite to the Hole through which I look'd. In an intant, this Monter of a Head, the Magpye, the Peacock and the Chimney-piece, were, by a udden Metamorphois, chang'd into a Woman's Head, the finet and handomet that ever I aw. The Abbot, having with one Hand, cover'd the Figure which repreented the Magpye, the Mouths immediately diappear'd; o that nothing was een in the Cylinder but a Woman's Head, without a Mouth: Afterwards, having laid his Hand
upon one of the Eyes, that were painted on the Piece, I cou'd not ee any thing in the Cylinder, but one Eye. I never in all my Life time, added the Duke du Maine, have een uch a curious Piece in the Opticks. The Ladies, who began to be impatient to hear the Explication of it, cou'd not forbear interrupting the Prince, deiring him that he wou'd be pleas'd to explain to 'em the everal Pieces, of which this Picture was compo'd. Ladies, aid the Duke du Maine, the 6 Eyes denote, that the Women wou'd ee all Things; the 3 Mouths, that they always begin to Talk firt, and leave off lat; the 3 Noes give us to undertand, that they have a very quick Scent, and won't be eaily deceiv'd; the Peacock hews their Vanity; and the Magpye ignifies, that they are always Chattering and Quarrelling: Latly, the Chimney and Smoak are a Repreentation of their Incontancy and fickle Humour; and all thee Qualities are o eential to the Perfection of the Head, repreented in the Cylinder; that if but any one of 'em be wanting, the whole is imperfect, as I have told you before.

p.q: We mut confes, aid all the Ladies in general, this Picture has omewhat urpriing in it.

You mut look upon it, added the Marhal, as a Panegyrick, in Short-hand-Writing, upon your Sex. It's
true, Sir, reply'd Madam de Tilladet, but this Encomium only exprees our bad Qualities. What, aid he, addreing her elf to the Duke du Maine, Sir, won't you do us the favour as to give us an account of ome of your Opticks, which may make amends for this, by repreenting us on the bet ide, with all thoe rare Accomplihments which captivate your Hearts, and make you our Slaves to wear our Chains, and to pay us Hommage. This is true, anwer'd the Duke du Maine, but it is much againt our Will. At the ame time, Ladys, added he, I wou'd not have you think me o vain, as to pretend to et up for a Critick, or to draw upon my elf the ill Will, as poor Orpheus did heretofore, of o trong a party, as the Women are. Whatever I have aid, was done meerly out of complaiance, and to atisfy your Curioity.

div.p:
Madam de Tilladet eeing how dextrous the Duke was at turning the matter from himelf, and in making his Apology to the fair Sex, for whom he had always hewn a mot particular eteem, being one of the mot Gallant Princes about the Court; told him, That 'twas reolv'd among 'em, that all the Ladys there preent, hou'd go to Morrow, in a Body to the Abbot Tallement, on purpoe to ask him, whether, what the
Prince had related to 'em, were really o; and that if they cou'd get this Picture, o injurious to their Sex, into their Hands, they hou'd make a Bonfire of it, and burn it in ome publick Place, as 'tis uual to do with Books that treat of Magick. I mut confes to you, Ladies, reply'd the Duke du Maine, that I took it no otherwie at firt, till the Abbot Tallement dicover'd to me the whole buines, and convinc'd me, that every particular of it, was a neceary conequence of the Rules of Opticks, He hew'd me another Piece, no les urpriing than the former, and which eems to contain omewhat upernatural in its kind: It is a Venice Looking-glas, which repreents People that look into it, tark naked, If I were Monieur de Boufflers, I wou'd go thither with Mademoielle de Grammont. This Looking-glas will give him a faithful repreentation of thoe Beauties, which young Ladys take o much pains to hide from their Lovers: And at once looking only in the Glas with his Mitres, he may learn more in one Moment, than two Months Courthip, and erious Converation are able to teach him. Away, away, with thee Triffles, anwer'd Mademoielle de Grammont, with a charming and pleaant Air, the Marhal has no occaion either for a Confident or for a Looking-Glas
to dicover my Defects. He is wie enough of himelf, not to be urpris'd or to be impos'd upon.

p.q: Ladys, reply'd the Duke du Maine, ince thee pieces of Gallantry do put you out of Humour, come let us have a touch at Morality. The Abbot, aid he, hew'd me among the ret, another Piece, which was no les urpriing than the former, and as far as I remember, I never aw any thing finer, and more curious in my Life time. Well, let us hear what it is, aid Monieur de Boufflers, but let me deire you, Sir, not to offer any thing, to affront the fair Sex: I mut needs tell you, that I am o very nice in that point, that I declare to you, I hall be ready to revenge their Quarrel, and even not to grudge, to employ my Sword in their jut Defence, if there hou'd be occaion for it. Wherefore Sir, added he miling, and you had bet have a care what you do. No, no, reply'd the Duke du Maine, this has no relation more to one Sex than the other; but all People are concern'd in it.

The Abbot Tallement hew'd me a large Painting, divided into three Columns: In the middle Column on the right hand, was repreented, firt of all, our Holy Father the Pope, as being the Chief of the Church, after him follow all the Cardinals; Arch-bihops, Bihops, Prelates, Abbots, Curates,
and in general, all the ret of the Members of the Clergy. In the Column on the right ide, you might ee a great many Portraitures, repreenting Temporal Princes, as Emperors, Monarchs, Kings and other Princes, follow'd by the Nobility and a multitude of Courtiers. The Column, which was on the left ide, was fill'd up, with the third Etate repreenting the Courts of Jutice; where you might ee the Pictures of Lords Chief Jutices and Judges, Maters of the Rolls, Counellors, Attorneys, Sollicitors, Notaries, Tiptaffs, Serjeants and uch like. So, that this whole Piece was fill'd up, with an infinite number of all orts of Perons belonging to the three Etates, every one in his Habit, according to the rank he bore in the Church, in the State or in the Courts of Judicature. The Abbot, after I had taken notice of the Medley, deir'd me to put one Eye to a Hole at one end of the Picture, and from thence to look upon the Cylinder which he had plac'd oppoite to it, at the other end of it: All thee different Objects, having made a reflection upon the Cylinder of polih'd Steel, this Intrument did repreent, no otherwie, than in a Looking-glas, a Death's Head, extremely well done; to put us in mind of the end of all Mortal Men, who in what tation oever,
mut all pay this lat Tribute to Nature.

I aure you, aid Monieur Boufflers, this eems to me, to be one of the mot curious Pieces that ever was made in the World, and I will give you my Word, that Mademoielle de Grammont and I, will to Morrow, do our elves the Honour to go and wait upon the Abbot, and take a view of all his Curioities. But that which is mot admirable in this Piece, is, added the Duke du Maine, that if you cover any part of thee Pictures, contain'd in the three Columns, with your Hand; the Death's Head, which is reflected in the Cylinder, appears defective, and there is ome part or another of it wanting; to convince us, that none can be exempted from the unavoidable neceity of Dying. We entreat you, aid the Ladies, directing their Dicoure to the Duke du Maine, let us not talk any more of this doleful and frightful Subject, Death. Let us rather return to our Jollities, and divert our elves with ome Pleaant Story or another; they are mot eaonable at this time, when we are met together, on purpoe to be merry and pleaant. Mademoielle de Grammont is mot concern'd in the matter, and it is chiefly upon her account, that the Ladys deire it. Becaue you will have it o, aid the Duke du Maine, I will relate to you
another very extraordinary Story, which perhaps you will look upon, as one of the mot refin'd pieces of Necromancy; the whole being altogether full of Gallantry.
The Abbot, continu'd he, having given us a view of all the Rarities in his Cloet, took me on one ide, whipering me in the Ear.
p.hi: Pray my Lord, bring the Ladys who came along with you, into this Spacious Appartment, I have a mind to hew you the Materpiece of all my Rarities; but don't you peak one word to 'em, you will divert your elf extremely, provided you let 'em know nothing of the matter; becaue they will perhaps be unwilling to ee this Curioity which indeed, will be very well worth your trrouble, and will undoubtedly give you more atisfaction, than any thing that you aw before.
p.q: I went therefore, to fetch in the Ladys, and having taken the Dutches de Chevreue by the Hand, to lead her into a very fair and pacious Room, which was jut by; the ret of the Ladys follow'd us thither. No ooner were we all enter'd the Room, but the Abbor, having drawn a Curtain, and open'd certain Windows; we look'd into a great Plain, which extended it elf beyond our Sight, and which appear'd to us, to be one of the bet and fairet Landskips in the World.

div.p:
Sir, aid the Abbot to me, do you ee that Country-man and young Country-damel
there in the Meadows, I will make 'em come hither in an intant, in the ame moment that I give the Word of Command, they hall come and preent themelves in this Looking-glas. This was an extraordinary fine Venice-glas, of about ix Foot high, cover'd with a green Curtain; the Ladys, who upected ome trick or another, began to laugh, but at the ame time, gave the Abbot to undertand, that they were very impatient to ee the iue of it, becaue the Peaant and the Damel were at above a Mile's ditance from us: The Abbot, to atisfie the curioity of the Ladys, who were very eager, took a Speaking Trumpet (the Invention of Sir Samuel Moreland, an Englih Knight) and pronounc'd thee Words; You young Damel, pull off your hoes, and come hither. The Damel obey'd immediately, and at that very intant, appear'd in the Looking-glas. For the Abbot, having drawn away the Curtain, which cover'd the Glas, and told the Ladys, that they hou'd take notice of what they aw; they were very much urpris'd to ee the ame Damel tark Naked in the Glas, which made 'em put their hands before their Eyes, tho' at the ame time, they laugh'd as heartily as they cou'd. Sir, aid they, we have enough of this, it being more than we are able to comprehend; and we know our
hapes well enough before hand, without your Inchanting Looking-glas. Lady's anwer'd the Abbot, this is not all, I have another diverion for you, before we part. You Damel, aid he, put on your Cloaths, and go from whence you come. This being done, he again took his Speaking Trumpet, and having call'd the Peaant, he immediately appear'd in the Looking-glas in the like manner, without any thing to cover his Nakednes; at this Spectacle, the Ladys with bluhes in their Cheecks, run quite to the other end of the Room, tho' they cou'd not forbear laughing at the ame time.

p.q: For my part, aid the Duke du Maine, I did all that lay in my Power, to make the Ladys return to the Looking-glas, but cou'd not prevail upon 'em. At lat having diverted our elves with thee everal orts of mot urpriing Adventures; the Abbot commanded the Peaant to take his Cloaths, and be gone immediately, which he did in an intant, and flew away from our Eyes like Lightning.
p.U:
aid I, you are more skilful than all the Magicians put together; I wih I cou'd learn your Art, the better to divert ome Ladys at Court, who ometimes give me the Honour of a Viit. Thus Ladys, continu'd the Prince, I have given you a very diverting Story; which, methinks, hou'd pleae you all, and if you
will vouchafe to take my advice, I wou'd have every one of you get you uch a Looking-glas in your Chamber, in which you may be able to take a full view of your Beauty, and of thoe Charms that make Men to be uch Fools, as to run after you, and which you are always o careful to hide from our ight. Sir, anwer'd Madam de Tilladet, if uch ort of Pictures were expos'd to publick view, they wou'd appear frightful to you; it is more afe to have 'em only in your imagination. Nothing is more in eteem among us, than what is conceal'd from us, and it is perhaps that which makes Love relih o well, and draws that repect from you, which you pay to the fair Sex.

div.p: Supper-time being come, the Company broke up, leaving the Marhal de Bouffiers and Mademoielle de Grammont by themelves, who pent the ret of the time in Amourous, Carees; for Monieur Boufflers did not part with his Mitres till pretty late at Night, when he went home to Bed; but his Head being diturb'd with Amorous Fancies, he was not able to ret all the Night, ometimes he flatter'd himelf that in time, his Mitre's Heart wou'd be mollifi'd, who hitherto look'd but coldly upon him, yet o as to treat him Honourably and Civilly. I want omething ele beides Complements, aid he, this not being that which can make me happy.

Thus he tormented himelf Day and Night, which made him appear in a very Melancholy and Languihing condition, his Countenance being quite alter'd, o as to be carce like himelf; which at lat turn'd to his Advantage; for Mademoielle de Grammont having taken particular notice of it, begun to Commierate his Condition, and one time when he complain'd to her of his Sufferings; Truly Sir, aid he, I am mov'd with Compaion for you, and I begin to hear ome hare in your Trouble. She poke thee words with o weet and o charming an Air, that the Marhal did now no longer quetion, but that he was belov'd by her. Monieur de Boufflers having receiv'd this aurance, manag'd his Affairs with o much dexterity, that he at lat overcame the rigor of his fair Mitres.

The news being oon pread abroad, that he was upon the point of being Marry'd, every one came to Complement our two Lovers, and the King himelf, who had receiv'd the News from Madam Maintenon's own Mouth, poke to our General, concerning this Match, in very obliging Terms; which prov'd a means to engage his Mitres more trictly to him than before. They pent their whole time in nothing but Feating, going abroad, Balls, Plays; and uch like diverions, which made a great noie
about the Town, being all perform'd with a great deal of Magnificence; o that this Conquet cot our General not only a great deal of Trouble, but alo good tore of Mony. In the mean time, in regard that he was of a very hot Contitution, and that his Mitres was the nicet Woman in the World, as to the point of granting him the leat Favour, beides that he bore o extraordinary a Repect to her, as carce to dare to teal a Kis from her; he reolv'd (in order to allay a little his natural Heat) to court a pretty young Damel, whom he had een at Boulogn, not far from Paris, imagining, that ince his Match was o far advanc'd, uch a piece of Gallantry, if it hou'd happen to be dicover'd, cou'd not prove any Obtacle to it. Conform bly to this Reolution, he often went to viit this Damel, diguis'd in the Habit of a Country-man, for fear of being known by any one, to his Prejudice.

One Day, Mademoielle de Grammont happen'd to go to the ame Village, with ome of her Friends, to ee a Nure who had had the Nuring of her, when the Marhal came jut from viiting his Country-Mitres; and having been oberv'd by the Nure, Pray, Mademoielle, aid he, look upon that young Country-Fellow, what a genteel Spark he is; he comes very frequently of late to that Houe, to ee a certain young Damel, the handomet, I
believe in a hunder'd Miles round. The Marhal was o near 'em, that they might eaily dicern his Face, which made Mademoielle de Grammont ay to one of the Ladies that was with with her; I vow my Dearet he is as like the Marhal de Boufflers, as one drop of Water to another. The Marhal having heard his Name mention'd by his Mitres, immediately camper'd out of the Village, to an adjacent Wood, where he chang'd his Country-Habit, for his own Cloaths, which he had left there before, with one of his Servants.

Mademoielle de Grammont, being curious without any further deign, having not the leat upicion that it was the General, whom he had een come out, wou'd needs go to ee this fair Country-damel; and was extremely taken with her charming Beauty. Her Nure told her, that he was natural Daughter of the Count de Harcourt, by whom her Mother, who was as Beautiful as the Daughter, had had two or three Children; and as to the Country-man, who came to Viit her, no body cou'd tell who he was, but that he was generally believ'd to be ome Peron of Quality under a diguie. Mademoielle de Grammont, making no further reflections upon the matter, only told the Nure, That he cou'd not imagine who he hou'd be, but that he reembl'd as much as one Brother does another, the Peron he had poke
of before. O! reply'd the good Woman, embracing her, I have heard it talk'd of among us, that you are going to be Marry'd to that Monieur Boufflers, who makes o much noie in the World. Indeed it is much dicours'd of, aid he, my Friends are buie in making up the Match: if it comes to a concluion, you hall be at the Wedding. That is evident of it elf, anwer'd he, What? a Child, that I have o carefully Nurs'd, hou'd he not let me have a hare in that merry day? Alas! if your dear Father, the late Marhal de Grammont, God bles his Soul, had been alive, I hou'd have at at the upper end of the Table; Ay marry hou'd I, becaue he had promis'd it me a great while ago. Don't trouble thy elf upon that account, Foncette, reply'd Mademoielle de Grammont, taking her by the hand, thou halt certainly be there, tho' not jut at the upper end of the Table, for thou know't that that belongs to the Mitres of the Feat; all my Kindred have a kindnes for thee for my ake. When he had poke thee words, he put a Piece of Gold in her Hand, and o went in her Coach with her Companions, and an Aunt of hers, directly taking their way to Paris.

But the Marhal de Boufflers, who had watch'd their coming back upon the road, accoting 'em on foot with one Servant only, they deir'd him to come into their Coach; Mademoielle de Grammont, having ask'd him, what cou'd induce him to take o long a walk? I
do not very well know, Mademoielle, aid he, rubbing his Forehead, and looking upon her with a paionate Eye, thoe Commotions which Love has rais'd in my Heart, have uch trange Influences over my Spirit, that I think the olitary Deerts and frightful Forets, the most uitable to my Humour. The Ladies, who were preent, did not in the leat quetion but that this Complement was addres'd to Mademoielle de Grammont, who, at this time, had the leat hare in it; his Mind being at that intant, taken up with the Beauty of his Country-damel, whom nevertheles, he was fain to abandon at leat for ome time, for fear of poiling the whole Buines, if the Hony-Pot hou'd be dicover'd: In the mean while finding, that by the overflowing Heat of his Love, he had poil'd the Country-damel's Shape, he thought it mot convenient to provide her a Husband, before it was too late; and having found out a Water-man of his Acquaintance belonging to the River Seine, he gave him 20 or 30 Pitoles, as a Portion with his Wife, to make him ome amends for his Horn-work, which he afterwards took care to make a regular Fortification, by adding everal new Bations and Half-moons in the Front of the Place.

Some Weeks after, Mademoielle de Grammont, who had not yet forgot the beautiful Country-damel he had een at Boulogn, talking
of the Gallantries of the Count de Harcourt, whoe Mitres this young Woman's Mother had been, told the Marhal, that he had een there, a certain Man as like him as cou'd be in all repects, except in his Cloaths, which were very ordinary. The Marhal, who otherwie is not very hamefac'd, bluh'd at thee words; his Heart accuing him of Treachery, the common vice of Men, and our fair Lady having oberv'd his Colour to go and come, Ha! aid he, one while a Fluh appears in your Face, and anon you grow pale again. Sir, urely you have had a finger in the Pye, as the aying is, and indeed your looks betray your Guilt. And what Guilt pray, Mademoielle, reply'd the Marhal? No les than high Treaon, aid he with a mile; Poibly you have infring'd that fidelity which you have o often worn to me you wou'd keep inviolably. Certainly, my mot charming Creature, anwer'd the Marques de Boufflers, you are only in jet, and throwing himelf at her Feet, is it poible, aid he, for you to imagine, that any thing in the World, cou'd appear to me more worthy of all my care, and that does better deerve the entire dipoal of my Heart, than you? O! do me more Jutice, or ele I hall not be able to live any longer. Then I wou'd have you live; aid he, altho' poibly I might be mitaken, yet I am willing to believe you the mot innocent of all Men. Can any thing be parallel'd to my preent happines, cry'd the Marhal
tranported with Joy; Since I have met with a Peron endu'd with o much Good Nature and Generoity, and capable of curing her elf o oon, of the Ditemper of Mitrutfulnes, which is certainly the greatet Evil that can befal any one in this World. For either it is requiite to relye upon a Confident or not, and if one cannot put trut in a Friend, what atisfaction can there be in this Life? You ay very well, Sir, reply'd the young Lady, but you'll allow, that if one loves a Friend, one is very unwilling to loe him, and that is the true caue of Mitrutfulnes. Then you own you love me a little, aid the Marhal, looking upon her very tenderly. At this very Moment my adorable Deity it is, that I can properly call my elf happy. And do you quetion it, Sir, reply'd Mademoielle de Grammont, is it poible to marry a Man, without loving him? Indeed that is a thing, I cou'd never do; I hou'd not be of the ame mind, as ome of our light Houe-wives are, who Marry a Man meerly to erve 'em as a Cloak for their extravagancies. Your Gallants, continu'd he, will find very lender entertainment with me. When I am Marry'd my Husband is to be my All in All, and I hou'd think my elf very happy, if I were ole Mitres of his Affections. And as I never can love any Man beides him, whom my Detiny has provided for me; o he ought not to doubt, but that I hall always be entirely at his Devotion. And is it eaie to be believ'd, Mademoielle,
reply'd Boufflers, that a Peron o adorable at your elf, whoe ingular Merits are o well known to all the World, and who has been always urrounded with o many Adorers; hou'd never as yet have had a kindnes for any Gentleman before? Sure your Heart mut needs be made of a very hard ort of Metal, to have been Proof againt o many Sighs and Tears, as have been o lavihly betow'd upon you. Certainly 'tis almot pat belief, conidering you are o Lovely, o Engaging and Trancendently Beautiful. Nothing is more true than what I have told you, Sir, reply'd the fair Lady, and I did not deliver my Mind with o much freedom, on purpoe to be complemented by you; but only to let you know, that I hall for ever place all my Joy and Felicity in preerving my Heart entire for him, who has o much deerv'd it.

But now the time of Courthip being pas'd, it was thought convenient to come to the Conummation of a Match, in which the Court took o much concern; and the Marhal was preparing to go to Church with Mademoielle de Grammont; which he did one Morning early at ix a Clock, when they were Marry'd by the Archbihop of Paris in the Church of our Lady. The Ceremony being over, and the Marhal thinking himelf now at the very point of cating Anchor in the Port of Felicity, he cou'd not without a great deal of affliction undertand from
Mademoielle de Grammont, that he was not at preent in a condition to go to Bed with him, being diturb'd at that time, with a certain Infirmity incident to all young Women once a Month: The Marhal wou'd have made a Jet of it, but his Lady being poitive in her Reolution, he was o Complaiant, as to languih three Days longer. The next Day after the Wedding, a great number of Perons of Quality, who were invited to a umptuous Feat and Ball, that was to be that Evening; came to Congratulate our Marhal for the happy Minutes he had enjoy'd the Night before with his Spoue; whom they look'd upon as a Peron o full of Charms, as to be capable of giving all poible atisfaction, as to what Men can imagine mot delicious in Love; But he, who had not as yet tated of the Sweat-meat, receiv'd their Complements with o much coldnes and indifferency, that the whole Company was much urpris'd at it. The Count de Montal at lat, unto whom the Marhal, as to a mot intimate Friend, had told the buines, unfolded the Riddle to ome, who made themelves very merry with it in our General's preence. The Marriage being at lat conummated with a great deal of atisfaction on both ides, they receiv'd for 8 or 10 Weeks ucceively, the Viits of mot Perons of Quality at Court; and the Marhal after having reap'd the firt Fruits of the Matrimonial State, was by vertue of his Majeties pecial Command, oblig'd to go to Flanders, not without a mot enible regret of being forc'd o oon to quit his adorable Spoue.
